This game is surprisingly good! The movement, combat, and exploration mechanics are unique and well designed. The story is incredibly deep and more realistic than I was expecting. Much like The Witcher, this game captures everything I love about an open world RPG despite having a fixed protagonist identity. The game-play expertly weaves in a healthy amount of elemental complexity and stealth tactics with next-level weak-spot targeting. I've never been happier fighting primarily with a bow! Even the need to manually save at campfires, which initially made me nervous, was manageable and mitigated by the auto-saves generated by both quest progression and datapoint scans. Overall, I strongly recommend Horizon Zero Dawn and the Frozen Wilds DLC to anyone who loves open world RPGs! You'll especially love it if the idea of hunting dinosaur-esque mechs excites you, or if you like post-apocalypse settings.

P.S. My only complaint mechanically was the potions and utility menu. I did not like how I had to scroll (left/right on the d-pad of an Xbox controller) to get to each item during combat, with no ability to use items directly from the inventory screen. Alternatively, in addition to the fixed medicine pouch direction, I would have preferred to set potions, traps, and utilities to the other three directions. Then a single click to use or hold to open up a sub menu.
Great overall game design and amazing visuals.

Horizon Zero Dawn was one of the first games that Sony ported from PlayStation to PC, something they are doing regularly these days. When it originally launched, it was very well received, which, at first, I was a bit skeptical about. The reason being that the concept is a bit generic. It’s an open-world game that takes place in a post-apocalyptic setting where the remains of humanity once again live in tribes, and machines have taken over. Maybe it’s just me, but I thought it was a bit uninspiring.
Until I started playing and realized I was wrong because what really matters isn’t the concept but the execution. And the execution is great. The open-world structure and objectives are nothing we haven’t seen before, but it’s one of those rare games where it’s fun to explore and do everything on the map. It rarely felt like a chore to me, and I 100% completed it. Especially considering that Sony at the time usually published more linear single-player titles.
The story is enjoyable. You’ll learn about this world and its tribes, as well as figure out why the world is in its current state. All while dealing with a threat that threatens all humanity once again. There’s also a nice variety of likable characters, and Aloy, the main character, is very charismatic. At times you can make some choices, but they don’t affect the story in a meaningful way.
Gameplay is mostly a third-person RPG. You’ll be fighting different machines, all inspired by animals, mostly with bows at range but also with a spear at melee. They have different patterns and weaknesses, since the game features basic elemental effects as well. By defeating enemies, you’ll get parts that you can use to buy stronger weapons. But progression isn’t like your typical RPG.
For starters, leveling up increases your health but doesn’t make you do more damage. The same applies to the weapons since they don’t have levels. What stronger weapons have is different ammo types, expanding your options, and also more modification slots, which are key. Throughout the game, you’ll get different modifications that are basically adding stats like damage, handling, and elemental power. Figuring out the best combinations and using them effectively is how you get stronger, and I like this simpler approach to progression.
In the beginning, combat is alright, but mostly because your options are more limited. Once you get access to better weapons and have more skills, unlocked by completing quests and leveling up, combat opens up and becomes much more enjoyable. It’s very satisfying and epic when you’re fighting the stronger machines the first time.
Also, a part of the reason I find the combat enjoyable is the sound design. Hitting machines sounds great, and the machines themselves also mix sound effects from the animals they’re inspired by. I didn’t find the soundtrack to be memorable, but it’s immersive. The graphics are also great, with a lot of particle effects. The world is also diverse, with forests, jungles, deserts, mountains, and snow.
And everything I mentioned comes together to make a great game. It feels polished, although I found some visual bugs here and there and crashed a few times. There are some things I didn’t enjoy though. The big one for me is that your inventory is limited. You can upgrade your storage space, but I reached a point where I was doing inventory management more often than I would like and trying to figure out what I could discard/sell. Other RPGs often limit what you can carry with you but have a banking system where you can deposit and save everything. But not here, everything you own is always with you.
Another thing I didn’t enjoy was the save system. At first, I thought that the game saved often, and it does if you’re advancing quests. It also saves every time you grab a collectible. However, outside of quests, the only way you can save is manually at campfires or by fast traveling. The game doesn’t save when you quit the game, so I lost progress after fighting machines because I assumed the game autosaved often, and it does but not in that case. That also meant I lost progress when I crashed, sometimes 15-20 minutes because I was fighting and exploring far from a campfire. It feels inconsistent.
That aside, it’s a high-quality Sony-published game and an easy recommendation. It also includes all DLC and has no microtransaction crap. And like most titles published by Sony, it includes a complete dub in European Portuguese, which is rare outside of this publisher. Won’t affect most of you, but it’s another touch I appreciate.

All corrupted zones cleared, all cauldrons cores overridden. I've still got the Frozen Wilds DLC area to explore and have some side quests left. 

The skill tree has useful items, especially when you're still weak. But even at higher level you will still find useful skills to unlock. Make choices according to your way of playing but definitely take Silent Strike and Concentration in the early game.
There's a wealth of weapons to choose from. Check regulary if you can improve them with better mods.
In upgrading weapons and outfits I skipped most of the blue items and went straight from green to purple (shadow) items.
The map can be overwhelming sometimes but it's possible to filter what items are shown.
Increase your item storage as quickly as possible because while wandering around you’ll find a lot of usefull stuff and it would be a shame to leave things behind.
Override cauldron cores to be able to override increasingly powerful machines and let them do the fighting for you.

If I have to add a negative point, it would be Aloy’s movement, which can be awkward in close contact battles and when you're close to the scenery such as rocks.

The combat in this game is so bad that I actually just quit playing and looked up a story recap on youtube. Seriously, save yourself however many hours and just watch a 30 minute recap.

 - literally no camera controls, not to mention the camera just repositions itself randomly. the camera also ignores foliage so good luck fighting anything if there are trees anywhere nearby
 - speaking of foliage - one specific type of grass hides you like you just put on the One Ring, but all of the other much larger, much more dense bushes and grasses are just completely see through to the enemies
 - monsters have about a 10 foot leash radius. want to lay a trap and lure a machine into it? too bad, they literally will not move more than 10 feet away from their predetermined area, even if they see you and are aggro. you can literally just stand there and the monsters will run back and forth while you plink them with arrows (learning this was what made me quit the game)
 - no separate keybinds for crouch, slide, bow, walk/run
 - the movement is extremely janky. sometimes your character just wont sprint no matter what. you get caught on little tiny rocks and other geometry, you get forced into a vaulting animation if you try to walk up a hill thats more than like a 25 degree incline - there are roads on these hills too
 - if you capture a mount and then fast travel, the mount disappears - yeah it makes sense logically but its really stupid for gameplay
 - the difficulty settings aren't actually balanced around anything at all. there are certain missions and trials that have time limits, and you aren't actually capable of completing the objective because environmental objects have hit points. for example, the trial to shoot log traps onto machines: on ultra hard, the traps take THREE ARROWS to trigger, because you only hit for ~20 dmg instead of ~120
 - overall the game is literally just badly coded

Horizon Zero Dawn is a visually breathtaking and immersive open-world game with a captivating storyline and a strong, independent protagonist. The robotic creatures and lush landscapes create a mesmerizing environment to explore. However, the open-world formula, while beautiful, may feel familiar to some players. Combat is a highlight with a mix of strategy and skill required to take down robotic foes. While the narrative is intriguing, some pacing issues may hinder the overall experience. Horizon Zero Dawn is undeniably a standout title, though it may not break entirely new ground in terms of open-world gameplay conventions.

[h1]Update:[/h1]

I'm replaying this game again nearly two years later with an open mind, and... the game is so much worse than I ever remembered.

The story is boring and forgettable and the characters are devoid of personality. There isn't a single thing drawing me into this game beyond its superficial charm and captivating setting. I find myself only able to somewhat enjoy this game by pretending this is the first game I've ever played in my life, and aimlessly traversing the wilderness and collecting resources, solely to admire its graphics.

If the story and characters failed to draw me in, the combat further sours the experience. Combat in this game is very lackluster and extremely unsatisfying. Enemies just SOAK up any damage you throw at them, and this is AFTER significant leveling and gear improvements, stripping enemies armor, aiming for critical spots, and hitting them with the elemental ammo type they are weak to.

Mission design exacerbates the tedium, often devolving into mindless fetch quests that require traversing across the map multiple times. The lack of enemy variety makes this even more apparent, paired with the unsatisfying combat and lackluster stealth.

Speaking of stealth, it's disappointingly surface-level. Stealth feels more like an afterthought, and its implementation falls extremely short, even compared to something like Insomniac's series of Spider-Man games, which while lackluster, I felt could at least be enjoyable. It's such a shame, because I would have loved to use more stealth as an alternative to the terrible combat in Horizon.

The dialogue is impressively bad and often makes me want to fall asleep. The stiff and awkward delivery of voice lines, paired with the very rigid facial animations makes even the main characters more forgettable and lifeless than they already are. I also can't forget how compressed the dialogue is for some reason, making it sound similar to the sound quality from a Nintendo DS game.

Horizon Zero Dawn's praise and acclaim seems very misplaced, considering its myriad of flaws. It's visuals and initial charm may catch your eye, however, the game fails to deliver any sort of compelling experience, and just served to frustrate and embarrass the player. If you disagree with me, please, share your thoughts and leave a comment, I would love to hear differing opinions.

[h1] Better than I thought it would be [/h1] 

HZD is a scifi game done right in my opinion and is at the very least well written in most parts. With believable and human characters and what turns out to be a quite interesting story. 

It does waver a bit in terms of writing, starting out strong, getting a bit wishy washy and ending fairly well but not as strong as the beginning. But I enjoyed it. 

Usual issues of open world story lead games is the pacing of the narrative is thrown well off when you go side-questing for days. But thanks to NG+ you dont have to worry too much about that as you can come back to it. 

The enemies are interesting even if the melee combat does kinda suck; Aloy cannot block, at all. And every enemy attack will interrupt your animations. The heavy attack which is the only attack worth a damn has a ridiculous wind-up and as such you'll get that animation broken by incoming attacks a LOT until you get used to it. BUT...

The game kinda makes up for it with the ranged and trap combat which is honestly OP AF once you get some points invested and upgrades plugged in. You have so many options to even avoid engaging in direct combat entirely and have the machines themselves fight each other for you. 

However the inventory system particularly for potions (health and buffs) and traps is all done on the D pad on controller, and you scroll through EVERYTHING every time you want something. Making it clumsy in combat. 

On that controller note, don't even bother playing with KB&M it sucks. The game was not at all designed with it in mind and it just does not work well. I tried for probably about and hour or more but eventually gave up and plugged in my controller and then all was well. 

Pricing of the game however is kinda extortionate tbh, I picked it up in a sale and would recommend the same, then its very good value for money.

Looking forward to Forbidden West coming to PC.

When Genshin Impact collaborated with Sony to bring Aloy in as a playable character, I knew nothing of her games. But when she was given as a free 5* character 2 years ago, I played her, and became very interested in her games... especially due to her backstory as portrayed, accurately and without spoilers, in Genshin.
Finally, in November 2022, I got the funds to buy Horizon: Zero Dawn Complete on Steam. And I was not ready for the amazing experience I was in for. 

I wanted to do a Pro/Con Review, but honestly, I'd rather speak from the heart.

As someone who has beaten Breath of the Wild; the quest system and how side quests affect the main quest and even the DLC is exactly how Nintendo should have done Breath of the Wild, and from what I've heard, Tears of the Kingdom.

Horizon: Zero Dawn is the best open-world game I've ever played. About 90% of what you do as Aloy will affect the main story quest and the finale of the game. Who did you spare? Who did you befriend? What (as I will call them to avoid spoilers) side-dungeons did you do? Depending on the answers to these questions, Aloy to mention everything you--the player as Aloy--has done in the Main Story Quest or even in OTHER quests. Skipped a side-dungeon which allows you to control more machines? Aloy will act in the Main Story as if she never did it. Because she didn't. But, what if you did? Aloy will mention it. And yes, [i]ALL THESE LINES ARE VOICED![/i]

And it's not just "mentions", she talks about them as if they were critical to the story. The Frozen Wilds DLC will have a lot of different Dialogue choices depending on far you are in the main story, what dungeons you've done, etc. These types of changing dialogue and changes the things you do have on the main story can create for countless replays.

Speaking of Replays, do you know about the New Game+ feature? Once you beat the game, you can make a NG+ based off any save you have. You're locked into the difficulty you select, you get upgraded versions of armor (which in Ultra-Hard Mode cost more) from merchants. And it starts you at the beginning of "Point of the Spear" as Adult Aloy instead of Child Aloy's "Gift from the past." So, you skip the entire intro. But that's not all, you can use NG+ on saves of new games in which Aloy has a low level, or you speedran the quest to get one of the best armors in the game without leveling much, etc. [b]The options are limitless![/b]

The voice-acting is superb, and the story is incredible. You might have ideas and theories when you start the game, and some of them may be right, but the story will take you for an unforgettable ride which will be a gaming treasure. The story will sometimes make you really wonder "what happened?" and some quests will leave you with more answers than questions. For me, beating Frozen Wilds and then the final main quest was an experience that will stay with me forever--in a very positive way.

Aloy has a max, in this version of 50 levels. She starts out (after the introduction as a child) at level 3. Every level you get a skill point and increase of health by 10. However, you also get skill points from main story quests, side quests, if I remember correctly, dungeons.

As for gameplay, I used the controller and hardly had any problems. Though, you either have to adapt to the default controls on the controller or remap your own. The game can be played with Keyboard and Mouse and I've heard that's better for aiming. Personally, by the time I had found that out, I was probably a 1/4th of the way through the game using the controller. Regardless, the gameplay is a little clunky, but once you get used to it, the cool thing about the controls, is a lot of the things you see Aloy do in trailers [b]are completely possible to do in-game[/b], it just requires a lot of practice and patience.

Bugs, as for bugs, I'm glad I had to wait (due to finances) to get the Complete Edition here on Steam as by the time I did, 90% (maybe 95%) of the port's bugs had been fixed. So, I was in for a smooth experience.

I'm actually redoing my playthrough now because a) my final save with 100% got deleted somehow and b) I have a much more powerful computer.

I beat the game on February 22nd, 2023 - with an in-game time of 142 hours, 10 minutes, and ~30 seconds.  Aloy's adventure has me excited for the upcoming Forbidden West sequel on Steam, though, I may wait some time before actually buying it. ;)

Soooooo, the vibes this game gave were pretty mixed. It felt like a low-quality Assassin's Creed (but even better than the last ones kekw). They implemented all the systems a modern AC game has but simplified them, and I don't see it as a bad point but the game itself lacks something that makes it unique. And after 52 hours and completing 100% of the game, I still feel that way.

BUT, on the other hand, I can point out three aspects that are pretty good about this game and make it worth your time:

[b]First:[/b] The main story has wonderful storytelling, a good plot, and a nice open ending for a sequel (coming to PC in March of this year).
[b]Second:[/b] A beautiful and immersive open world with different biomes. I really enjoyed traveling in this game on my own and almost didn't use fast travel.
[b]Third:[/b] The combat system. It's cool, dynamic, complex, and unless you grind like a psycho, you can enjoy it 100% without feeling it's boring or overwhelming. Each enemy has its own way to be brought down and the attack patterns change according to the parts you destroyed, making fights with the same monster different from one to another.

Overall, the game is good enough to give you a few hours of entertainment. The only thing that can be annoying is Aloy making random comments all the time. The first few hours are cool, but the longer you play, the more annoying she becomes (you still love her, she is kinda cute).

Horizon Zero Dawn Complete Edition is an absolute marvel of gaming excellence. From its breathtaking landscapes to its immersive storyline, this game delivers an unparalleled experience that will leave you captivated from start to finish.

The Complete Edition offers an abundance of content, including the base game and its exceptional expansion, The Frozen Wilds. Exploring the vast open world as Aloy, a skilled hunter in a post-apocalyptic world overrun by robotic creatures, is nothing short of awe-inspiring.

The gameplay mechanics are flawlessly executed, blending action-packed combat with strategic elements as you utilize Aloy's arsenal of weapons and tools to overcome challenges. The depth of character development and the richness of the narrative keep you invested in Aloy's journey, as she uncovers the mysteries of her past and the secrets of the world around her.

Visually stunning and accompanied by a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, Horizon Zero Dawn is a testament to the creativity and craftsmanship of its developers. Whether you're scaling towering cliffs or engaging in intense battles against mechanical behemoths, every moment is a testament to the game's attention to detail and dedication to delivering an unforgettable experience.

In conclusion, Horizon Zero Dawn Complete Edition is an absolute must-play for any gaming enthusiast. Its blend of breathtaking visuals, compelling storytelling, and engaging gameplay make it a true masterpiece that stands among the greatest games of its generation.

I've barely started the game, and already two major issues.  Why is there an unskippable cinematic when opening the game that takes several minutes to complete?  Why can I not adjust game settings at all during it?  And most importantly, WHY IS THE FUCKING VOLUME 100% DURING IT?!

Quit the game and start it again?  Guess what, you get to enjoy that opening cinematic again and again every time you launch it.  Have fun!

Oh, and if that's not enough, your privacy options are to provide them with either all of the data they want to collect, or most of the data they want to collect.  There's no way to opt out entirely; only blocking the game with external tools (e.g. a firewall) will completely prevent it from contacting them.  Enjoy!

The game is similar to many Far Cry/Ubi open-roam games, with a mandatory linear beginning chapter (where the clumsy narrative "everybody's a jerk to you, outcast" tone gets old very quickly, along with the "your mentor is an unhelpful surly sensei" trope as well) that later opens up to a large map and non-linear play.

A skill tree allows for significant customization, and enemy kills provide raw materials for crafting upgrades - a mechanic that's also very common to FC/Ubi games. Aloy's character design is a refreshing example of a strong female lead in a post-Collapse hunter society.

The game is actually easier than many open-roam games, when it comes to infiltrating human-run bases. The camera is permanently in third-person view (since melee combat constitutes a huge part of the game, and third-person view gives much better situational awareness) and the game is generous when it comes to takedowns and silent kills. I found Aloy's overrun of a populated human base to be much easier and rewarding than in many equivalent Far Cry games - especially Far Cry Primal, which is also a bow-and-spear epic.

The game's main enemies are machines, rendered in animalistic builds a la Matrix design, and they are much tougher than the human foes you occasionally encounter. Once you get into the main portion of the game, beyond the first two machine types, the predator style machines become more and more challenging. Often, if the machine is able to close with Aloy in melee combat, you're looking at a game over and a checkpoint restart, since her spear just won't provide any meaningful combat parity.

This becomes more problematic in the game's dungeon sequences (called Cauldrons). It's unclear whether these dungeons are optional, but they're definitely signposted as places of importance, and they supposedly unlock the ability to tame a broader array of monsters. The first and only Cauldron I attempted was near the beginning, Cauldron Sigma, and it slowed my PC to a crawl. The gorgeous lush overworld of HZD didn't cause any problems - it's the vaultlike underground platforms and conveyors that my graphics card didn't like.

Play slowed down significantly, and with a much more linear level design, combat became much more obligatory. I found one area where I was constantly forced to die and retry, until I was able to lure the enemies onto a ledge and nickle and dime them to death with arrows from afar.

And after this achievement, I then fell prey to another typical porting problem from console to PC: janky save points. I made a wrong turn at the T junction and went right instead of left, where the game offered me the view of a sheer cliff. In trying to turn around, the third-person camera view of Aloy made her walk a few steps in the wrong direction, and she was instakilled because the game thought it was reasonable to walk her off a cliff.

The quicksave point was before the most recent frustrating dog-slow combat, meaning I'd have to go through it all over again. At this point I lost interest.

Will Aloy ever figure out why she was outcast as a baby, why her foster father refused to tell her anything about her past, and why the planet is in such a post-Collapse shambles? In a word: no.

There are other open roam games out there, and a few are the equal to HZD in worldbuilding and presentation (Far Cry 3, 4, 5, and New Dawn were especially well done). None, in my opinion, are as good as HZD's stealth mechanics game design - as she can hide in longgrass and even maintain Sneak Attack bonus out in the open, as long as she is unseen.

HZD's weakest link in its triple-A production values, however, is its scripting and narrative. While the game mechanics feel very well balanced and the leveling feels fair and non-oppressive, the origin story and background for Aloy just feel very limiting. The early outcast "everybody hates you" narrative wears out its welcome very quickly, and there's a YA Hunger-Games-style contrived competition that she just coincidentally can take part in (despite people not being allowed to talk to her as a religious taboo) to win back her citizenship in the tribe. The social elements of the worldbuilding feel flat and superficial, like they're just there to get you to the next chapter before all is forgotten and it no longer matters.

To her credit, Aloy remains a sort of "post-Collapse stone age" character throughout the time I played this game. While it's true that Aloy's not the first strong female lead of a video game ever, it is also fair to say that unlike Samus Aran of Metroid, she hasn't yet had a career period where she's slinking around in a curvy leotard wearing high heels either.

Horizon Zero Dawn is a mediocre open-world game. If I could summarize it in a quick sentence, I’d say it’s like a Far Cry game with a far more interesting world but much worse combat. From here, I will dive deeper into why I feel this way.

The best things Horizon has going for it are the aesthetic and narrative. Aloy is a compelling character, and her journey of self-discovery is quite intriguing. I loved learning more about the world as I progressed through the game, and I enjoyed hunting down collectibles that provided more information. I found these elements compelling enough to finish the game (although I never completed the DLC), although not everyone will.

While I did enjoy the overall narrative, the game starts slowly. The first few hours are essentially all tutorials where you play through some of Aloy’s childhood and a bit of her adult life before the game opens up. I’d like to say more positive things about the game, as I did finish it, but I have trouble coming up with many. 

One of my main issues with Horizon is the combat. Combat is underwhelming in many different ways. Melee combat is undoubtedly the worst part. You can do a heavy or light attack; that’s it. These attacks don’t lock onto enemies, so you’re essentially swinging and hoping you don’t get hit and have your animation canceled before your attack lands. While putting less focus on melee combat helps play into the fantasy and lack of power that comes with fighting massive machines, you often fight human enemies and have to deal with the same issues. Countless machine types also explode or have elemental effects when you defeat them; this dynamic makes melee combat even worse, as even if you win an encounter with it, you’re losing a considerable amount of HP or maybe even dying after a successful kill. Doing something akin to the Mad Max game, where you rip off the Batman Arkham combat and include some counterattack, would’ve made this much better. The ranged combat is stronger; you can scan enemies and see their weak points and elemental weaknesses. From there, you can use various arrow types, traps, and different weapons to inflict status effects, remove machine parts, or brute force arrow damage until enemies are destroyed. While this loop is fine, it’s not a strong point of the game, and the developers don’t seem to realize that, as the game's final section is a grueling combat encounter where you take on many challenging machines at once. To make matters worse, enemies tank many hits, so you’ll frequently need to craft new ammunition during combat encounters, interrupting the flow. The only defensive maneuver you possess is a dodge roll with some immunity frames. The dodge is nice, but enemy attacks often have such large hit areas that you’ll take damage regardless; on the flip side, on countless occasions, I watched my arrows fly through enemy heads or hit machines square on with no hit registration. In combat vs. enemy humans and neutral machines, I often found that the neutral machines would ignore all other humans and target me, which was annoying and broke my immersion. 

The weapon system also wasn’t my favorite. You can buy different weapons from merchants scattered across the map, although they mostly sell the same weapons, and the best weapons become available once you reach the main city. Weapons can’t be upgraded in the traditional sense; instead, they have a few modification slots where you can add modifications that you buy loot during your travels or buy from merchants. These modifications do things like an 11% damage increase, and each weapon typically has 0-3 slots. Armor is essentially the same system but with defensive buffs like ranged damage taken reduced by 12%. 

Returning now to the story. Yes, I found the overall narrative compelling, but interactions with NPCs are not interesting. The voice acting is solid in the main story, but side mission characters aren’t compelling. Sometimes, side characters are well-acted, but their writing is so awful. It’s commonplace for NPCs to repeat themselves and talk robotically like chatGPT wrote their dialogue, stating something like “Aloy, my brother is missing. I haven’t seen him in days, and I need to find him,” then literally saying, “Aloy, my brother is missing, I haven’t seen him in days, can you help me find him?”. It’s repetitive and boring, and I found myself ignoring all side quests once I had enough EXP to progress without doing them. 

On the bright side, I did find the open world compelling. There are bandit outposts, machine dens, hunting trials, corrupted machine zones, tallnecks (essentially synchronization points), and four different types of collectibles scattered across the world. While I enjoyed some more than others, I had a good time clearing the map, and some of these optional objectives unlock useful upgrades. Although traversal, specifically climbing, is the boring industry standard stuff you have seen in countless games. Swimming is particularly terrible, as you get locked into animations when you enter water, but typically you're only crossing small streams or rivers and end up swimming into invisible walls for a few seconds while you try to leave the water.

The world of Horizon is interesting, and Aloy is a compelling character, but the combat and side quests are widely uninteresting and flawed. While I finished the game, I can’t recommend Horizon Zero Dawn. That’s not to say that Horizon Zero Dawn is a bad game; I don’t think it is. Ultimately, the issue is that Horizon Zero Dawn fails to establish a combat/weapon system, gameplay loops, and side objectives worth experiencing in the vast landscape of open-world adventure games. 

I’ve heard the sequel is much better and improves on many of my complaints, so I’m excited to try that if the PC port isn’t terrible.

My mistake was I got this just before Christmas, thus this game ruined my wife's Christmas time..... and my kids......and my in-laws.....and my parents. 130 hours in 2 weeks...... with a 50 hour a week job. Factor in sleep and "family time" and apparently, children need to eat more than once a day, the math clearly states, all my free time was spent on this game.

The story is phenomenal. Compelling and original, I truly felt compelled to do everything to help everyone to max out my gear. It was a blast. The engagement options are endless, full stealth, full aggression, diversionary, traps, status effects, and even making the machines fight for you.  You'll fall in love with Aloy with her snarky "don't mess with me attitude", that's well justified, and her intelligence and compassion as you go through this story with her. HZD has a fan for life now with me. 

TLDR; if you classify yourself as a "gamer" you have heard of this game, you probably own this game, and if you do not, you need to.

You'll just love this game. From it's superb visuals to unrivaled gameplay, this game has captured me in it's open world!

It's an action based RPG whose story and characters makes you really grounded and connects you with this world they are living in! The way characters move and talk bring them to life, though their unblinking eyes can be a little unnerving at first. The lead, Aloy, is a believable protagonist against waves of beautifully rendered machines! The best part is you get to pull the machines apart piece by piece using a variety of weapons! This feature of the game is so rewarding as you slowly reveal weak points to different machines, or figure out which arrows function best for taking out a specific unit!

The character seems dynamic and it doesn't feel like they react sluggishly to your controls. In fact the reaction timing of moves from attacking with spear or arrows is super intuitive, and has to be, as the harder difficulty levels are unforgiving. If a challenge is not what you want then try the Story mode that is good for new gamers and those who just want to enjoy the environments without too much looking over your shoulder for machines. Speaking of environments, they are richly crafted and the character even reacts and talks about the environment they are in, giving that extra bit of realism.

The acting is top notch and you really feel the emotions all the characters are experiencing. It even features the talents of Lance Reddick(RIP). from the series Fringe!

The open world is rich with memorable locations and plenty of different collectibles that you can trade for unique items or that help flesh out the story and timeline of events. These little tidbits help tie the main story together, but if you don't want to read 100s of entrys you can grasp the main story without them. The tale is excellently crafted with enough of a twist that you should be wary of spoilers, but not so much as to ruin the experience of the game altogether. 

After finishing the game I started another playthrough on it's game+ feature! This, like other games which have game plus allow you to start a new game from scratch, but with all your equipment you worked hard to acquire. I'm addicted and can't wait for the next game, Horizon Forbidden West, to come out on PC!

The concept behind the game is very innovative and the world is very well built. Some sort of disaster has happened and the humans are organized in tribes and rely mainly on scavenging technological part from constructs of the past. In addition, mechanical beasts roam the countriside, which always pose a challenge to fight. You can easily immerse yourself and discover this amazing world.

The quests feel always new and I didn't have the feeling of being repetitive as in other video games. However, I think that the role-playing part is a bit weak, in the sense that there isn't significant interaction with other characters that could shape the development of the game. At least I didn't perceive it like this. The development of the equipment is also quite slow meaning potential upgrades come late in the game. Vendors providing equipment seem insignificant after a certain point and the same seems feeling comes also from the quest rewards. In addition, the inventory management seems to suffer from "child sicknesses" of ealier RPGs, where the inventory is quickly bloated and getting full without knowing what could be useful and should be kept.

To the positive side, the storytelling is captivating and you are always eager to discover more. Being an action RPG, the action elements are quite strong with every battle posing a new challenge. There is a wide array of weapons that if used successfuly can turn a lost battle to a triumph. The learning curve is facilitated by the fact of quest-tutorials in the use of new weapons, while hunting lodges provide trials to improve personal combat tactics. Once again, the atmosphere is amazing and you can really get chills when something big and mechanical is scanning for you, while you're hiding in the bushes... Totally recommended!

At present, I think that Horizon: Zero Dawn is criminally underrated, and I can't recommend it enough. 

To start with, a future of hunter-gatherers in a world filled with robot monsters is a fun idea, which the art department handled beautifully. Zero Dawn has an absolutely stunning world to explore, spanning a variety of different biomes, with a large number of colossal enemies suiting each area. The character models feel a little bit dated (especially child Aloy), but by and large the game still looks great.

The gameplay is very typically Playstation, with a climbing mechanic revolving around highlighted climb points, the ability to scan environments. The combat uses a combination of light/heavy attacks and dodges, as well as incredibly satisfying bow mechanics. 

As for bugs, at the time of playing the game only crashed once, with no other bugs to speak of.

I played through the entire main game, all side missions, the entire DLC storyline, along with all the DLC missions, on the hardest difficulty. This game is not worth it. The main game is awful. The DLC “The Frozen Wilds” is absolutely fantastic. It is everything this game should have been. Does a 5 hour DLC make up for a 30 hour, regular paced main game? No. Especially if it is not on sale. This game is not worth anything more than 20$ due to its disappointing features: an insulting amount of visual and audio glitches, boring collectables that don't do anything, boring side missions. They tried so hard to connect nature and robot dinosaurs and it ended up with a story line that doesn't make sense. I could honestly deal with all of that, all of it, if everyone's face in the game weren't so dang stupid. Sooo stupid. They're just...blank...emotionless. The game makers tried to do some sort of facial tracking that they implemented into the game or something. it didn't work. Everyone looks like they have fetal alcohol syndrome.

[h1] Why you should or should not play Horizon Zero Dawn [/h1]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2770308267

[i] Original Review [/i]

Gorgeous game, beautiful story line and plenty of content! This has turned into one of my favourite game so quickly that im already wanting more... and im not even done the game yet.

[b] What is Horizon Zero Dawn? [/b]

This game is a beautiful single player open world story game. The main character is absolutely amazing to play and you can travel the world to figure out her origins, make friends (and enemy's) as well as upgrade various tools, ability's and skills to defeat things in the game. There are not to many real animals, and seem to be a lot of robots which are a mystery of how they came to the world, but some of the people are definitely evil too.

[b] Initial Thoughts: [/b]

-"I am absolutely addicted to this damn game... I can't put it down."
-"I wonder when the second one is going to come out. I hope soon, I am going to need some time off work to play it."
-"This story is so rich already and I have just started the game... amazing."

[b] Beginner Player Friendly?  [/b]

I would say this game should be pretty beginner player friendly, though I am not sure of how well the controls would be to figure out for someone. But, they are pretty straight forward for mouse and keyboard, and without any people being rude to you due to it being a single player game, it should be a nice game to play for someone starting out.

[b] Game Play: [/b]

The game play is absolutely rich and beautiful, I couldn't even believe how addicted I was for multiple days and hours throughout the week (obviously work got into the way of me completing it all in one day.) I never had the time to finish the DLC and I am still upset about it. It is kind of like black dessert, and many other games,  in the sense that it will show you exactly where to go when you are lost. There is the main story line as well as multiple side quests you can do. Though the main story is very amazing, I am so sad that the next game is a PS5 exclusive at the moment. 

[b] Graphics: [/b]

I am not sure how the did the graphics exactly, but they are breath taking in the sense that they are very realistic while still maintaining a certain style to the game. The character is beautifully designed and fits their role perfectly for the person they are trying to portray. Though, if I remember correctly this is a style of game that used an actual person to act as the people in the game. It worked out well. 

[b] Community: [/b]

I do not know to much about the community but with how nice they seem on steam, I don't think they are all that bad. 

[b] How long can you play? [/b]

This game kept me busy for hours, and considering I have quite a bit of game play left and also a whole DLC I could play, I would say it takes a decent amount of time to play. So if you are ready for a longer session this game may be for you.

[b] My Opinion: [/b]

In my opinion, I think this game is worth it, and if you enjoy extra content you should definitely get the DLC that goes with it as it adds more content to the game. The story is beautiful and mysterious. It will keep you on the edge of your seat the whole time you play and it is so worth it by the end of the game. There is a second game out as I said earlier, although, its a PS5 exclusive, which means it is not yet ready for PC, or may never come to PC, so if you have a PS5 and prefer controller you could always get Zero Dawn on your Playstation as well, as it is a SONY game and would be available there. Then you could play the second one right after you play the first.

[h1][b]Horizon Zero Dawn[/b][/h1]

[b]Overall Score:[/b]
(3.5/5)
The game is the near-peak of what I imagine western open-world action adventure games can be. Unfortunately, that means that the game is marked with a redundancy that comes from the need to fill a map with tons of points of interests (POIs), and the combat is only [i]just[/i] entertaining enough keep you from getting too bored too quickly. That being said, what the game gets right is a gorgeous world that also feels well sized and populated; the distance between different POIs is never too long, so at least the act of traversal doesn't feel like a chore even if "cleaning up" the map and of its POIs does.

The crown jewel of the game is its overarching premise, which feeds you enough mystery to keep you hooked for what the next story reveal could be. The troubles of the main and supporting cast didn't interest me all too much, but I found myself invested in learning everything I could about the events and actions that led up to the game. If you only focus on the main quests, the story will reward you without dragging on too long.

I went into this game having already watched all of the cut scenes.

[h2] Story [/h2]

I will not be talking about what the story is about but rather what I think about how it was written and then how it was presented. This games story is interesting, well written and hooks you in early. However, I do not believe it retains a consistent level of interest that warrants a play through for the story alone. What I mean by that is the main story beats are too far apart but once you have completed it and know everything its great. Another issue I have is in the way the story was presented. There are few cut scenes in the game and most of them aren't that impactful despite their very clear ability to do so shown in the final cutscene. To elaborate on this a little further, some scenes that are meant to be sad are only just visibly meant to be sad as in, you know they are meant to be sad but you don't care that much. Another unfortunate thing is that the side quests minus a few are pretty boring and are all just go to x location track footsteps... find person dead or alive and kill machines in the area. All of that said the story/setting as a whole minus the way it was spread throughout the game is very interesting.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

The combat in this game is simply the best thing about it. It is in no way difficult even on the hardest difficulty unless you start the game on it which I assume is basically unintended which is probably why it was removed from non new game+ in the 2nd game. That disappointed me a little but I guess not every game needs to be challenging. The visual and auditory feedback when hitting shots feels great and is definitely a big reason as to why the combat feels so good. Constantly knocking parts off of the machines your fighting is my favorite part. Some of the fights in the game feel cinematic the way the enemies are animated and the way everything comes together. The games mechanics are all very simple and you wont feel overwhelmed when you first look at your inventory and skill tree like most games. I do think the game could have had better tutorials for some mechanics however. The combat also isnt flawless obviously. Most times it is a dodge sim but imo it is still insanely fun.

[h2] Graphics/Other [/h2]

Some people may disagree with me on this but while the game is beautiful so are plenty of other games from the same year or before. So what I mean is yes its stunning but doesn't rise above the rest. I wanna talk about the facial animations and the non combat related ones as well. The facial animations especially in the non DLC areas are not good unfortunately. I think it is one of the games weakest points and the non combat related ones aren't too amazing either most people look really stiff with the occasional hand motion thrown in. The performance for the game is good most of the time however there are select areas where no matter the specs you may have low fps but luckily they are not points of interest. This game also happens to have amazing music and sound design overall. There are very few games where I can remember specific sound effects from the game but this is one of them. 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

Overall HZD is definitely worth it when its on sale just so you can experience FW. Forbidden West fixes every one of my issues and improves upon everything except the story is a little wild. I would say the combat alone in HZD is worth experiencing rather than skipping it and going straight to FW.

I've got every single achievment in this beauty of a game, so I'd like to think my opinion is worth a pretty penny. And my opinion is that this is one of the best games of its generation, and one of my personal favorites of all time. Aloy is such a charming character and I loved hearing her reactions to what's happening in the story, but also her cheeky comments on the world around her. "Don't look down... don't look down... dammit". The characters in this game are all so wonderful and compelling, and it was so much fun to ask them questions and learn more about them. Finding all the little lore bits (there's a lot!) was tedious at times, but worth it for how much extra content is in the game. If you spend time listening to the audio files and reading item descriptions, you'll gain a whole new insight into how deep the story goes. I truly cried at several points in the story because I was so moved. While RPG isn't a huge component of this game, the few choices you do get are so fun to test every option. I love being able to choose emotional reactions and responses that actually receive different replies. There's also some dialogue that you only get when you react certain ways, and it's not always an immediate response.
The combat variety in this game is debatable, but fun enough where I truly didn't mind that it mostly consisted of "load, slow time, aim at weak spot, fire, repeat" for every machine. On the plus side, I enjoyed the variety in how the machine enemies would come at you. Their patterns and styles are different, so It's fun learning to time dodges and when to unleash a flurry of attacks. My biggest complaint is that the controls are incredible janky at times. Aiming is so frustrating, especially on agile and flying enemies. What's worse, however, is the platforming. I swear 80% of my deaths were Aloy just running off/leaping off ledges instead of grabbing onto a ledge or rope. For most of the game world there's some forgiveness to the controls, but running courses or climbing up cliff faces while in a time crunch made me rage quit a few times.
The graphic are absolutely stunning. The snow and water affects are gorgeous. The character models are detailed... if sometimes a bit disturbing when their lipsyncing isn't perfect. Generally, however, the game is just incredibly pretty to immerse yourself in. And the lighting! Oh the lighting is just so amazing on the snowy mountains. I also love how the art style blends natural and manmade/metal elements in a pleasing and seamless way.
Despite its few issues, the good qualities of this game more than make up for it! I always looked forward to learning more of the story and world lore while also happily spending time just appreciating the landscape. I seriously recommend this game to anyone who wants a game with a great mix of combat, story, and atmosphere.

Horizon Zero Dawn is a masterpiece. Not only is the gameplay amazing, well balanced and challenging, but it is joined by an epic story and an amazing soundtrack. The game has an initial difficulty issue if you play on anything other than easy, but the game quickly becomes easier the more levels you gain throughout the story. If you struggle, just keep on playing. I promise it gets easier.
The Story is a classic 'you are the chosen one', but this game spices it up a bit by concealing why you are the chosen one until pretty much the last 20% of the story, which is great as it allows for a great reveal at the end. You play as the Nora Huntress Aloy, who you watch grow as a character as she unravels the mysteries of the past and finds a way to save the future. The Story can be a bit confusing at first, but makes sense at the end once all is revealed. Multiple playthroughs (using the amazing New Story+ feature) is highly recommended, as this allows you to experience the story with all your earnt skills from a previous playthough.
The Gameplay is remarkably well designed, and still very simple. Combat can be broken down into Melee, Ranged and Traps. Traps are fun to use and do deal high damage when used correctly, but ultimately the worst of the three. Melee and Ranged are much better as the modifications for them are far more useful, and they can be used in almost all situations. Killing Machines by targeting their hard spots is recommended as not only does it detach some parts you can pick up without even killing it, it also deals critical damage, making the kill easier. A much needed skill is the 'Focus' skill which lets you slow down time while aiming and makes hardpoint targeting much easier.
The Soundtrack is amazing, having a fitting track for every revelation in the game. Combat music is also great, with passive/exploring music being enjoyable as well.
Overall, Horizon Zero Dawn is a lot of fun, and should be a must play for everyone. However, the initial difficulty for a new player can be hard, with combat only starting to become relatively easy around level 25. Various gameplay elements are also not shown very well and can be completely missed in a first time playthrough, making the game even more difficult. Even with these flaws though, once they are overcome the game is a lot of fun and well worth the mystery of the story!
Horizon Zero Dawn gets an 8/10.

I really liked this game, although when I've fully finished everything, I had an overdose. You have to spend too much time in the game, to fully finish with immersion. Of course you can just run through, but it's not me. 

This world is vast... you can see beautiful landscapes, multiple environments, travel as you like. Just amazing.
The theme is creative with this kind of apocalypse, interesting combination of nature, machines and humans.

There is some problem with the balance in this world. I think the density of the machines is too high. How can people even live there near these huge machines? They can't even walk 500 m without bumping into a hostile machine. I think the humans are overpowered over machines and our Aloy is way overpowered over anything. Yeah, I can get over it, but sometimes it's strange.

Fighting system is well developed, although I've found myself spend the 2/3rd of the fighting time in the menu, which is awkward. Maybe the opponents should be weaker, and in the meantime we should be forbidden to access the ingame menu. Dressing over mid-fight is strange...

The music/soundtrack is terrible. You have a good main menu music, and that's all. Actually it does not have a soundtrack, not even at the cutscenes which is unacceptable. Take a look at God of War: When something is happening, the music is following the events, and enhances the story, and when is not needed, silence takes over. Or Ori where the orchestra did a great work, and really takes part in storytelling. In the Doom series during ingame-menu, they just lower the volume of the blood pumping metal, not breaking the rhythm of your game. 

With some caveats, but overall it was a great journey, enjoy!

I game I became immediately invested in and it kept my attention pretty much until the end. Played on normal difficulty without too many issues until the last boss and decided to just play the DLC on story mode difficulty because I just wanted to know the whole story. A few things:

- The story is interesting. Maybe not completely original but definitely has a few unique elements and I think the first game has that "if it goes well there's plenty of world building left by going other places" feel, but can also be interpreted as, if it was the only game, a story that is sufficient enough to give you what you're asking for. That said I think Guerrilla had plans for sequels to this game.
- Very cool gameplay mechanics, especially fighting machines is fun because there's several ways to go about it. Obviously it borrows elements from other games with it's talent tree but it also leaves open what weapons you should use. There's really no one correct way to do it but the game has an encyclopedia on machines with parts and what the weaknesses are and you can go from there to make things easier. 
- For a 2017 title the game is gorgeous. I've always been a huge fan of dystopian worlds and the 'nature has taken back the world' sort of setting and this game gives you that in droves. Beautiful game.
- The characters could've been more fleshed out aside from Aloy and possibly Sylens, but I understand the plot needs to keep moving and you need to meet many people to really understand the world.

For the negatives I encountered a few bugs still. You can easily get pushed out of bounds by machines in certain areas and as a result you need to reload save. I also think the machines have weird hitboxes sometimes and hit you when they aren't supposed to. I also think the game expects you to dodge as late as possible not to get hit because the machines somehow predict where you are going, like it homes in on where you are in the middle of their attack.

TLDR: Very good game gameplay-wise and super pretty for a 2017 game. Story is interesting but maybe not revolutionary.

In Horizon Zero Dawn you play as tribal huntress Aloy in a future world, in which robotic animals roam the landscape, trying to find out why the machines have suddenly become increasingly hostile.

i originally didn't want to recommend HZD after about 20 hours, because the game seemed generic and wearisome. however, i'm happy i then started to focus more on the main quest, which reinvigorated my interest. the setting and the story are clearly the forte of the game. the graphics also hold up really well, it still looks stunning. however, the side quests are, in my opinion, quite boring. i didn't vibe with the main character during those quests at all, aloy seemed a bit like the classic boring hero heroing things. that all changed when i started only playing main storyline quests, which is what i would recommend everyone to do. while the world is beautiful, nature diverse and the different tribes quite distinct, there is actually little to explore as no place has an actual backstory or meaningful quests attached to it. barely any npcs one can really talk to are around, and the towns and settlements seem repetitive.
the main story however is dope, the mechanics feel very good and the machine fights feel epic af.

This game is good. It's not great and I don't see a lot a of replay value but it is good enough that I will probably play the sequel. It doesn't play like a 7 year old game.

There is not a great deal of innovation here if you have played 3rd person action RPGs before with a stealth archer build you will find all of this very familiar. The mechanics are solid and the world is very pretty. Aloy is a great character to play and her story, as long as you can suspend the disbelief of humans surviving a roboapocolypse for more than a few dozens of hours, is a nice one to follow.

The history of the world is there to find and really you can skip most of the world building and not lose a lot. The problem with this, as with most post apocalypse stories, is that I just don't see how humanity survived it is just not believable. 

The other problem here is that Aloy and Sylens aside the ensemble cast is very one dimensional.
If you add to that the fact that the music (imo one of the most important parts of a game) is forgettable at best there are many reason whilst this is a good game, which I recommend you play, it will never get near any GOAT lists.

Pros
Stealth Archer Fun
Pretty world
great protagonist
Doesn't mention 25 dev studios in an absurdly long splash screen
Can skip all the dialogue and cut scenes
despite there being no save anywhere option I didn't have any rage moments with autosaves
pretty solid PC port not crashes

Cons
No save anywhere option. Uses fireplaces and autosaves.
No exit to desktop in the pause menu
The character hair and eyes are a bit off
Music = forgettable at best
ensemble cast of characters are very one dimensional. Some of the voice acting is poor.
limited role playing options cuts down on replayability

Conclusion Play it, it is fun just don't expect it change your life.

This has got to be the most overrated crap i've ever played. I swear, i tried to like it, i've given it many chances, but no! just no!
Combat is just not fun and more of a chore. I played it with a controller and also with M&KB and none of the ways felt intuitive. Alloy's positioning is all over the place and inconsistent, the enemies reach works on their favor everytime depending on your distance like they can somehow always reach your position. I could excuse this if firing the different weapons was any fun but instead it feels like wasting a barrage of ammo for no result even when hitting weakspots. The weapons that one could consider fun to use are best holstered since everytime they're fired there's a high probability they end up wasting more resources than you get from the outcome. the game is effectively trying to stop you from using what could be it's best feature. With so many enemy encounters in such a massive map, combat needed to be quicker to feel engaging but instead every encounter drags for so long it ends up feeling tedious.
The world is the typical "wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle". The map is massive as is the amount of useless crap scattered through it. If you played any of the ubisoft open world's, at least those usually have some kind of decent traversal while here is just mindless circling around rocks to collect a 1000 year old mug. The game only lets you climb specific areas and you can do nothing about the waist high wall blocking your path.
Missions are all the same with minimal variation: "activate sensor, follow clue, reach destination, kill enemy, get back".
What about the story? oh boy...! this is soap opera levels of predictable cringe! Alloy is a non-stop exposition dumpster! (Schwarzenegger shut up meme) There's not a single character that's not a complete plank of wood! not even mo-cap could help these characters feel a bit more alive. I'm not even going to comment too much about the fact that in a world where mankind allmost got wiped everyone acts as peacefull tribal comunities, Where are the cannibals? raiders? rapists? junkies? fanatic religious cults? people dying of starvation? there's so little of a sense of "decay" on the human side of things it ends up making the world feel unnatural.
If you want a good story, you won't find it here. Want a good post apocaliptic world? go play Mad Max. Want good combat fighting against big enemies? monster hunter is your friend.
This is nothing but AAA massive budget marketing to build hype. Many people might rate this crap up in denial from the fact they can't believe they spent 60$ on a product they wanted to be good and got this shit instead. This is just an example. modern AAA can kiss my ass!

I've had this game installed for years, having it rotting around on my Hard drive for years and after some time I've come back to playing it. I've spent my last weeks completing (probably) all the games missions and enjoying the atmosphere. Now I'm going to elaborate further on the good and the bad of this game. 

Starting things off, I'll start with the bad stuff, which there is not a lot of. 
[list]
    [*]Jumping and Rolling physics: This is one that drove me up a wall quiet a few times, even though it's not as big of an issue. You can only climb at marked spots (except for some ledges in the DLC area, where you also can climb), if you are jumping up the hills, there's basically a 50% chance of falling down again or getting up. As there are no slide physics when you fall down a hill, you just fall down and get a lot of fall damage or just die. It also happens that you get stuck in dead machines mid fight, which make it difficult to dodge attacks sometimes (that is probably what most of the time happened to me). 
This annoyed me the most, but it is forgiveable, it does make some fights or platforming a bit frustrating, but in the end it doesn't really affect the gameplay too much, as this mostly only happens once when it's happening, which is not a lot. 
    [*]Conversations with NPCs on the main map: As much as the cutscenes and lore behind the game are really wonderful, something that pulled me out of the immersion quiet a few times were the conversations with sidequest NPCs. They feel weird to talk to, their animations don't really make sense. This is a weird thing, but also only a minor issue, I mean this game is also 7 years old already, so it is forgiveable again. This Bulletpoint also doesn't count for the DLC, in the DLC area they nailed the sidequests and it's conversations, so thumbs up to that. 
[/list]

That's about it with the negatives. Now to the good stuff. 

Graphically, this game looks gorgeous and all the areas are very fun to explore. After Guerrilla made some updated, this game handles wonderfully and very linear everywhere in the game, although I've had some performance dips in the DLC area compared to the rest of the world. Runs well on both on Windows and Linux (with proton obviously). 
The story is very catching and I enjoyed every second of it, I like story oriented games a lot and I really like the character development throughout the story. Aloy is a wonderful role to play in a world like this, I like how she drops her one-liners here and there, also at places with previously completed missions to remind you of what happened at a place that you were at previously, or also her childish approaches in some situations, she truly feels human and how humans could react. Also I've found her voice to be very calming, even though the game rarely lets you feel safe. 
That's another thing that I like about the world, the lack of safety in almost all places of the map makes it very engaging. Sometimes it's a bit quiet and the surroundings are pretty empty and suddenly something pops out of the ground and attacks you and the next time you go there some entirely other machine is guarding the place. Every time I chose to get me a ride somewhere I've immediately regretted my decision as I've always felt like I missed something and went on by foot. 
The best part about this game together with the story is probably the combat system. I've never felt like I was missing some crucial information on how to fight someone or something and learning the patterns of the machines and its weaknesses is still very fun. You can customize your playstyle yourself. Do you like to just go in and fight alone with all of them at once? You can do that. Do you like to keep your distance and use your bow a lot? Sure. Do you like to stealth more? Sure thing. 

Summarized:
This game is very recommendable. It's graphically gorgeous, the story is great, the combat is great and new players will probably like this game too, as everything is meant to be easy to learn and hard to master. A must have in my opinion

Yes and no is still foolish... This is a Buyer be AWARE more than a Buyer BEWARE. This game is crippled by a couple of things that require pointing out otherwise this would be a "Yes" I guess. I have 100% completed the Base game and DLC so I have seen all the options. In the category of story this game may not be "unique" (what is anymore) but it does come close to exceptional. Dialog is entertaining and sometimes even thoughtful. As to Combat; here we get into the mess. The IDEA is great, the execution less so. Too often the game Swaps your camera to its own liking (that is to say where you cannot see) Random swapping of ammo types without any command to do so (this might be OK if it swapped to the best type but instead it is just random and useless mostly to mess up whatever you intended.) and the ever fun you press "turn left" and it turns right. Then there is the most shameful game mechanic of all time; The self gratification method. This is where if you are doing well the game "decides" to cheap shot you. Completely ridiculous things; pure cheating (you can even watch it in slow motion with certain skills), it is disgusting. The fact that it causes so very much frustration and anger is why this game needs this warning, it can really detract from the experience. Other issues are the foolish weapon system itself, the weapons are all the same except when they are not... that sounds meaningless and now you understand the weapon system... Multiple bows to fire different arrows that would work just fine in the "Standard" bow. It's honestly just too messy all round to describe adequately. Just another point of frustration. Rather than smooth game play you will constantly, not just be "swapping weapons to maximize combat", but instead you will be FIGHTING not the enemy but the controls more often than not. 
  Okay, that said I still liked the story and the character is relatable, the fandom is about the ideas not the game itself. There are A LOT of Drama issues surrounding the game that are yours to decide upon and I will not discuss but they ARE there. This game is a good Story and experience for the most part. but the issues may force you to "Give up" before finishing. As to completion, as I stated before I have completed both game and DLC at 100% so issues in the past concerning Glitched items/quests seem to have been resolved. They also added items to the merchants that can be bought that show the Hidden locations of the required items for 100% completion, that was appreciated greatly. So my review is a NO only because if everyone says "Yes" the game just shows "Very positive" and that just isn't true. But in the end if the price tag isn't too steep for you this is a story worth hearing perhaps. But if it is game play you are interested in you might want to look elsewhere.

In short: While the game has its flaws and bugs. It is often very engaging and fun. And the story is pretty well written. 

Horizon Zero Dawn is a fun action RPG where you live in a post apocalyptic world ruled over by big animal-like machines. The idea is that you craft weapons, you kill machines with those weapons, and the machines then drop goodies that allow you to make even stronger weapons. 

Most characters that you meet have an unique personality and have understandable motivations. Most questions you will come up with during your play through will be answered by the end. And these answers get pretty disturbing at times.

One thing I dislike however is the pathing mechanics specifically around climbing and take-downs. I do not know what went wrong in the development. But at times its pretty hard to see where you can, and cannot climb. To the extend I have been jumping against rocks way too many times. Sometimes the game has problems understanding which path you want to take, even though the path has been specifically crafted by the developers for the main story line. You do not want to know how many Aloy fell to her death because the game didn't register that I wanted to slide off a cable in my game.

There is also a lot of cheese possible in this game. Especially the stealth mechanics are incredibly bugged in the best ways. It can cause hilarious situations. The trip caster can also be abused very easily to cheese certain boss battles. I however, think this is great and love it. But I can imagine someone else not liking it.

Great game, spent 80 hours on one run. Go for it. 
I am a completionist and did all the side quests before going on main line, so that affects my experience. 
Idea and story are great. The pacing and revealing of the story could be better spread, also across side quests. 
Despite many tapes and texts with background information, in the end there are still many unanswered questions and important ones. So the satisfaction is not as it could be. 
The machines are a work of art. It was a joy to study every new kind and find ways to defeat them, where to shoot, see them explode and damage machines beside them. I even felt sorry for the deer-machines when they slowly limped with 10% hp. Could they feel pain, or could they not and were just damaged. So I learned to finish them quickly. 
Weapons are plentiful, but weird concept. Huge amount of different ranged weapons, but all enemies basically run into you to fight at close range. The spear is the only melee weapon and cannot be reasonably upgraded until the very end. Doesn't make sense. So in the early game, I mostly did stealth attacks to kill immedietely and avoid melee combat, in late I basically used the heavy bow and tried to one-shot machines from afar to avoid melee combat. Worked like a charm. 
My biggest problem is the wokeness, and once I noticed, everything became cringe. Most of bad guys and generally incompetent, confused people are men, most of good and competent and confident people are women, plus many small details in conversations, the "war against the patriarchy" in the hunters lodge. Through and through, just felt wrong. 
Characters were beautiful, with excellent faces and wardrobe. My favorite was Ikrie from the Banuk territory, I returned to do her trials many times. 
Sadly there was no romance, even though Aloy should be capable of feelings, should be curious about other genders in her age and some people were very handsome and likeable. But Aloy rarely showed any affection, maybe once or twice and those were just a sentence or two. 
Finding collectibles brought no satisfaction, eventhough there was a potential for altering the world with them. 
After leaving the Banuk territory to do the main quest line, I was level 50 and climbed to 60(max limit) pretty fast in the Carja territory and the previous enjoyment was gone. 
Summary:
+ machines
+ world building
- weapons and ranged/melee combat chaos
-- wokeness
- no romance
- 60 level cap

Horizon Zero Dawn stands as a groundbreaking achievement in the realm of gaming, seamlessly blending a captivating narrative with breathtaking visuals, innovative gameplay mechanics, and a meticulously crafted open world. Guerrilla Games has delivered a true masterpiece that sets a new standard for action RPGs.

At the heart of Horizon Zero Dawn is its protagonist, Aloy, a fierce and determined hunter in a world overrun by robotic creatures. Aloy's character is instantly compelling, and her journey to uncover the mysteries of her world is a driving force that propels players into a narrative rich with intrigue, emotion, and unexpected twists.

The game's open-world design is nothing short of spectacular. The post-apocalyptic landscape is a visual marvel, featuring diverse environments from lush forests to desolate deserts. The attention to detail in both the organic and mechanical aspects of the world is a testament to the developers' commitment to creating an immersive and believable setting.

A standout feature of Horizon Zero Dawn is the awe-inspiring robo-dinosaurs that roam the landscape. The design and animation of these robotic creatures are a testament to Guerrilla Games' technical prowess. Each encounter with these mechanical behemoths is a thrilling mix of strategy and action, with players utilizing Aloy's agility and an array of weapons to overcome their formidable adversaries.

The combat mechanics are a true highlight, offering a satisfying blend of ranged and melee attacks. Aloy's versatile arsenal, including the iconic bow and arrow, adds depth to engagements, allowing players to approach encounters with creativity and finesse. The strategic component of identifying weak points on robotic foes adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay.

The narrative unfolds through a combination of main quests, side quests, and environmental storytelling. Every discovery, every piece of lore contributes to a rich tapestry that keeps players invested in the world and its mysteries. The characters Aloy encounters, each with their own stories and motivations, further enrich the narrative experience.

Horizon Zero Dawn's soundtrack, composed by Joris de Man, contributes significantly to the game's emotional resonance. The haunting melodies and epic orchestral compositions perfectly complement the on-screen action, enhancing the overall atmosphere and immersion.

In conclusion, Horizon Zero Dawn is more than just a game; it's a triumph of storytelling, world-building, and gameplay innovation. Guerrilla Games has crafted an experience that not only pushes the boundaries of what is possible in gaming but also resonates with players on a profound level. For anyone seeking a captivating and visually stunning adventure, Horizon Zero Dawn is an absolute must-play. Enter Aloy's world, and prepare to be mesmerized.

Oh my god this game is SO DANG TEDIOUS.
I tried. I really did. I made it as far as Mother's Crown, then realized in the middle of a trial that I was simply wasting my time with this game. It's so slow and boring. I was doing better on the trial I was running... Logpile Trial... but it just wasn't fun at all.

I'd recently killed a pair of Sawtooths (Sawteeth?) for a task, and I managed just fine, but, even with tips online, it was work. Not hard, just... work. More than necessary for so early in the game. And past Mother's Crown, Sawtoothi become a regular thing.

After a couple of start-of-game must-haves (Silent Strike and Lure Call), I barely felt any "increases" in power, from gear or skills; either something suffers massive damage from a gimmick, or the fight takes too long to be fun, and there really isn't a way to mix the two. There's virtually no appreciable melee improvement (I'm yet to see a better spear), and, once the gimmick misses, combat is too busy to "plan" things like "knocking off armor pieces" (a selling point of some skills), because you're a paper tank in melee; two or three unlucky hits and you fold like a cheap suit. I hope you saved recently! And there's no melee options to exploit weaknesses... if they're vulnerable to fire, there are no fire-based melee options, for example.

Mobs are scattered around in groups, many of which aren't marked on the map, which makes travel unpleasant; either spam your Focus regularly, which REALLY slows you down, or be ready to run from unexpected encounters. You could use a "horse", but the horse controls are TERRIBLE.

And the camera. Oh god, the camera. There's no zoom whatsoever, and it clings to Aloy. Look: the player is not the character; being able to zoom out the camera a bit to look around the character gives the player info the character presumably picks up around them naturally. The game also requires knowing where key spots are to use, like tall grass patches, but the VERY up-close camera makes it hard to find what you need when you need it. Given that this is a stealth game with pretenses of melee and an expectation of mobility, the no-zoom camera is agonizing.

This "game" just feels like work.

Horizon Zero Dawn is my second introduction to Sony games. This game captures attention with its unusual setting and excellent storyline. Thanks to these factors, the game has no competitors in this genre. The best part is the combat system. Each robot is unique, has a good leveling system, etc. The main plot of the game draws you in from the very first minutes of the game, which is very cool.
