Overall a good game, and worth the price. While the gameplay and story are really generic and not really memorable, it still delivers an enjoyable experience for the most part. Aloy is a forgettable proganist and very generic, Runs great on steam deck also at 30fps on medium. Read below for a more detailed breakdown:

Horizon starts out really strong. You get introduced to this really bizarre distopian world built on top of a destroyed previous civilization. There are these massive machines roaming the world that you have to hunt as you try to survive. You get introduced to your hero, Aloy, you can't help but feel empathetic toward her as she is a young outcast trying to prove herself. As you move through the first parts of the game you attend this challenge to become a brave, you meet some interesting people...and then slowly the story just unravels into a really basic experience. All of the people who hated you suddenly respect you (despite initial reluctanance when you become a brave) and the dialog is very redundant and uninspired. Combine that with horrible animations and you just end up skipping most of the side quest dialogs.

The game also suffers from "large open world that is mostly empty" disorder. the map in this game is huge, and what should be fun to explore becomes a chore as everything just blends together. The most interesting areas (the cauldrens) suffer the same problem. They also implemented this weird fast travel system that requires you to use an item in order to travel. However crafting (or just buying) this item is easy and you'll quickly get a dozen of them, and eventually you can purchase one that gives yoy infinite fast travels. You also can fast travel to anywhere also and not just campfires, so this negates the entire point of exploration or the fast travel system. You could have been able to travel freely to certain points like cities or bonfires, or made it hard to aquire fast travel sacks so you have to carefully use them. 

Despite some problems the game is still fun, and there is a lot to do. It's not really different or unique in anything that it does, but if you like games like assassins creed you'll like this one.

Very good, but I feel like the sadistic gameplay would not hold up without the Ultra Hard setting gimmicks, particularly how effective elements and statuses are. Ultra Hard with your full modded kit (as you would use in NG+) feels like how the game is intended to play. Ultra Hard from a fresh game descends into ninja gaiden territory which is very fun if very time-consuming. Until the absolute end-game most roaming machine encounters command a lot of respect and strategy, and new machines are gracefully introduced through the main missions. I've shat on lots of "action" games lately and tried standard cheeses like just pumping blast wires and farming materials back up and it doesn't stand up to the encounters this game has to offer. Very nice. 

I don't really care about story at all, I think this game's was pretty okay. I do have some minor gripes not tied to combat however (except the one tied to combat).

1. The beginning of the game, the first bandit camp+cauldron, the entire Nora region...is really fucking good. I was excited to see 3/4th of the map still fogged after clearing the initial round of stuff. However...once you progress out of the sacred lands, scenery and environment gets pretty disappointing. I figured there'd be a pretty segmented Osseram area and a variety of locales, but it is 80% desert. the machine distribution also doesn't lend much to the environment...you will find snapmaws and glinthawks in the early desert, you will find them in the late desert, you will find them in the jungle, you will basically only stop finding snapmaws very very far north basically. I will point out the jungle area south of Meridian is what I'm asking for; stalkers suddenly appear all over the place and the greenery and cliffs are very distinct from other areas. There's even a cauldron that is pleasantly very different down there. But the rest of the west is pretty boring. 

2. Not a huge gripe personally, but DLC has pretty standard bullshit to test gameplay limits that well and truly do not scale like the rest of the game at all. They are pretty difficult, manageable, and strategic on lower difficulties...and you just cheese on UH. I would encourage people to show me otherwise. Triple corrupted iceclaws with a useful companion, double iceclaws in a horrific arena with a more-than-useless companion...and fireclaws/scorchers in general. It is CRAZY time-consuming doing any fights against the DLC enemies and it's the only point where I would complain the game resorts to lazy sponging on UH. Corrupted thunderjaws are scarce and usually merited by the occasion, while also being pretty melt-able if you're collected and do all the right things with endgame loadouts. The DLC enemies basically always pop up in Demonic form, which is short-hand for sponge form. The challenges are kind of comical but I wish these encounters were more approachable with conventional means. 

3. Sidequests...are honestly quite bad throughout. There are few enough in the nora region that they feel like little bonuses while exploring the map. I rolled my eyes every time I unveiled a new pocket of the west and the green exclamation mark popped up. The issue isn't necessarily in the quantity since this is an open-world game after all, but damn. I counted at least 13 side quests and errands that include a component of "well kill some glinthawks now". It definitely exceeds this but I can't place an exact number. These quests are comically similar and are all needlessly long without telling any kind of story. You get some lore from starting it, and the end of it has some kind of closure. This is almost invariably recovering someone who is lost or just killing someone. "Kill this enemy", "waste time tracking over 200m then kill this pack of enemies", "you found the person afterwards but there are bandits so kill them"...it is kind of dreadful. And again, every time it's glinthawks. Glinthawks surely destroyed the world, not the chariot class. To add insult to this, glinthawks are very trivial enemies with plugging a fire arrow then dispensing of their small health pool. Ultra Hard negates this advantage and makes them supremely tedious. Yes, I can kill a pack of three damned glinthawks at once. Why am I stuck doing this for any side story content the game has to offer?

Despite all of that, excellent game from start to finish. I was astonished how bug-free the game was and how pleasant the exploration aspect was until I sat down to finish 10-20 stray side quests and errands towards the end and started the DLC. This is a proper action though you might be godmode with freeze status and any dps arrow on lower difficulties. The roaming and climbing terrain like the endless mountains in this world is surprisingly pleasant given the lack of a glider or jetpack or the like. That would open up many more design opportunities for the world and is apparently one improvement from the sequel. Anyway, I see 0 reason to not play this game, I enjoyed it a lot and I think the appeal is pretty wide.

Coming in 7 years late to the party, I had a bit of a rocky start with this game, playing it on and off for 1 or 2 two hours at a time over the course of a month, not really "getting it". But upon starting to invest more time the game really opened up and I had a grand old time with the exploration, combat, and everything else your typical open world game is supposed to offer!

It might seem a bit like scrambling to find a complement (although I assure you this isn't the case), but the absolute best aspect of Horizon Zero Dawn, and the one thing that most sets it apart from other open-world titles, is the fascinating enemy design. The robots mimic real animals in look and behaviour, and just generally look cool af; wires exploding instead of veins bursting, and metal chucks flaking off when you land a heavy hit. The kicker here is that certain body parts of the machines have special effects when destroyed, anything from exploding to dropping off stronger weapons you can use to turn the tides. Each machine has it's own weakness and thus it's own personality, with a story on how the beast was toppled for the first time. It's extra cool that this story is unique for each player. While there are better ways of approaching a fight, it's not like one strategy is miles ahead of everything else in effectiveness, and the strongest weapons in the game (mostly from the DLC) require huge amounts of resources to use for longer than a second, so you can't just bully your way through every fight with the best firepower.

This does mean fighting loses some of it's engagement as you level up and become stronger and more of a hoarder though. It's a power fantasy to see machines that were previously behemoths become mere insects for sure, but you do lose a lot of the adrenaline that early game fights provided. There aren't machines strong enough to provide the same rush past a certain point. Fighting a Bellowback at level 10 is absolutely not the same as fighting a Thunderjaw at level 40. I wish there was a larger category of "late game" enemies and something resembling a single ultra-strong final boss machine, instead of swarms of middling-difficulty mobs. They do this a little in the DLC included with the Steam version, which is miles harder than anything in the base game. But even that never reaches the rush of having to sneak around the Nora starting area praying that that yellow exclamation sign doesn't light up, because [b]you know[/b] that Sawtooth will kill you once you've been noticed. 

This issue is a little bit a product of my completionist streak. I reached the max level in the game during the final mission, and was generally a lot stronger than if you play the game with the story as your focus.


Segueing into the story it's..... fine. The narrative is pretty generic, and none of the characters (including Aloy herself) are that interesting, but it hits all the emotional beats you'd expect and is generally serviceable if not forgettable. The side-quests can be cool with unique mechanics (like the one where you get the Oseram cannon and get to bomb the hell out of bandits)! Or they can be the 10th time you're send to track down some random friend/lover/deserter/thief just to have them die on you. It's pretty insulting how much the game tries to discard any moral ambiguity in Aloy by just having all the criminals and bad people die from machine attacks instead of like, anything impactful. 

There's (sometimes) a feature where you can control Aloy's response in a conversation but it's only slightly more than quarter-baked. It's the worst of both worlds: it doesn't change the story in any legitimate way aside from the next 2 lines of dialogue to make you feel like your choices matter, but it also ruins Aloy as her own person since the player now gets to make meaningful character-defining decisions for her. i have to imagine at some point in development this was supposed to actually impact the narrative but was cut for time.

A smart decision in most open-world games is to incorporate exploration into your narrative so the player [b]has[/b] to see the world you've spent years creating. Breath of the Wild (the only open-world game as we all know) does this by giving the player the choice of exploring any of the 4 cardinal directions to stumble their way into the story, in any order at that. Horizon Zero Dawn said "Nah." and has a story entirely driven by the premise of "go ride your robot horse in a straight path towards this yellow diamond to see the next cutscene". Luckily for the team, they sort of clumsily fall into a gold mine here, since you're able to explore the map (which is legitimately good) completely devoid of any thought about the story (which is legitimately mid).


Let's end on the map, which is a real hoot to expand and explore. Tallnecks are awesome, and hearing their thundering booms in the distance is always a treat when you're lost. The game announcing every new machine camp you come across lends to a real sense of progress in your journey. Collectibles being shown on the map ruin a bit of the surprise of finding something unexpected, but it also gets rid of the "clean-up frustration" of having to open up a guide online and watch 50 loading screens as you teleport to pick up everything you missed. It also sort of justifies the collectibles having pretty lame rewards, since they're easier to find. There are hard-to-find things that aren't on the map, but they are smartly relegated to being just lore and do not count towards completion percentage, so they're only for people who [b]really[/b] don't like seeing empty boxes in their inventory.

The map is also just genuinely beautiful with a plethora of biomes and flora to explore. The highlight here is the snow areas (they made an entire DLC focused around this), but every part of the map is stunning to look at and they all blend from one to the other seamlessly. We're in a time now when super realistic graphics and scenery is kind of a given for these cinematic-leaning big-budget games, but I often overlook releases like this when they happen, and it feels weird to play them past their relevance, so I'd say this is probably the most realistic game I've played to date, and one of the prettiest at that.

The music adds a little to this visual experience, being more about ambiance then melody; the instrumentation will change based on where in the world you are and how "tense" your fight with the machines is.


I write reviews more for myself than other people, but the TLDR for the public is: I do think Horizon Zero Dawn is worth buying today if you're looking for a lengthy open-world game that places a lot of emphasis on exploring a beautiful world at your pace, even if it comes with a weaker, more generic story. 

Even though the sequel is also coming to PC soon, and a lot of it's once unique high points are overshadowed by newer games, it still features probably the best enemy design of the bunch and comes with the sweet bonus of being 75% off during sales.

The good:
Again, story is pretty unique, enemies are really fun and varied, youve got loads to upgrade, and loot, different costumes with different bonuses, different weapons(although they basically follow a tier progression, up untill the very end dlc items that  are just OP which is not bad btw)

The bad/not so good:
Combat - the hitboxes are all over the place, and it seems to be based on dodge timings, as sometimes youll get hit even though youlll have seemingly dodged, as the attack animations dont seem to be visual but frame or some other weird shit based, can get  extremely annoying, especially on harder difficulties(you can get used to this, but its just, infuriating when it happens)

The open world and the questlines/missions - the map is HUGE, with the dlc its even bigger, the  quests are a bit all over the place, so youll be fast traveling a lot! Which isnt a bad thing, just make sure to get the infinite fast travel pack from one of the cities. The collectibles, again, not really an issue, you can buy all of the maps to find them at a merchaint, but it does turn into a bit of a checklist by the time youre nearing endgame, could be a bit, annoying.

The story -  Phew, honestly? its UNIQUE, ill give it that, but it feels a bit, weird sometimes, itll jump between , oh wow look at the people having trouble with x  to save the world from the bad robots, and at some points the tension is just, too and far  between to really keep you hooked. So dont expect something groundbraking like the witcher 3 or red dead 2 or something. Side caviat, the npcs, the facial animations are, odd in the base game, eyes wobbling all over, and npcs just stand there wide eyed whilst talking to you,its extremely offputting in the beginning (they did learn from it because when youll start the DLC content its like a whole new game in that regard, so id save it for last!)

One of the best games I've played. This game is not only visually impressive, but the story and the stark contrast between futuristic technology and viking-like culture makes the entire premise all the more interesting and unique to me. The amount of passion that was put into this game is truly shown by all the tiny details that accumulate in adding to the experience and immersion. Not only that, but it's open-world with tons of things to do such as side quests, secrets and collectibles, all plentiful.

The story is excellent, especially with that added contrast I mentioned earlier. Though it might be a little slow to start at the beginning of Aloy's story, it truly becomes more intriguing once you start learning about the robots and how and why they came to be.

From a gameplay perspective, it's not an easy experience. The best comparison I can make is that the combat takes a "Souls-like" inspiration, but a couple notches down and with its own unique mechanics such as specific weak spots on every robot, being able to dynamically tear off armor from robots, etc.. It might be hard to get a grasp on everything and understand what equipment is best used for what but once you understand weaknesses and an enemy's animation logic and can dodge properly, everything becomes fundamentally easier. Personally, I played on Hard and only really used the bow most of the game and did fine.

There's lots I'd love to compliment this game for, but all-in-all, it's a game I'd definitely recommend if you like "Souls-like" combat, difficulty, story, RPG mechanics, and an open-world.

A good game. 8/10
The pros: a different take on post-apocalyptic life/gameplay, a good story, and somewhat novel combat.
I'm only really good at writing about flaws, so here they are:
Arrows fly straight, until they disappear at their maximum range. I know she's a genius, but straight arrows are terrible gameplay, period. It doesn't ruin the combat, but it definitely harms it.
Knocked down enemies can be given an extra powerful blow with RB. However, it often doesn't recognize them, so instead you whack them with a light spear attack. This is bad.
The climbing is terrible. There are yellow ropes and metals indicating where you can climb, and she's completely incompetent anywhere else. She will not use her arms anywhere else, so she falls for no reason. It's not well done.
There are other bugs, in a number of places.
Stealth attacks are really weak against most enemies.
You can't control when its nighttime, and with the glare from my windows I can't see crap at night.
Rocks in stealth don’t work right. So instead, they give you a magical single-target whistle.
She screams random things, often when stealthed, including “look out below!”
When she rappels, she jumps off a cliff and throws out an axe on a rope and it magically catches perfectly and she never falls to her death. It's stylish, but incredibly stupid.
There are other problems, but ultimately this is a good game.

I loved this game! It's one of the best I've played in recent years. The world is rich and colorful, and the main story is intriguing. The mystery of Zero Dawn had me invested from start to finish. There's a ton of unique characters to meet, but I'll admit that most of them aren't super memorable outside of a small handful. There's a bunch of side quests to keep you busy as well, but there's not so many that it feels overwhelming. Some are interesting, others are a little tedious. The enemies are pretty neat, I mean, who doesn't want robot dinosaurs? Not only do they look cool, they're a lot of fun to fight. The combat is all about technique. The game gives you a bunch of tools to mess around with as you discover each new machine's weaknesses and strengths. There's a little bit of stealth too, which breaks up the pace nicely sometimes. After I finished my first playthrough, I immediately started a new game and went out of my way to get all the achievements. I definitely recommend this game to anyone that wants a good single player sci-fi mystery with solid and enjoyable combat.

A great sci fi story with compelling characters that's mired down with way too much "open world" gameplay stretching things out far beyond their welcome.

I spent ~90 hrs on this game. It should have been a tight 20 hr game at most.

No one wants to read a wall of text, so here's pro's and con's:

+ Beautiful graphics
+ Character control is smooth and forgiving
+ Story keeps you going
+ Characters that actually have character
+ Characters dealing with emotional situations that drew a tear from me at times
+ 

- Story takes a while to ramp up
- Story has several "I saw that coming a mile away" moments
- Story has several plot holes you could drive a bus through (can't say w/o spoilers)
- MASSIVE world map.. that's pointless to explore (no rewards for doing so)
- "Open World" busy work done to extremes
- Often quests force you to run back-n-forth to opposite sides of the massive map
- Paltry rewards for demanding quests / collections that demean the experience
- "Detective Mode" you have to constantly toggle on/off gets old fast
- "Every fight is a boss fight" gets exhausting fast
- Play the way you want (eg: stealth) until game forces you to play its way (eg: forced combat w/o places to hide)
- Contextual commands (eg: press X to do Y action!) are sketchy sometimes

This game is a dichotomy. It could have been a wonderful, tight, 10-20 hr story with light RPG elements and a few, wonderful locations.

Instead, the dev studio decided to make it like every other open world game (Far Cry, Just Cause, Assasin's Creed, Grand Theft Auto, etc) and create a massive game world with a ton of busy work to fill it in. This includes "tower climbs" to reveal the map, scavenger hunts for junk, side quests for random follks, competitions (eg: hunting time trials.. b/c in a post-apoc world with people worried about killer beasts, we need to have a competition on who can kill them faster! smh).

Now layer in hunting and crafting. But, like most things in this game, take it to extremes, too. Every weapon seems to have it's own ammo pouch. And they each have 4 upgrades. These require common, rare and very rare ingredients to create. But, it's dumb in how they did it. Something requires a rabbit skin. Ok, I'll just kill a rabb-.. wait, why isn't there a skin on the rabbit? Oh, right.. b/c it's a rare drop. So, keep killing rabbits until one drops a skin.

It's just MMO open world tropes like this that force things to be a longer slog than they need be.

Need new gear? Well, the vendor wants money.. plus the heart of some crazy beast that almost killed you last time you fought it. Oh, but the heart is a rare drop. So, go fight 20 more of those until you get it. It just makes you roll your eyes.

They also went with the loot box trend by making most of your rewards loot boxes. Problem is, the loot boxes are filled with junk you find just wandering around. It's not like you get a new weapon or other interesting stuff. Only very few quests do that. Most give you an "extraordinary" loot box that, when opened, feels like someone just handed you their trash to go take to the dump. It makes whatever grand experience you just had surviving beasts or bandits by the skin of your teeth feel utterly insulting when someone hands you a bin of common trinkets you could have found on your own in 2 seconds.

The game world isn't worth exploring. A road leading to a dead-end towards a mountain is just a dead-end. There's no magic waiting for you if you check it out. There is vast expanses of emptiness on the map, and they are just that.. empty.

The most excitement you'll have is hunting or evading the robo beasts, which gets harder the further into the game you go.

The combats can get utterly ridiculous, even with Aloy being high level. You can hp every level, but it feels like they secretly also raise your damage amount. Because my gear wasn't upgraded very much, but I was one or two shotting things that were giving me serious trouble early in the game. I don't think it was skill. I feel like the game just cheats and makes you secretly more powerful as you level without you knowing. Sort of like how Borderlands has it's annoying level system, where anything one or two levels higher than you is god-like, but anything lower level than you is a push-over.. just artificially done like that.

The story is interesting, but that's why the slog of the open world aspect makes it so dichotomous. You're following along this adult story of serious events, then spending 90% of your time chasing animals around for rare drops, or going and screwing around in the hunting time trials or other dumb stuff. The fate of humanity is on your shoulders, but, ok, I'll go stop by the hunting grounds and play some games for a bit. No big rush. *rolls eyes*

It's like having a steak dinner, but in between each bite of delicious steak you're expected to eat a basket of bread. At first, the bread is tasty. But, then you realize that, at the pace things are going, this meal is going to be 20 baskets of bread to 1 tiny steak when you're done.

I'd much rather they consolidated certain events into a single, special one than to have multiples of it wasting more time. EG: you have several that let you control animals. I'd rather just have one that unlocks all the animals.

The game should have removed the scavenger hunts, consolidated some quests, etc, etc, and focused on getting the player to the next plot point as soon as possible to keep the momentum going.

Instead, we got this.

If you can slog it out for 50+ hrs with open world game tropes, then this game is worth a shot for the story. Otherwise, avoid.

Hey choombas, it's your boy Ausy, beaming to you from the neon-soaked basement under your ma's pad, ready to drop some chooms on "Horizon Zero Dawn." Buckle up, 'cause this ain't your granny's game review.

Kickin' it off, where do we even start with this badass piece of art? It's like "God of War" hooked up with some high-class sci-fi saga, no deities attached. And out popped this masterpiece. Folks, we're jaw-deep in primo graphics, a story that's gonna blast your brain, and combat mechanics smoother than a corpo's lie.

I'm a story gonk, no denyin'. This game? It's like shooting purest narrative adrenaline straight into your veins. Dive deep into this one and you're swimming in a tale smoother than Johnny Silverhand’s last solo. "Horizon Zero Dawn" doesn’t just deliver; it kicks the door down and throws a fucken party.

Enter stage left: Aloy. This young chick's not just some Amazonian wanna be; she's a damn typhoon of badassery. With quips as sharp as 'er arrows, slinging sarcasm (if you choose the right words) and arrows with the same deadly precision.. Sure, she's playing for the good guys, but in a world that's a few clicks shy of total anarchy, her style of good-hearted ass-kickin' is a real breath of fresh air.

Now, let's talk heat. Aloy's packin' bows, arrows, and spears like she’s Robin Hood’s tech-savvy offspring. Spot a Bellowback? Pop its cargo sac, and it's light-show time, baby. And wranglin' those metal monsters? It’s like hackin' a Militech server on steroids – pure edge-of-your-seat, chrome-cool action.

This game slams you with urgency right from the start, like a mystery wrapped in an enigma, then dunked in secret sauce. No spoilers here, just a big-ass thumbs up for the wild ride.

To close out this braindance: Was it a blast? Damn straight. Pumped for the sequel? Like a fucken hacker on the edge of a breakthrough. "Horizon Zero Dawn" isn’t just a game; it’s an epic freakin' voyage. Till the next time we jack in, choombas. This is Ausy, logging off. Stay wired and keep those pixels poppin’.

Easily my favorite game. The gameplay is a beautiful balance between stealth and pseudo bossfight mechanics for each of the creatures (enabling both the "low level boss monster becomes a regular enemy at higher levels" thing, along with "shoot here to disable ability X" type gameplay). The setting is interesting and well developed, but the story doesn't give away too much too fast. The mystery of *why* there are robot animals everywhere is teased and slowly revealed along with exactly who you are. 
Bonus points for the story integration with the "Frozen Wilds" DLC (included for free) which can be played almost as soon as you get access to the area rather than locking it behind the final mission. As a result, dialog both in the main quest and the DLC can change depending on what parts of the mystery your character has discovered, dynamically making sense that you can ask about thing X but not thing Y. 
The game also features a cool system where if you want to craft an upgrade or buy an item and you don't have the parts (or even if you don't have the money) for it, you can have it *make a quest for you* to get those items, and that quest will dynamically point you at the best place to farm those items. More games need a to-do list like that.
I almost never do a New Game Plus run right after the original playthrough, but for this I dove straight into NG+ ultrahard (in retrospect, should have farmed some shards first). I do not recommend ultrahard for a first playthrough, but if you enjoyed the game, the fight mechanics hold up with increased difficulty.

So, this game is awesome on soooo many levels! I myself am a practicing Catholic, before anyone starts getting angsty about it - let me explain why that is super important for this review.

This game, despite some issues I have with it - plot-wise, for example, there's an element of sci-fi which goes against moral values we hold, as well as some gameplay elements I know some Catholics would object to - is deeply, truly, profoundly Catholic. For the first time I have played a video game which wasn't something with a crude, "squint and you can kind of see it" representation of Catholicism that also wasn't in hatred of my people; rather, this is a game which has so many deep presentations of the Faith I hold which makes me feel, yes! I'm finally represented in a game! Yes! There are people out there who love to make games, high-quality, holy games which present the themes of my Faith even in characters who in the game, do not believe!

I mean, Rost naming Aloy in a religious reitual some days after she was born, without a mother - is so much a reflection of the Lord, being born without a biological Father, being named by His foster-father, St. Joseph, 8 days after His birth into a world which is cruel, cold, and relentlessly dangerous. How much love must they have poured into this game! How much awe and wonder does this evoke in me! How much glory do people skim over when they play this - unaware of the truly deep beauty this game hides just below its surface?

Yes, Aloy may be an atheist in the game; yes, she may not ever believe in my Faith, even if It were shown her - etc, etc, etc. Yes. People can see this game as anti-religion. But I see the opposite: a game which is anti-idols (made of metal, mostly in the game) but which uses these peoples' faiths, to review our own religious beliefs and show that even among those who are not Catholic, there is still the Lord showing Himself on ways they themselves can only understand, reaching out beyond what they know, beyond what I might be uncomfortable with, saying, "I am here, and I want you to know you matter to Me! That is why this game exists - beyond the images on the screen, there is Me."

And yet, while all this is good - great, even! - I had to stop playing after about 24 hours because the plot becoming too heavy of a depressing burden. Not that I don't love the characters, or the world, but at one point, I felt this game revealed within me a fearful depression that was too much for me, to healthily continue this game. At least for now.

Still, besides that - it has holiness embedded within it beyond the surface, but barely so. I recommend this game just for that. I know this game means a lot to many people for many reasons - some of which I would heartily either disagree with or maybe even just like to discuss with them - but for me, this game matters because of its beauty, and that I felt truly presented and represented by a game which by no means is small. This game is cool. I finally feel there is a game out there I can say, "It shows ME! It shows my Faith! My life, my beliefs! And so many people love it in turn!"

Thank you for whoever put so many of these things into a game. I finally feel like I am shown in and through a game. I feel happy to say that, nobody else could have made a game like this which shows me. My people. My family. We finally get to game in a way that shows us for us, not a caricature. Thank you

Maybe 2-3 hours to get supplies I needed for "Adept" weapons and armor. I got really good at quickly switching between armors as needed mid-battle.

I have changed my opinion on this game, unfortunately.
It seems to be an interesting game at first glace, with really good visuals and a mysterious, beautiful world to investigate and weapons to try out on the different enemies.
Turned out that the only good thing is the looks on this game, the game mechanics are quite bad.
Even though the enemies have certain "weak spots" (or so the game says, the reality is that whatever I do and wherever I hit them, they take very little damage regardless of how much I buff my weapons), it's always a struggle to beat them, and very rapidly (if there's no tall grass to hide in) you get a horde of jumping beasts hitting you, no matter how careful and stealthy you tried to be, and it will be very often your end.
Fighting humans was the most boring, poorly experience in a game I had in a very, very long time. There's just no strategy to use. Just wait away and shoot arrows one by one. So bad.
I started playing the game with a controller, but I noticed from the beginning that it wouldn't be possible to enjoy sitting back with it, as the aiming was absolutely impaired by the poor precision of the aiming sensibility.
Even after switching to play with keyboard and mouse, I found the use of traps, potions and abilities VERY frustrating, why the HELL they put these three completely different actions in one single key, for which you have to scroll with left and right keys through about 10 items in the middle of a battle with some overpowered beast just jumping over you and smashing?! It's pretty much impossible to use this in battle, I can't believe devs were ok with this functionality all the way up to the release of the game, and more so the people playing don't mind this!. This pretty much destroyed the game for me, as every combat is very difficult and you really need to use all these resources in most of them. Even walking prepared into a battle, with the item selected won't help, because you'll probably have to use 3 or 4, which can't even be sorted on your preference. Their accessibility is abysmal and it absolutely kills the fun of the combat, to the point of ALT+F4 TF out of the game.
Other things that I noticed in time are that the weapons and costumes, the loot and crafting are very basic and obsolete in essence, and definitely not fun or exciting to pursue, which as a consequence makes the exploring less exciting.
I found really cool landscapes which looked amazing visually, but there was nothing to be found within besides a generic pile of scrap to loot actually..scrap..and they were just a view from far. WHAT A DISAPPOINTMENT.
In fact, WHAT A DISAPPOINTMENT OF A GAME.
I'm actually curious about seeing more of the map, I'm curious, but the fact that I would have to force myself to play this game in order to satisfy that curiosity, instead of being pulled by fun mechanics and enjoy all the work that it would take, says a lot of how broken the game mechanics are. At least for me. I see a lot of people loved this game, but I didn't even find the story interesting, in that matter, it didn't catch me a bit from the beginning. A lot of talking doesn't make a good story, or a "story deep" as the Steam tag says.
Just another machine holocaust with a society regression to tribe life. Haven't we see that already, anyways?


First review starting the game:
I'm really enjoying this game (far from finishing it yet!), I love the post apocalyptic setting, it really does a great job with the exploring part, the world looks beautiful and intriguing in knowing how everything went wrong for the world as we know it.
There are lots of different areas and caves to explore and they really look beautiful.
The character is very expressive and likeable, the NPCs are also well acted.
A few things bother me though, specially in terms of combat. I'm playing with a controller now, and I find VERY difficult to aim to small objects (most of robotic enemies have weak points to shoot at to defeat them easier) as there's no sensitivity adjustment when aiming the ranged weapon (something that's been implemented decades ago!!) and aiming precisely with the camera sensitivity is almost impossible. This takes a LOT of the fun to have with the game mechanics, so it's a BIG deal!! Not a game breaker, but it really frustrates me not to be able to aim precisely and I don't want to be sitting in front of my computer with a mouse and keyboard.. It's a real shame. I thought it could be a weapon perk or a skill to improve but it doesn't look like it so far.
There's a skill to slow time, but it doesn't help really, as a tiny little touch of the stick will move the reticle all the way past over the target.
Decreasing the view sensibility would make looking around too slow, so I'm stuck with the poor aiming.
The melee fighting is not great neither, pretty much a button smasher and the occasional roll to the side, it could be done way more complex and satisfying with such a variety of enemies to fight!

The traversing could be more polished too, the character gets stuck in really short jumps and ledges where baby Lara Croft wouldn't have a problem.

Besides all these quite big issues, I'm actually enjoying the exploration side of the game, I loved to see how the full moon was peeking from behind the mountain peaks and illuminating the tree tops in real time while I was hiding in the bushes from a pack of angry enemies wanting my blood. A beautiful moment.

Anyways, will add more to this if if comes up as I play the game, but I have to say, I'd recommend this game as far as I've played it!

You know it is funny to me seeing the wide range of criticism of this game online. I personally don't think the game is amazing and I can understand why many people wouldn't like it. However, I found that the combat was some of the most fun combat of any ARPG I have played in ages outside of the Batman Arkham series and Shadow of War. It is just deep enough to force players to focus on aim and elemental weaknesses at higher difficulties. The game unfortunately is far too easy even on Ultra Hard if you really pay attention to stuns. Everything seems to be capable of doing stuns once you accumulate enough damage and it makes it fairly trivial to stun an entire group of enemies for brief moments while you take on the larger ones.

The story of the game is a mixed bag. The story that is happening at the present time the game takes place is nothing to write home about but it has it's moments. However, the story that takes place that you find through video logs, voice logs, and text logs is some of the best sci-fi world building/writing I have ever seen in a video game. The Faro Plague is such a unique antagonist and I was absolutely hooked on finding every single log I could find in the open world and campaign missions just to flesh out that narrative more.

All in all. 100% worth the sale price (usually $15 or less) and once you get past the first 5-10 hours the game really opens up to you.

OH MY GOOOSSSHH!!! Where and how to even begin this review!?! This game is absolutely amazing!! I am a HUGE fan the final fantasy games and this one caught my attention because it gave me instant Final Fantasy type vibes from the trailer I had watched. I happened to purchase this game on a Black Friday sale and I could not be happier that I had!! Let me start by saying that the atmosphere, cinema photography, the music made it all so easy to get lost within the world! The story line was amazing and literally had me wanting more. I found myself fighting and struggling within...Do I hurry through the mission story line or do I complete some side quests along the way? Ultimately I ended up doing some side quests along the way but I found myself longing to know more of Aloy's story. I found myself becoming so invested in some of the characters that I literally would become a bit emotional with watching some of the scenes. Yes, I am a bit of an emotional ball of nutty feelings most the time, but it's not very often I find myself emotionally invested in characters in video games and this is one game that was able to achieve that for me! So big Kudo points for that!

Again I cannot say how beautiful the layout of the game truly is! Mechanical animals roam rampant in this vast open world game which after a certain point in the game you learn how to override them and are able to use a mechanical beast to aid you in part of your journey. My favorite was the option of riding a mount (a mechanical horse, bull, or ram). I often just found myself riding from point A to point B because of the enjoyment, plus there's always the perk of being able to grab more items along the way. 

This game is easy enough to finish without having to purchase the frozen wild however the frozen wild seems like it may contribute more to the story of one of the tribes that Aloy meets along the way. I haven't completed the Frozen Wild yet at the time of writing this review. In fact I'm just getting ready to start it.  Make sure once you have completed the game though that you watch a scene they have added at the end of the game after the credits. It sets up for the sequel that is coming later this year. Oh goodness I don't think I've been this excited for a game release in a loooong time!!! Horizon Zero Dawn is an amazing game and even with over 88 hours invested into it I still have plenty left to do to complete it 100% but I don't mind. I have loved every minute of it, and don't dread investing anymore time in the game either. I guess it gives me plenty to do while I wait for the sequel to be released!

The main protagonist is a strong independent ginger, not much more to say, i think it is self explanatory. The combat felt challenging, and requiring pixel perfect aiming, and sometimes not even that worked, i guess there were some troubles with the port? Also platforming, sometimes hero would not grab a ledge, that it should, and you would fall to your death, or did not fire from the bow when it should. I also often died because got stuck in places, and could not get out, or enemy would drive you into the corner and would not let you get up, felt a bit strange. The world building is super nice, and i think a much much better game could have been made with this setting. I think this game is heavily overrated, it is a 6-7 at best.

I like dinosaurs, I like robots, I like open worlds...

And that's basically it. It was all there for me to enjoy the game, but for some reason it just didn't click in to me. I guess this is an unpopular opinions, since many love this game, but I just want to say that I really struggled to get into it.

The entire dinorobots schtick gets stale once you realize how to work with it. Open world is basically an Ubiworld style, meaning that all side content is just like playing a single player MMO fetch quests with no meaning. RPG progression feels meaningless as you get abilities rather fast and items don't really need replacing a lot once you buy some better stuff early on. I could go on. The story and setting actually seems very interesting but the pacing of it is terrible in the 12 hours I spent with it. Even AC Odyssey with it's terrible mandatory level grinds felt better paced.

The game is beautiful (apart from lip syncing), runs very smoothly even on midrange hardware and is stable - definitely seen worse PS ports to PC... and it might just be your vibe, but for me it just didn't click at all.

Check out some videoreviews with longer gameplay loop to find out whether it's actually for you or not. Definitely not for me though.

Played and completed for the first time in 2023. I went in with zero background knowledge of this game, and was very surprised with how the story reeled me in. 

I ended up beating the main story in about 25 hours of play time, and at no point was I bored or feeling like the game was dragging on. Combat felt awesome, difficulty was brutal at some points until you learn the machines attack patterns.

I love the fact that the side missions are 100% optional. I did my fair share of what I felt was interesting and still ended up well over the recommended level for the final boss. 

The less than stellar parts: inventory management, crafting and gear. It all felt tact on, which seems odd for a game where you're surviving and traversing the wild. I ended up with a ton of extra supplies that by the end of the game I just stopped picking up stuff entirely. Weapon upgrades felt fine, but armor upgrades felt lacking. The need to constantly be crafting ammo mid fight also felt bad.


The movement, combat and story should be enough to draw you into this game. I highly recommend it.

A great RPG with stunning graphics, an interesting story, and tough combat encounters. 

The game has a beautiful open world that will give you many photo-ops as you walk through a forest into a clearing or climb a ridge to see a vast mountain chain. The story has great voice acting and writing for the main characters, and lots of scattered datapoints that construct a chillingly-plausible depiction of humanity's future (hint: look out for white cubes on your compass). Depending on difficulty, the close-combat fights will force you to be prepared or pay the price, and over time you unlock more abilities and develop real skills that make you better at combat without grinding. The included post-main-campaign expansion will push you to your limit, and there's a new-game+ mode if you want to go beyond.

Overall, an easy recommendation for anyone who likes grand open-world exploration games. Think Breath of the Wild or Far Cry, but with much more lore than the former and more up-close and lower-tech fighting than the latter.

Horizon Zero Dawn, my thoughts:
The first time I played this game was on my ps4 pro, it was one of the reasons why I even bought that console honestly.
I ended up loving the game and played through it 2 times on that console. So here I am playing through it on my pc still loving every single moment. 
The story gets to me, the design of the machines, the design of the character and ofc, the world itself. The history that is going on in this world also intrigues me to no end to the point that I just sit there and read text after text of information I find. I just want to know more about the world to the point that I will stop playing just to read about it.
Are there some flaws? Of course, what game doesn’t have flaws. When I first played it I didn’t notice it as much, but now after playing it for a third time I noticed that I found the climbing a little bit annoying. Sometimes it wasn’t super clear what ledges I could climb and which ones I couldn’t, I think the main issue stems from the fact that the ledges you can climb up have a white coloured marking on it. Which is a bit hard to see when the area is either filled with snow or when the light shines a little bit too brightly upon it. It’s a bit of a nitpick but still a flaw so I felt it was worth mentioning. 

I cannot recommend this game enough. If you love a story driven game with interesting characters, an interesting world that is full of life, running around all over the place (or ride) to explore? Then I would recommend this game to you.

Has all the polish you'd expect from a former Sony exclusive, but it's a pale and shallow facsimile to better games like Witcher 3 and Monster Hunter, in virtually every way. The Witcher 3 inspiration is worn pretty clearly on Horizon's sleeve, but everything it copies, just makes me wish I was playing Witcher instead.

The good is the creature design - fighting robot dinosaurs is just as cool as it sounds on paper. Weapons also feel pretty satisfying. There's also a wealth of straight up scenery porn for anyone that wants to make use of the game's built in camera mode, and just get lost in the sprawling hinterlands. 

The Bad: Pretty much everything else, including elements from the good. Very few characters feel nuanced, and even personal quests for other characters that seem to hold a great sense of significance, winds up being largely unfulfilling and underwhelming - solving the legend of Redmaw, being a prime example. The way people and documents built that guy up, I thought I'd be facing Zacama or something, but it was just a slightly tougher t-rex than normal. 

Traveling the countryside feels like an incredible chore. You know something is wrong when you're burning through fast travels just so you can finish the game sooner. When you have an encounter with one creature, you're liable to encounter another group of creatures, just from hearing the commotion. Do the different species of creatures brawl with each other out of territorial instinct, like you'd see in Monster Hunter? Nope. It's a tightly coordinated effort of Ravagers, Sabertooths, Scrappers, Watchers, Longlegs, and of course, Glinthawks - all against the woefully average Aloy. And when you find out why machines don't attack each other(with the exceptions of ones you have to individually hack and override), it's the kind of reveal that just feels insulting to the player's intelligence. 

I don't know who on the committee was so hung up over Glinthawks, but they are the biggest chore to deal with, and they never stop being dangerous in groups. And they easily make up the fixture of more sidequests and missions than any other creature in the game, combined. Just the glinthawks alone make me never want to touch this cancerous game again. Just imagine having an ability to slow down time to line up your killing shot, and because you gotta tilt you camera up at a cowardly opponent that's always up in the air, the camera keeps getting crowded out by the foliage you're standing or crouching in. That's not a good challenge, that's just sloppy, stupid game design. 

If I do play anymore beyond this review, it'll only be due to the sunk cost fallacy and me stubbornly not allowing this game to be a  complete waste of time, as opposed to me genuinely enjoying the journey. I know how the game wants the player to play it, but you burn through so much Blaze while crafting ammo for your most powerful and useful weapons, and it in turn burns out your wallet when you resupply. Overall, it's not as if I can't handle a good challenge. But the challenging elements of this game seem to mostly be implemented to be tedious and infuriating, rather than testing the player's skill or stealth or ingenuity. It feels like an amateur effort from a Publisher that has decades' worth of experience making much better exclusives. 

Now admittedly, I should also give a begrudging merit to this game, in that Horizon runs exactly as intended. Even if your graphics card is behind the game's preferred hardware specs, it doesn't seem like that'll affect your experience much. So if you like having to wrangle some grass eater every single time you need a Roche, you like having to constantly waste resources that take a lot of time to gather, and tiptoe through mountainous environments that make your footing difficult to manage, and you somehow absolutely LOVE dealing with the millions of Glinthawks this game throws at you, then there are at least some players that will appreciate Horizon more than I did. No real game breaking experiences other than temporary freezes when saving at campfires.  

Also, as a closing thought, if you think I'm being totally unfair to this game, have a look at all the achievements. I hardly consider myself an achievement hunter, but a fair number of the ones I've scored have barely been touched by anymore than 15-30 percent of the playerbase, particularly the late game ones. And they weren't like side stuff you really gotta dig around online to discover, they're just missions that push the main story forward. Seems I'm not the only one that got tired of this game's tedium.

tl;dr - Don't touch this game for any less than a 90% discount. And even then, your time is still much better spent on Monster Hunter and Witcher 3.

Overall, I don't intend to keep playing. I just didn't click with this.

long version:
games feels worse when it very very close to greatness but just falls short. rather than when its flaws are very visible and you can appreciate the things it does well. and that is the case with Horizon zero dawn.

-the world is beautiful to explore... and yet you are limited climbing only on very specific colored hand grip places, your character is capable to amazing acrobatics and climbing feats on those, but is stoped by walls and rocks on her neck height

i could go on, but you can apply that to everything in the game. 
the end result is a game that would have been great... 20 years ago. is not bad by any means, but eehhhhh

I've spent a considerable amount of time playing this game, finding it hard to quit, primarily due to my high expectations fueled by its widespread acclaim. However, it turned out to be a hybrid of a FarCry-style fetch quest and Tomb Raider-esque character dynamics, but in a third-person shooter format. The storyline is lackluster, riddled with nonsensical elements and plot holes, making the gameplay tedious and monotonous. It's essentially a journey from one point to another, interspersed with frequent yet irrelevant cutscenes that add little to the overall experience. The combat mechanics are hit or miss, oscillating between being overly simplistic and frustratingly dependent on luck. The weapons, though intended to be innovative, come off as trite and uninspired. The "Focus" feature feels like a leftover developer tool rather than a thoughtfully integrated game element. As of now, the game feels superficial and disappointing. I plan to continue playing for a bit longer, but my hopes aren't high. On a positive note, the graphics are decent, and the game runs smoothly. However, the cutscenes, presented in a 4:3 aspect ratio despite playing on a widescreen, are a major letdown. It's baffling why they weren't rendered using the game engine and instead appear pre-rendered in an outdated format. Quite a pity, indeed.

This game is great! I didn't know what to expect when I first got this game, I didn't notice the stealth tag as it is pretty low on the tags, but the game is highly built around stealth. I usually have not been much of a fan of stealth games, however Horizon Zero Dawn allows for what I call "loud stealth" which is if you get spotted while sneaking, you are more than capable to hold your ground in a fight. Stealth is not necessary to beat this game, and when you play the game like I do, you use stealth as an opening tool to combat before going in bows blazing. The stealth is somewhat similar to the Assassins creed games.

There are options in the dialogues which allow you to respond to the conversation in one of 3 ways; compassion, intelligence, or with anger. It's not a lot of options but it is nice that there are at least some options as to how you would like your main character to act and behave for role playing purposes. It was satisfying to play as a compassionate character with the occasional cunning idea, but at the end of the game when dealing with one of the games major villains, I was able to show them no mercy which to me was more meaningful. I'm not certain but I don't believe the dialogue options affect the story, so don't worry about thinking too hard on which option you choose and if it's the "right one".

One of the things that stands out the most about this game is the atmosphere. The world creates this sense of wonder as to how things are primitive yet futuristic at the same time. The game does a good job at pacing how they tell you why the world is the way that it is without feeling like there is an info dump as well as giving you enough time to digest last piece of the stories puzzle before giving you another.

I don't remember coming across any major bugs or glitches in my play through except one which was apparently somewhat common in the steam port, when you unlock the ability to knock 2-3 arrows in your bow, it just doesn't work as if you didn't unlock the ability. This may have to do with the fact that I didn't play with a controller, this bug is by no mean game breaking but I feel that it is at least worth mentioning when leaving a review. 

Overall the game is great and I would highly recommend anyone to play this game if they haven't. Graphics are good, the story is good, the core game play of the game is good, and there is plenty of content in the game to keep you busy.  The game also frequently goes on sale and is certainly worth the money, I am eagerly awaiting the next game!

I was hesitant to play this game at first because I didn't really buy into the roots/tribal + sci-fi dinosaurs theme. And to be frank I don't think my thematic preferences will change even after playing the game.

But...

That being said, after playing for a few hours, I must say that it is as very well executed. While playing the game, it isn't at all a turn off like I thought it would be. I am totally immersed, and while playing the game, I love mechanical dinosaurs and I love the tribal aesthetics.

Two things that usually I specifically don't favour at all.

I must insist on this because it give important context to my praise of the game. I have two negative biases against the basic concept of the game, but when I'm playing the game, these bias completely disappear, because they are doing two things right. Well they are doing a lot more than two things right, but I don't feel like writing for 30 minutes so I'll just praise those two things which stand out the most for me.

1. The World-Building : it is done very well and you can feel that this is a LOT more than a combination of ideas, it has dept and coherence and the world feels very much alive. They have really thought about this. I am impressed.

2. The Cutscenes and the Acting : It is not only good, it is great. A shinning example of how digital faces can feel like they havce a soul. All the characters have real personalities that are not only accessories for variety but are actual characters which you rapidly feel you can know and have deeper insights about them. 

There are two reasdons I can see why it is such a success for me. First the characters are all given true credibility by actors who seem to have really poured life into their characters. That is paramount and bravo. 

Second, and for that reason alone I am glad I bought the game because this does it for me : the minuscule and constant movement of the eyes and the intricacies of the facial expressions of the models are astoundingly perfect.

THIS is the secret to creating convincing 3D models. The movement constant and subtle mopvement of the eyes is exactly like a real person would do it, and that alone gives tremendous credibility to the characters, you just get drawn into it.

Compared to it, other good narrative games are worthy attempts, but for this one, in my eyes, this is how you do it.

If the narrative experience is something that can make or break a game for you and you are hesitant about this title, then go ahead my friend, you'll be served something exquisite.

I bought this game on a whim due to the Winter Sale, and also I was curious to see what the hype about this game is all about. As of this writing, I am about an hour or so into the game, and hence, hadn't really gotten into the main story as of yet. But the little that I've seen of Aloy's story and the world, I do like it.

The game is set in a post apocalyptic world that had been largely inhabited by machines, with a few human tribes being the sole humans left in the world - which is a big change from most post-apocalyptic games that I've played in the past. The combat system is easy to pick up, and there are several resources you can pick up around the world and even loot the machines you fell to make better gear and weapons and even upgrade your satchels. 

This game runs great on my Steam Deck straight out of the box, and I have no issues when running the game. Ironically, it's on my PC when I run into issues, as the game lag or freeze at certain points, especially during the opening sequence, and even crashed on me a few times. I guess I'll probably be playing this game on my Steam Deck for the foreseeable future until I either upgrade my PC or start building my own.

[h1][u]Striking Graphics, Missed Opportunities[/u][/h1]

While I had high hopes for this game, it ultimately fell short of my expectations for what makes a truly engaging RPG.

[b][u]Pro:[/u][/b]
+ Unique and captivating scenario.
+ Excellent graphics and improved performance post-patches.
+ Aloy is a compelling protagonist with varied dialogue options.

[b][u]Contra:[/u][/b]
- The story lacks player impact, offering only one ending and feeling like a movie.
- The open world is underwhelming with limited activities.
- Side quests are tedious and seem to unnecessarily prolong the game.
- Combat system focuses too much on dodging and ranged attacks.
- The melee skill tree is ineffective, making ranged combat almost mandatory.
- Lack of a true parkour system limits exploration to specific areas only.

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
This game lands squarely as [u]AVERAGE[/u] in my RPG experiences. Despite its promising premise and protagonist, it falls short in delivering a dynamic RPG experience, with a linear story, lackluster world, and unfulfilling combat mechanics. It's a game that shines in certain aspects but ultimately fails to provide the depth and freedom expected in a top-tier RPG.
Stunning game with a deep story.

Pros: 
Great story.  an original take on the "post Apocalyptic" story line meshed with "10,000 BC" that works really well.  The lore is interesting and you can skip reading all the little details an still now what happened.  
Shooting is fun. The primitive weapon gameplay is fun, lets a wannabe sneaky, ninja sniper like me play at his pace, while giving enough challenge in the hectic fights to be borderline infuriating.  Sometimes arrows track targets, sometimes they don't.  you can sneak up to a high spot, snipe at your targets with tight aim, or you can fire frantically at the tail of a mechanical T-Rex while he stomps you...
Cons:
Camera... All that fun arrow shooting gets  frustrating when you're crouched in tall grass and the camera settles behind a log or leaf or something and you can't see your target.  And I desperately wanted some sort of Lock-on feature. Fighting said T-Rex while he is running around the area, dodging and jumping out of the way, then having to swing the camera around just in time for him to charge past you again was getting old.  Both of these problems were worse in the Frozen Wilds maps with snow and more frantic enemies.  
Invisible Walls... In a game where climbing up mountains is part of the gameplay, and trying to snipe from a safe distance is too, I ran in to a lot of invisible walls where Aloy just wouldn't jump up on that rock or a few spots where arrows stuck in mid air.  not a huge deal, but noticeable. Only being able to climb on clearly indicated yellow ledges is a trope, but it stood out here where traversal is such a big thing in the gameplay.
Sound design.... This game made me think about playing Shadow of the Colossus... riding your horse through the wide open terrain, no music, just the "natural" sounds of the environment.  Horizon didn't do that... Instead, you have sometimes very intrusive synthesizer music popping up out of nowhere.  I don't know how many times I ducked for cover because of one track that clearly had danger cues to it, but was just the open world.  Its a shame, too, because the music is pretty good, just inappropriate. Then, especially in the endgame while exploring the last couple of dungeons with Sylens in your ear, you come across hologram projectors that play way too loud, then Aloy and Sylens start talking over them and you cant hear what they are saying.  One time, I had an audio story file playing when I triggered a hologram, and then Sylens started talking.  All three voice tracks going at the same time... You cant do that to the late, great Lance Reddick! Other times, Aloy is making the same dumb comment she did last time you slid down a hill, at full volume... The sound design is just so poorly done in some sections that I felt like muting my game at times.

I just finished the main story today and feel like I can give it a fair shake now: 

Let's go by technology first:
The game still looks beautiful, with a nice day/night cycle, lush environments (snow/tundra, desert, lush forest and so on) and a variety of enemies. Grass moves in the wind, you leave tracks in the snow and so on. So graphics are really nice. Music is mostly subdued and only picks up during certain events. Can't say I cared very much for the music, tbh. Gameplay-wise this is a mixed bag for me. Movements are fluid, weapons are varied and you have always different approaches to objectives. For example you often are able to stealth-kill, sneak around or even take over (machine-) enemies. However there are also, in my opinion, glaring problems with the gameplay: climbing and verticality only works at certain points. So you can only climb walls the devs want you to climb, which sometimes lead to frustrating searches for the "right" way to climb a mountain without any indication why, exactly, only that rock surface is climbable. This broke immersion for me. You can also conquer "dungeons" called cauldrons here that sequentially unlock the ability to take over the machines that populate the map. Cool in theory, but you can't give them any commands and only some of them can be used as mounts. This is especially infuriating when you learn that you can take over the T-Rex style robot and the giant electric Eagle, but you can't ride them and their only function is to attack enemies that are nearby. So it's basically useless to take over these machines. I understand that having a flying mount would open up a whole different level of technical difficulties for the devs but it still feels like a big missed opportunity. 
Otherwise it took me about 50 hours to complete the main story, plus however long it will take me to finish the expansion. But beware, there is a lot of busywork that reminds of the Far Cry games (and not in a good way) where you run around getting collectables, audio and text logs, free "corrupted zones" of machines and so on. This stuff feels like sub-par randomly generated busywork though I suppose it was deliberately placed on the map by the dev-team.
On the other hand there are fully acted and voiced side quests with their own little story lines that are, while not  Shakespeare, at least serviceable and they also managed to let those side quests feed back into the main story in a small way. 
The main story though is excellent and I really enjoyed it and thought it was quite unique. So this game is worth a playthrough alone for the main story. There is also a "new game +", however that's not for me I think as I dislike the busywork and therefore won't complete everything there is in this game and the story also lends itself to only one playthrough (at least if you rummage around a bit and get all the background info in form of text/audio logs pertaining to the main story). If you're a completionist I would think you can keep busy in the main game for 80-100 hours alone, not counting the expansion. So there is a lot you get for your money if you're a completionist. 
Overall I would say this is a very competent, polished game with an engaging story and some sub-par busywork that's just there to pad the playtime. If you can stomach that type of game then I say go for it, it's worth it.

Title: A Promising Blend with Minor Hiccups

Rating: ★★★★☆

I recently played this game on my Steam Deck, and I must say, the visuals on the smaller screen are impressive. The fusion of Assassin's Creed Odyssey and Fallout styles creates a unique atmosphere that keeps you engaged.

While the FPS drops occasionally occurred, they weren't game-breaking and didn't overshadow the overall experience. The intriguing storyline, complete with unexpected plot twists, kept me hooked from start to finish.

However, the game's attempt at promoting inclusivity felt forced, with a noticeable imbalance in character portrayal. It's disappointing to see most white males depicted as villains, alcoholics, or ex-war criminals. On the flip side, the positive portrayals of characters often come with unnecessary details like being gay or vegan, raising questions about the relevance of such specifics in the game.

Despite these concerns, the game manages to deliver an enjoyable experience, blending elements from popular franchises. With some adjustments to its approach on inclusivity, it has the potential to be an even more captivating adventure.

Pleasantly surprised by the quality of this game. Sure, it's heavily inspired by AC and alike, but it has its own character and much tighter and cleaner-designed core game systems compared to AC, FC, or TR.

The game's main narrative premise is very well unpacked, and the characters are well-written and designed, butt the best feature is combat, this game is about combat:

It grew on me with the time, the more I play, the more I appreciate the combat, some fights are just supper interesting from machine behavior perspective. The fact, that you can destroy certain parts of the robot to disable certain functionalities like vision or hitting fuel tanks with fire arrow makes them explode, which stuns the machine, certain weak spots are susceptible to certain type of elemental damage, they communicate between each other  -  this is just pure awesomeness. It's a real time slasher combat system with so many layers, where you have to make those decisions fast, kinda tactical but very fast. Stealth works as you expect and is an integral part of the combat.

This game undersold itself to me. I only recently bought it on a recommendation when it went on sale for 75% off, and I didn't really expect to enjoy it. I was wrong.

I have read some really strange complaints about how this game is really boring with your typical open-world killing/crafting/questing. In a way this is what I thought of the game at a glance. That is wrong.

Horizon Zero Dawn works so well from beginning to end because of its very believable world, the nuances in stealth, characters you can comfortably care for, and satisfying combat.

I'm pretty sure it takes a lot from the modern Tomb Raider games which I have replayed several times in the past but it does so much of a better job, where Tomb Raider concentrates mostly on action sequences, Horizon Zero Dawn has an incredible story to tell where the more you learn, the more you want to find out, even to the end.

The game does have some minor flaws. The very first one came where it seemed like I could climb rock faces that I couldn't, and this largely continues until the end of the game. Notebooks and audio logs are scattered in the world and I could not care less about them - the world building is amazing, but these are not for me. Occasionally I would play an audio log while I continued moving around and nothing else was going on, however one section of the game is absolutely littered with these collectibles and if I wanted to pay attention to this part of the story, my momentum would have grinded to a screeching halt for the sake of a lot of reading and waiting until an audio log had finished until I got to the next one - that wasn't happening.

In combat, there's no parry, but there is a "dodge" roll, however there were times I felt like I rolled away and still got hit. The machines in this game are designed to feel dangerous, and this never really slowed down. While earlier machines get much easier, the difficulty in the larger machines ramps up considerably. While I felt like I could beat every kind of machine, combat with them felt rough, and I liked that. 

One more thing about combat is the controls which took some getting used to - you have a spear, and all your ranged attacks. You cannot "select" your spear - it is your default weapon when you press attack. To use a ranged weapon, you select the type of attack you want to perform with it (ie. which kind of ammo to use), hold right click to aim it and then press left click to attack. If you weave ranged attacks with melee attacks, you have to switch between these interchangeably. Eventually I got so used to this that it worked and flowed well, but to begin with, it felt very strange that I wouldn't just select a weapon and then attack with it.

These are only nitpicks that I thought could have potentially been improved upon. The game is amazing and now that I've finished it, I'm only sorry I didn't notice and buy it earlier on. Horizon Forbidden West, its sequel, is definitely on my radar when it comes to steam soon.

If you need to read a review to understand how good of a game Horizon is then you have been living under a rock.  A must play for any gamer.  option of stealth, direct combat, strategy, and a very well done difficulty hierarchy.  The New Game+ on Ultra hard is a good balance of keeping all your old gear without being overpowered.

Edit: 12/18/2023

Let me break it down to the basics.

1) Graphics: are great. You almost forget you are playing a game, and it's easy to get wrapped up in the beauty.
2) Game-play: is easy to learn. Mostly the key-binds are loosely intuitive.
3) Crafting: essentially grinding for materials is a must. It's simply part-and-parcel a staple of the game.
4) Story: it is a fantasy, futuristic, post apocalyptic world; no zombies, but machines equal to the task.
5) Difficulty: there are several difficulty levels; story based (easy) to OMG (veteran).

Yes, you are using arrows to fight metallic beasts. I have read complaints that there is no way arrows could penetrate metal. Regardless your take, so what. It is fantasy, make believe, and uses imagination to drive entertainment (equally, though there are no zombies in this game, it can be said you can't kill a zombie, it's already dead; just saying).

Bottom line, this game is well worth the investment. I got it on sale and is worth every penny. I have not encountered any game shattering bugs. I think this series is worth it as an open world, play at your pace, kind of game. Exploring is encouraged, and surprises are to be expected around every corner.

I have played for 70 hours, and 30% of the game - it should have gotten game of the year. I am having so much fun.

I highly recommend the game.

Loved it through and through and if anyone is thinking bout giving it a go due to the sale, I'd say go for it. Went in with no spoilers and now its got me really excited for Forbidden West's PC release which is slated to be early next year.

Pros:
1. Does a good job of familiarising you with the game's mechanics and the practices you should adopt while not completely handholding the player like some other modern games.
2. Well balanced difficulty setting (mostly did my first playthrough on very hard)
3. World building is really good, from how the world looks and how alive it feels on a base level, to the lore and fun character narratives in side missions and datalogs. Main characters of the narrative are really well crafted imo.
4. If you like machines, open world freeroam, diversity in hunting and a good narrative, the game will not fail to deliver.
5. Main narrative/story was really well crafted, with the ending amping up the challenge and being highly satisfying to get through. Felt like a good conlusion at the end, unlike some other games which just go "play the next game to know what really happens", while also leaving on a good cliffhanger making the player eager for the next game.
6. I would get distracted by the machines and just get lost hunting the machines for long stretches in between story mission because it just feels fun to do so, the hunting aspect of the game is really a major part of the experience, atleast for me and has me totally hooked.

Cons:
1. No big complaints with the game except for how the lipsync for some NPCs and facial expressions during cutscenes would be totally off. I've heard that they've improved upon it in Forbidden West so that's good ig.
2. Humans generally felt very easy and their AI felt very base level when compared to machines. Makes the humans very non challenging to face but that may be intentional game design, idk.

Overall, a really fun experience, looks beautiful even though its over half a decade old. Highly recommended.

HZD is one of those gems that reminds me why I still play games. I don't think I've felt this enthralled by an open world since I first played Skyrim 10 years ago. It's one of those games where you enjoy just being in the world, looking at stuff and going "Ooh! Ahh!" because everything just looks so fucking nice. I couldn't stop taking screenshots, and that was at MEDIUM graphical settings with low textures. The story is good but not incredible, the combat is fun, the Far Cry-esque progression is satisfying, and the exploration is done well. The only major drawback for HZD is that some of the voice lines sound low-quality, probably because of faulty compression, and it can be offputting at times. It's like what happened with the voice lines in Far Cry 3. All in all, I'd highly recommend this game at $12.49 USD when it goes on sale next. If you like The Witcher 3, Red Dead Redemption 2, any of the Far Cry games or Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor, you'll absolutely love this. 

PRO TIP: If you get the game, I recommend putting it on an SSD and setting textures to low to avoid stuttering. Thank me later.
