I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Honestly, one of the more unique games I've played recently. 

A compelling post-apocalyptic yet futuristic theme, compelling storytelling and character investment, fun combat, innovative gameplay mechanics... Need I go on?

Horizon Zero Dawn is just stunning with its gorgeous landscapes that totally draw you in. The game mechanics are easy to pick up, and having a bunch of different weapons to take on machines and enemies is a blast. The side quests are a good time, even if the main story feels a bit short. But oh boy, that plot deserves a perfect 10/10 – it's just so darn good, like a chef's kiss kind of good, you know?

This is an open world survival combat game not entirely unlike Assassin's creed, but this is a totally unique experience.
Like many other games like this, the game offers lots of combat alternatives in the form of various gadgets, gizmos, and devices to use other than just your fists. Such examples include spiderman, assassins creed, shadow of mordor, and Read Dead Redemption. Having played all of the games listed above (and most, if not all, of their respective sequels), this is the first game where I have ever been interested in using said gadgets, gizmos, and devices. I have always been able to rely on my own skills and the basic combat mechanics to make my way through the story and any coinciding side missions or tasks I might find myself interesting in. Horizon Zero Dawn however, does not allow this. The game at many times nearly forces you to use, or consider using, ever available item at your disposal to take down your enemy.
With horizon, many of the missions have been entirely unbeatable unless you use other things besides just your bow and your spear. I regularly use traps, bombs, different arrow types, tripwires, ropecasters, etc to take down my enemies, which is not something I've ever tried before with any other game, or at least not to this extent. At about every turn, I've found myself actually planning out how I'm going to approach different situations based on my environment and the devices available to me, which has been a very unique and positive gaming experience.

Great game!

The dialogue is completely forgettable.
None of the NPCs are written to a level that would cause emotional attachment.
The only NPCs with half a personality - Rost and the blond brat - are killed within the first hour of the game.
5 hours into the game, there is no story to speak of and I doubt that there will be one.

The climbing is perfect where devs specifically designed it, and nonexistent where they overlooked it. 
Collision with environmental objects such as trees and rocks is funnily outdated.
Enemy attacks have wildly unpredictable hitboxes, but you can spam dodge roll for tons of i-frames.

The resource system is ... very boring but incredibly rewarding. I kill 50 boars, I am invincible for the next few fights thanks to full-heal potions. Is that good design? Idk, you tell me.
The Quests are boring and forgettable. Who cares why I am clearing out the bandit camp or taking down multiple sawtooths? It's hella fun to do it! Why the absolutely generic NPCs?

With all respect to the devs, if this game was recently published, I'd accuse them of using ChatGPT for all of their dialogue- and story-writing past the tutorial. The resource-collecting and crafting has no purpose except stalling the game out.

[h1]Complexity simplified[/h1]

Well worth the full price. There, I said it... and I don't even know where to start.

You play as Aloy — a motherless child left to be raised in an environment with barely any odds for lone survival. It's your typical "zero-to-hero" narrative, but with top-of-the-crop ingredients and just enough seasonings that make the experience special. Without dwelling into spoilers, I would deem Horizon: Zero Dawn as a must-have experience for Sci-Fi and Post-Apocalypse nerds.

Landscape and level design are absolutely bonkers — I had a feeling even the most minuscule piece of dirt was placed there for a reason. I cannot reckon playing a game with a game world so visually immersive other than The Witcher 3. Even the relics of the old civilizations felt so eerie and somehow alive. When you add the absolute smasher of the OST (Aloy's Theme in particular), it is hard not to feel all the emotions of warmth, cold, fear, relief, sorrow, irrelevance, and grandiosity at the same time.

Ranged combat is favoured throughout the game, although I got to experience stleath in the early levels. While some of the people held a grudge against this, I found it refreshing and incredibly lore-friendly. This game does not pursue the usual RPG tropes where it's selling you its lack of vision for an "uniquely yours experience". This game is not that. It's Aloy's story -- a linear open-world experience not pretending otherwise.

While we are at it, as mentioned before, Aloy succumbs to the usual hero tropes -- for better or worse. Fortunately, the overall world-building and Aloy's placement in the grand narrative simply made the game incredible, at least for me. Even listening to collectible audiologs was so darn interesting and enriching. Further evidence of this is the fact that the game's ending actually feels like a proper ending. Once you get introduced to the post-credit cliffhanger, although you are left yearning for more, it's not the type of yearning where you're left with a feeling of being robbed of an experience for the sake of future installments and corporate greed. Morover, Frozen Wilds DLC fits well into the post-game lore expansion that will surely be valuable for the second installment.


Overall, Horizon: Zero Dawn is uniquely complex technical endevour that is successfully presented with refreshing well-dosed simplicity. I had 2 crashes throughout the whole playthrough — although I am more than convinced they were related to abysmal AMD drivers (7800XT).

My rating: 8/10

* Horizon: Zero Dawn while not the most stable or post-launch supported port of a PS5 game to the PC is still an amazing title and a franchise I am eager to see continue to develop not only on PC but in its story. Having said that the game does have some rough edges many stemming from the aforementioned lack of support it has gotten on PC from water interaction animations and cutscenes seemingly playing at very low FPS despite having around 200 FPS unlocked which most likely stems from the original coding and hardware limitations it had on its console launch, as well as an uneasy amount of eye movement from various characters during cutscenes which I can only chalk that up to facial animations being tied to framerate. In terms of auditory issues, the game does tend to reuse a lot of the same voice actors for various characters which is most apparent with the guards having many of the same voice lines repeated over and over and cloth armor both on Aloy and some important characters use a lot of metal chainmail like sounds which seem out of place. During my playthrough, I also encountered issues of audio playing simultaneously from audio logs found within the world at the same time important characters tried to fill Aloy in on something with important exposition causing a lot of auditory overlap. As for the story while amazing it does suffer from a slow start with many of the major events both from the main story and side quests not seemingly acknowledged by the residents around you. Often these events come with some sort of dialogue options on how you want to approach them which is a nice touch but means very little in the way of actual game-changing outcomes paired with oddly long pauses in dialogue it does take some time for the story and it's characters to grow on you. One key note I would like to make is in terms of performance the game does not seem to like overlays be it Steam overlay or MSI Afterburners overly I did experience a few mid-game crashes and one consistent end-game crash forcing me to remove MSI afterburners overly known as Riveratuner Statistics along with disabling steam overlay. I was not able to narrow down which of these was causing said issues but they did not persist after their removal. In all, I am excited for this franchise to continue with the hopes that it also continue on PC for years to come!

Difficulty Played- Played at Ultra-Hard and Very Hard Difficulties the first time. Had to switch it down to very hard at some places. 

Combat Mechanics - Enjoyable and Fun. Easily the most under-rated RPG out there. This game is really well thought in terms of mechanics and I thoroughly enjoy playing it even when not associated with the main story line.

Graphics - I love playing games with exploratory maps with a mixture of seasons and weathers. I am not a full time hard-core gamer. I have played AC-Odyssey and AC-Origins in the past. I do not think the environment is as amazingly built as in AC-Odyssey. Characters have better models and are more good looking than AC-Odyssey.

Long range/Short range Combat - Remember that this game might not be for people with strong preference for lot of close combat. The game requires a lot of arrow usage mixed with close combat with a spear. But as I grew into the game, I realised arrows are more important in this game instead of more close combat weapons and play-style. There is sufficient variety of bow and arrows to keep the combat engaging and fun.

Story - I am not a fan of story in games, I never find myself being associated with the characters in games. All I majorly care for is combat variety and mechanics, which involved weapons, Armours etc.

Bought this up on a super-discount as I've always heard decent things about it. I'm not super big on open-world survivals, only due to burn out of these types of games.. but honestly, this was nice! I always love sniping things off anyway and this game really encourage snipe-tactics and traps. A lot of the time laying traps feels more off an afterthought, but here.. I actually made pretty damn good use of them. 

The environment is wonderfully done. The graphics are a little dated, and talking npcs definitely feel their age in graphical date- but its serviceable. Simple yet information-ready UI and quick radial menus make really navigating through the menus not much of a hassle. Music is absolutely stellar, though some sound effects got a bit annoying. Especially with hitting critical areas of enemies. Dunno, that sound just bugged me after awhile.

I encountered no bugs on my full 70 hour playthru, start to finish on normal difficulty. The story was alright, though the pacing felt a bit off sometimes. The way gear is discovered and upgraded can also feel a bit rushed? You can end up in the best of gear pretty much mid way thru the game. BUT, doesn't mean the game gets that much easier over it. Still some challenging fights- and even more so at harder modes. 

Its definitely a game worth delving into, especially if you can catch it on a discount. Its not going to break the ground in survival-gaming for most people, but its still a solid game that does a lot more right than bad. Some of the other detractors are your usual sub-genre of gamerbros who just don't like 'unsexified' female leads. Such amazing potential that is unfortunately squandered by sterile corporatism and illogical writing. Tribalism and sci-fi technology intertwining is a big reach, so it needs to be done logically. Unfortunately we don't get that here. Why on earth would people be shooting bows when there's laser shooting robots everywhere? Even better: there is scrap metal literally everywhere, so why are you wearing leather to fight these things?

They made the races mixed like it's the USA, and made sure to portray tribal aesthetics from multiple cultures. But it just doesn't work when they're that close. It doesn't make sense. And it doesn't look right. This made it feel very forced. The introduction to this game was amazing, and honestly super adorable. But after you're made a "Seeker", the quality in general just nosedives. The immersion was just pretty low. The story was afraid to be different. Which made it boring/ ultra PG.

One of the most fascinating post-apocalyptic games I've played! I thought it was just a tribal hunters kill mech-dinos game, but the story behind why the tribal hunters are the way they are and why there are mech-dinos is surprisingly convincing and intriguing! I eagerly found and read every piece of message left by the "old ones", especially in the Grave Hoard. The emails and voice logs that engage with the faro swarm apocalypse from different perspectives bring the certainty of the apocalypse to life. I was obsessed with the swarm, and thought I had watched a movie similar in concept before, but can't remember what it was called...
Buying the sequel on day one release of the PC port. Solid game.

First off, the main quests are pretty good. I have good investment in Aloy and the first couple hours set up an interesting plot I want to see through. 

But everything else, man, woof. The world is barren. Your map is covered in markers, but instead of interesting locales with dungeons or motivated little questlines, your markers are either "you can kill some robots here" or "you can find a collectible here". The sidequests are uninspired and require *so* much walking. Moreover there's little choice in how they're resolved--for example, you can't stop Aloy from being a narc and pettily demanding robin hood return the sword he stole to mr noble.

The robots are cool, fighting them is difficult and they are super varied. But a total underbaking of melee combat means you're constantly running away to plink off a shot only to run away again. Aiming your bow at close range isn't really an option at all (and trying to hit weak spots feels pretty unforgiving on higher difficulties).  You can lob grenades, but the blast radius on them also removes them as a close-quarters option. The combat pattern of shooting then running is not really to my taste. Moreover, there are lots of robots per pack so getting swarmed and ganked to death is super common at least until you realize that corruption arrows are the only viable strategy in many cases.

But what good aspects are there in the combat just doesn't overcome how much of a wasteland the world is. Nothing but trivial ubisoft style mini challenges to do, or some boring sidequests (that the game occasionally calls "Errands" which unavoidably makes you think of them as chores). You can do the only interesting thing, which is the main quest, but half the time the next objective is placed a mile away in unexplored territory, so enjoy your walk!!

It blows my mind that studios are still messing this up. Fallout New Vegas came out in 2010, had terrible combat and took place in the literal desert, but felt so much more lush than this. Heck, even Skyrim has better quests and some memorable characters. Horizon Zero Dawn is not worth the slog, but if you insist on playing it anyway, download some mods to remove loot drudgery (better drops, double medicine from plants, more inventory stacking) and beeline the main quests. I've heard the dlc is good too.

So this is easily one of the best narrative/storyline games I've ever played, so the 'recommend' was a no-brainer. With the sheer and titanic amount of love and effort put into developing this game, it's easily right up there with GTA V, Death Stranding, etc - at least in my opinion.

I'm going to do my best to provide no spoilers, so I'll be making use of the spoiler bars. Since this game is all about learning more and more as time goes on, it could potentially ruin the experience if too much is revealed - but that's up to you to reveal my spoilers or not.

So what's the basics/background? I'm going to begin using the spoiler bars here - but to be honest, what's mentioned in this section is hardly super important - what's blacked out right here is nothing you won't learn in the first fifteen minutes of gameplay, but still hiding it just in case. You are a young woman who lives in a day and age of bow and arrow, spear and sling. The world is filled with violent machines, and those machines kill humans when they spot them. [spoiler]This is because long ago, humanity was actually very high tech and the world was filled with super-advanced technology... but at some point, "something" went wrong. Humanity has turned from super advanced to primitive, going from immeasurably powerful weapons and AI back to the days of worshiping the sun and using bow and arrow to hunt. Why has this happened? Why are we now primitive and fighting machine animals all over the world? What has gone wrong?[/spoiler]

So now you are a young woman warrior in that world filled with hostile machine animals, and you're trying to figure out your place in the world. Some sort of major revelation always seems right around the corner... But you'll have to fight your way through this bizarre world for your answers. Using nothing but the very primitive weapons of our ancestors, you will fight the mechanical equivalent of our world today.

It needs to be pointed out that an immense amount of effort seems to have been put into developing this world - this isn't your usual copy+paste world of repeating visuals. This is a detailed world with many biomes, many cities, mountains, valleys, forests, plains, deserts, and everything in between. As an open world, you can explore as you like - as long as you can fend off the machines that threaten you. The graphics are some of the best I've seen in a while (besides Aloy's hair in the elevator, I mean... well, you'll see).

You take on the main storyline missions - or, there are a plethora of side missions (side missions, errands, 'tallneck' missions, cauldrons, and many more). In this way, you can focus on just beating the game as quickly as possible... or fleshing out the world by playing tons of side missions and really getting a bang for your buck. Think of GTA V, how you of course have the main missions, but then just TONS of side missions scattered all around to take on. That is this.

The fighting was beyond satisfying. Rather than just being a button-masher, where the worse the finger-seizure you have the better you do, this one relies heavily on using the right equipment, and using it right. Also, rather than just 'shoot the big machine target,' you have to pick your shots - I mean, you're fighting an enormous machine with a bow and arrow, so your attacks have to count. You've got to find weak points and exploit them, or use the machine's overall weakness against it. So you have to actually get good at the fighting to win battles.

It's also not a "line 'em up and mow 'em down" game. Very rarely will you have the ability to just mow down bad guys (and when you do, it's usually with extremely limited ammo). Each fight is a lethal struggle for survival. Each encounter forces you to put everything on the line to win. Granted, it gets a little easier as you level up and gain skills, but it's never a walk in the park - especially with some of the deadlier machines.

That's one thing I really appreciate about this game - the fighting. The fights actually matter. The equipment load-out matters - this isn't one of those games where you'll just use ranged or melee all the time - you'll have to combine to overcome. 

There's also a great use of stealth in the game. If you just charge in arrows flying, depending on the circumstance you can find yourself being overrun within seconds. You're free to fight however you like, but you'll quickly find it pays to sneak around as long as possible, head-shotting enemies to reduce the amount of people charging you once the battle becomes fully engaged.

The story is gripping. I found myself almost unable to stop playing because I simply HAD to know the answers. Why do we find ourselves in a world like this? What's up with the machines? What's up with the strange "metal cities" or whatever it was they called them, which are filled with high tech stuff? What is the story here - and what is Zero Dawn? I enjoyed every bit of the story.

The voice acting as above par. It wasn't the most gripping voice acting I've ever heard, but it wasn't distractingly mediocre, either. I would give that a 7 out of 10.

Graphics, as stated, were out of this world, besides a few quirks here and there... but in a game of this scope, I hardly think that's unreasonable.

The music/soundtrack was fantastic - often in games I'll turn music off as it is annoying, but in ones like this, where the music blends just right with the environment, I'll leave it on. Fantastic. The sounds fit right in, also, not ever sounding "wrong" or "weird."

Amount of stuff you could buy was a bit short,  but fine. I did find myself wishing there were more a selection of weapons to choose from - but the amount of customization you can put into each weapon kinda made up for that. Same with armor. The amount of machines in the game was JUST right - not so few that you're fighting the same thing over and over, but not so MANY that you give up trying to memorize the strengths/weaknesses of each one. It has JUST the right amount of machines.

Overall, I sunk about 60 hours into this game, and still didn't complete everything. (I mostly did not use fast travel, though.. It felt like a cheat - like if Aloy wants to get to Meridian, she'll have to fight her way there, so I wanted to be a part of that journey. So maybe my time logged could be a little inflated.) Since I bought this on sale, that is a HECK of a bang for a buck... but even at full price, that would have been less than a dollar an hour. So the question of "should I pay full price?" is easily answered: there is enough content in this game, it was executed well enough, and is just plain amazing enough that $50 is an easy sell. I would recommend this game to anyone, on sale or otherwise.

Absolutely one of the coolest games I've played in a very.. very long while. 10/10 would recommend. Darn near perfect. The only, only thing I didn't like about this game was that I waited so darn long to buy it. I should've bought this one a long time ago.

4/5. Horizon Zero Dawn is a solid story. It plays like Far Cry Primal with robots. You play a person who was exiled from her tribe for being motherless. You spend half the game finding out who is your mother/where you came from and the second half saving the world (naturally). The mechanics were fun to play, and the conversation aspect was good enough. Doing the side quests gave you a nice sendoff at the end. The only downfall was the color of the climb markers. The yellow and off white blended into the rock too well, and I spent a lot of time running in circles trying to find the start point. Neon green or neon blue would've been better. Otherwise, I thoroughly enjoyed the story.

That said, Frozen Wilds - 2/5. This was super boring, and I regretted playing it as recommended before the end game of HZD. It ruined the flow of the main story of the main game. There is nothing that interesting to learn that makes it worthwhile. The weapon upgrades are nice, but you can get those without doing the entire DLC. Find out how much what you want costs, run around harvesting gems, and done. If you want a better spear, it's a single side quest that you don't need to kill anything to get. There's a cool shock weapon you can get for doing the first main quest if you really want it for hardcore mode. This first main quest might be doable at early level, when you initially hear about Frozen Wilds (level 14 for me), if you try to avoid fighting. Really, though, I could've won the game without any upgrades and had a better time of it. I'd skip the DLC and stick to the main game.

This game is basically Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild but not as good.

Light on main story as most of the game is spent wandering around the game world doing stuff and collecting stuff. You use primitive melee and bow weapons when there was an age of technology in the past. You get meat from animals and horns from baddies. You get different outfits with different bonuses, none of which look like actual effective armor. This is a BotW clone but not as fun. Except for the climbing, which is a buggy version of Assassin's Creed/Uncharted that was ripped from Prince of Persia. It does have voice acting, but it's mostly just phoned in with the main character Alloy or whatever sounding like some teenage amateur trying poorly to mimic Commander Shephard from Mass Effect. And the tutorials could be better, they spend too much time explaining obvious stuff, while I was around 14 hours in before discovering that you can expand your inventory, they definitely should have mentioned that was possible earlier. Melee combat should be better balanced too, the spear seems to just be for occasional stealth kills as it is basically impossible to avoid most melee attacks because there is no Flurry Rush like in BotW, unless that is an advanced skill I have not reached yet.

So why positive? Well, BotW was amazing. Everyone except a few XBox fanboys who never played it and are thus missing out on one of the greatest games of all time would agree on that, so who wouldn't want more BotW clones? It is a smart move to learn from the best. I have heard that they might make another one of these Horizon games one day? I bet it will copy improvements from TotK since this is basically a BotW fan game but not as good. I mean, the alternative would be a BotW clone that is better than BotW, and that is basically impossible for some no-name developer so I'll take what I can get.

This game has some great moments but there is WAY to much filler dialogue. Half the game feels like a mix between watching TV and listening to the radio. Entire areas filled with data pads that you'll need to scan in order to get the full story. You'll spend hours either reading paragraphs of story or listening to it. Add the forced NPC dialogues with wheel after wheel of babble and it's beyond excessive. 

The game play can be fun but it's basically just another Fallout / Farcry / Just Cause / Assassin's Creed / etc, re-skin. So many of the decisions regarding this games development feel like they were made to pad game time rather improve the experience. Is the story well written? Yes. Could that story be presented in a way that didn't result in the player literally barely interacting with an interactive medium? Also yes.

I vividly recall watching Horizon's debut through a streamer's eyes, initially drawn in by its stellar graphics and compelling storyline. The game's standout feature, combat against machines, adds an exhilarating twist to an already engaging experience.

The mechanics are a standout highlight, particularly the ability to scan enemies for weak spots and tailor arrow types accordingly. The variety—regular, tear, shock, frost, fire arrows—enhances strategic depth, making encounters truly immersive.

Visually, Horizon hits a perfect score. The synchronization between mouth movements and voice acting is impeccable, complementing the stunning graphics that beautifully craft its art style.

One facet of the storyline that left a lasting impression was Aloy's journey from societal rejection to becoming a beacon of hope. Her evolution from an outcast to a revered figure, saving countless lives from the looming machine threat, is a captivating narrative turn.

Environments remain consistently refreshing, devoid of repetition. Each area brings new experiences, save for the familiar herbs, maintaining a diverse and captivating world.

Immersed in the game's audio with headphones on, I found it both captivating and functional, aiding in tracking enemy movements and adding depth to encounters with satisfying combat sounds.

The ability to override and stylishly dismantle machines stands as a unique and thrilling feature, further elevating the gameplay experience.

While encountering a few minor bugs—like arrows passing through enemies and herbs stuck in rocks—these were hardly detracting factors from an otherwise flawless adventure.

With the inclusion of a New Game+ feature, Horizon offers the opportunity to increase the challenge while retaining progress. This feature, combined with varied dialog options and reduced fast travel, adds substantial replay value.

In summary, Horizon deserves a perfect score of 10/10. It comes highly recommended. Its immersive world and gameplay beckon players to experience it repeatedly. Embrace the title of Nora and delve into this remarkable journey—it's an experience you truly deserve.

A Masterpiece Unveiled: Horizon Zero Dawn

Horizon Zero Dawn is not just a video game; it's a breathtaking journey into a meticulously crafted world that seamlessly blends stunning visuals, gripping storytelling, and exhilarating gameplay. Guerrilla Games has outdone themselves, delivering an opus that stands as a testament to the limitless potential of the gaming medium.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Aloy, the game's fearless and charismatic protagonist, you are thrust into a post-apocalyptic world teeming with mechanical beasts and a lush, vibrant environment. The sheer beauty of the landscape is awe-inspiring, with each sunset casting a warm glow on the ancient ruins and dense forests that beg exploration.

The narrative is a triumph of storytelling, weaving a complex tapestry of mystery, intrigue, and emotion. Aloy's quest to unravel the enigma of her past unfolds with cinematic grace, drawing players into a narrative that feels both personal and epic. The writing is top-notch, filled with well-developed characters, unexpected twists, and poignant moments that resonate long after the credits roll.

But Horizon Zero Dawn's true marvel lies in its gameplay. The dynamic combat system is a symphony of strategy and skill, as players must study the behavior of robotic creatures to exploit weaknesses and emerge victorious. The satisfaction of toppling a towering Thunderjaw or outsmarting a pack of robotic raptors is unmatched, making every encounter a pulse-pounding experience.

The open-world design encourages exploration, rewarding players with hidden treasures, breathtaking vistas, and lore-rich discoveries. The sense of freedom is palpable as you traverse the diverse landscapes, from snowy mountain peaks to sun-drenched deserts, each region brimming with its own challenges and wonders.

Equally impressive is the game's technological prowess. The attention to detail is staggering, from the intricacies of the robotic creatures' movements to the seamless transitions between day and night. The audio design further immerses players, with a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that complements the ambiance and intensifies the emotional beats of the narrative.

Horizon Zero Dawn is not just a game; it's a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of the medium. Guerrilla Games has raised the bar for what can be achieved in the world of gaming, delivering an experience that captivates the senses and leaves an indelible mark on the hearts of players. If there's one game that defines the pinnacle of gaming excellence, it's Horizon Zero Dawn.

Horizon Zero Dawn: Complete Edition is nothing short of a gaming masterpiece. From the captivating world-building to the engaging storytelling and stunning graphics, this game has left an indelible mark on my gaming experience.

Having completed the game on the PS4 and earned the platinum trophy, I can confidently say that Horizon Zero Dawn is one of the few titles that have absorbed so much of my time, and every moment was worth it. The initial issues that plagued its release have been addressed and fixed, allowing players to fully immerse themselves in the breathtaking landscapes and intricately woven narrative.

The Frozen Wilds expansion serves as a delightful addition, introducing new monsters and weapons that elevate the challenge for seasoned players. Beyond the increased difficulty, it also satisfyingly ties up some loose ends in the story-line, providing answers to lingering questions that had piqued my curiosity throughout the main game.

One of the game's most commendable features is its ability to leave players on the edge of their seats with a compelling cliffhanger. As a fan eagerly anticipating the release of the sequel on PS5, I'm hopeful for a PC release to continue the adventure.

In summary, Horizon Zero Dawn: Complete Edition stands tall as an exemplary single-player experience. Its seamless blend of narrative depth, stunning visuals, and captivating game play make it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast. I wholeheartedly recommend this title to anyone seeking an unforgettable journey in the world of Aloy.

Bought the game and had a TON of issues getting it running. Lots of crashes on start-up, and a really weird issue where it would sometimes get past the (unskippable and fairly long) intro cutscene only to then hang on the title screen. Verifying game files worked at first, but then it didn't. So I refunded the game.

But this came very strongly recommended to me from a few friends, so I was set on at least trying to make it work... ended up getting the GOG version and, after MUCH tinkering, managed to get it running. And it ran quite well for me. But then I was confronted with the game's other issues. 

The default control scheme is Souls-like, for some reason, which is a huge negative for me, personally. You can customize it, yes, but doing the mapping feature doesn't [i]quite[/i] work... Switching things around lead into placing "crouch" to L1, which is where the "weapon wheel" is. The weapon wheel should theoretically only appear on a button hold, as it is described with a "(hold)" indication on the mapping menu. But it doesn't work. Having "Crouch Toggle" and the "Weapon Wheel (hold)" both on L1 (which is a combination of inputs the game accepts) completely ignored the first function, no matter how quickly I tapped the button. After some much switching around I managed to place the wheel on the left d-pad, which is as cumbersome as it sounds, but at least it didn't take any important inputs away. I had come up with another, much better, solution at some point, but it required leaving one of the inputs empty, and the game refuses to do that.

Another slight but definitely present annoyance comes with Aloy only being able to climb designated surfaces. I didn't expect this to be as jarring as it is, but years of playing games with free-climbing have spoiled me on this aspect. It feels very jank to have the character able to jump 7/8th of the height of an object and that means I have to find a way to walk around it because she won't climb the remaining 1/8 as a part of an animation or whatever. And this is a game very full of things to scale up to. And yes, it feels very cinematic and pretty when their perfect animations lead you from anchor point to anchor point up a mountain. What it doesn't feel is organic... or particularly fun.

Last but definitely not least... (actually, this is my biggest gripe with the game) Horizon Zero Dawn is the most acute case of "uncanny valley" I've ever personally witnessed. The game just looks...... wrong. The bit in the intro where we get to play as child-Aloy was particularly sickening to me. Her model just looks... unnatural. The characters are constantly twitching in ways humans just don't and the changes from animation to animation in conversation can be very abrupt. It's like they tried to add a ton of subtlety and variety to the movements but there is actually too much and they don't connect naturally? It made me super uncomfortable to the point where I started to actually avoid dialogue. Which is a bit of a shame because I've been told that the story in this game is actually pretty decent. I'll take people's word on that. I've played for 7h-ish hours and there is still no sight of a decent plot anywhere. The set up is nice, but they have so far done nothing with it.

Anyway, if you can get past these, this is actually a really good GAME. It feels very good to play for the most part. Most of the movement is intuitive and responsive (aside from my point above about climbing), the combat has good weight behind it, feels impactful and using the numerous traps and weapons to set up specific situations feels engaging and rewarding. I like being in the world, and could recommend on that merit alone. But there is a lot of stuff around it that I found very lacking and made me drop the game even after I managed to get it working. Which wasn't this version of it, so there is also that. Can't in good faith recommend this one.

Horizon Zero Dawn is created by Guerrilla Games and is set in a post-apocalyptic world where machines rule the open lands. Mankind has been reduced to tribes scattered across the world. Technology is an ancient and forbidden thing, yet we live side by side with machines that act and look like the animals of the Earth before everything went to hell.
That is one of the strong points of Horizon Zero Dawn. It sets up an intriguing story that keeps you asking questions like, what happened here? Why are there machines as animals? Where did they come from? Who created them? And so on…Even the protagonist Aloy has mysteries of her own.

You start the game off as playing a young Aloy, learning how to hunt machines and other mechanics of the game. You quickly realize that the tribe has outcasted you and your caretaker, Rost. None of the tribe members are allowed to talk or play with you. But there is a trail of sorts called “The Proving” in which if you win, even an Outcast can then become a member of the tribe. This leads into a montage of the game showing Aloy growing up and training for “The Proving”. When the day comes, you are a guest of the tribe and are able to take part in the games to prove yourself along with other youths who are coming of age. During “The Proving” the contestants are attacked and killed by a group your tribe has called “The Killers.” Being the only survivor of the attack, the tribe elders task you with finding out what happened and who these “Killers” are. It is at this point of the game where you are now allowed to explore and do as you please in Horizon Zero Dawn’s open-world.

Once you step out into the open world of Horizon Zero Dawn, you can then do as you please. Follow the main story quests, which reveals what happened to Earth, where Aloy came from, and other pressing questions that the story presents you.
Sidequests are another strength for Horizon Zero Dawn, earning you both experience and shards. You can go hunting to eventually gain access to the hunter’s lounge in the main city of Meridian, or look for Cauldrons, secret locations which produce the animal-like machines out in the world. Overriding these locations gives the ability to override more machines in the wild. The freedom is yours and there is less of the boring repetitive gameplay seen in most open world games these days.

The gameplay of Horizon Zero Dawn is fun and interesting. You can get a variety of weapons and armor. The rarer the weapon, the more ammunition types are unlocked to you. The weapons and armor have to be bought from vendors exclusively. But what can be found in the wild are the many resources used in crafting and trading. Machines and humans will drop mods, resources, and shards. Shards are the form of currency in the game to buy things and are used to craft ammo as well. While exploring the world, you can also find these ultra-rare items, which specific vendors will trade very rare items for them. So Horizon Zero Dawn has a lot for you to explore for.

When it comes to the combat in Horizon Zero Dawn, it gives you satisfaction when bringing down a machine. You quickly learn that the machines are a force to be reckoned with. Especially the bigger ones. The bigger they get, the more ammo and time it will take to bring them down. Going up against many machines is a bad idea, they will overpower you and kill you fast. So using a device you get in the beginning stages of the game called a “Focus”, can show you the weaknesses of each machine. This will help you determine what weapon to use and ammo. Some are vulnerable to fire, others too cold, and others need ammo that does damage to armor.

Jumping into a battle unprepared with the machines in the wild is suicide. Plan carefully and watch your surroundings. The other aspect of combat in Horizon Zero Dawn is the fact there is no target locking. Yup, you have to freestyle every shot, so make them count. At least the game gives you a few moments to slow down time. Skills can later extend this, but it only gives you about 3 to 5 seconds of slowed down time to make that specific shot count. As you can guess, there is experience gained while playing the game. Experience will level up Aloy, which she can then put skill points in about 30 or so skills ranging from slowing down time to making your critical hits stronger.

As beautiful, fun, and interesting as Horizon Zero Dawn is to play. The game doesn’t come without faults. At times I wish I could pull back the camera some more because I always ended up hitting things that stopped Aloy in her tracks while fighting the bigger machines. The camera angles got annoying and even caused me to die at times. Another fault I want to touch on is the human enemies. They suck and are pretty boring. I found the combat and planning my attack on the machines more interesting than dealing with the human enemies in the game. Their AI is terrible, and the sections with them in it were the least interesting. I found myself avoiding the sections where you fought humans, they just were not that exciting as the machines to fight.

Horizon Zero Dawn is one hell of a game. Even with the faults I mentioned, it was one epic journey. I enjoyed the story, the combat, and even exploring the world. I got easily distracted while making my way to the next main story mission. That to me makes an awesome open-world game. There is over 80 hours worth of gameplay here. Even if at times I got frustrated with the game, I still wanted to jump back in to see if I can find that next Cauldron or plan my attack on some machines in the wild. Horizon Zero Dawn is a must own for any open-world fans.

Final Score: 4/5 - Great Game

There are a couple of things I didn't like:

+  I feel a good portion of my playtime was likely spent cowering in the grass, hesitant to make a move. The game has swarms of enemies at every turn, which often hindered my exploration. 1 on 1, would likely be no problem, but that's not always the case as there's almost always a pack of enemies, and a variety at that. Some people really enjoy challenging content though, so it's just a me problem.

+ Inventory management was a pain. I felt like a hoarder for much of the game without really understanding what was truly important and what wasn't. I didn't spend much time looking at it, but the stat management of gear didn't seem very informative. It was hard to truly tell what was better.


Overall I would say the game was absolutely amazing. Even with the combat challenges, I thoroughly enjoyed the combat system. I loved this game, and I now look forward to Forbidden West in 2024.

[h1][b]Content[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 20/20[/b]

Its moderate length prevents fatigue, which I see as an advantage. Story completion and first playthrough take 20-30 hours, while the full game completion spans 60-80 hours. Besides the first playthrough and the new game+ opportunity to 100% the game, I wouldn't consider the game world interesting enough to keep you entertained outside the two playthroughs mentioned above.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

The gameplay is probably the most enjoyable part. Most encounters require preparation, which might be frustrating for people used to button-mashing. Tactical combat is by far the best gameplay feature of the game. As far as the interaction goes, there's nothing groundbreaking. It's the typical stuff seen in other similar games. The gameplay features: unlocking a specific area of the map, hunting grounds, collectibles, focus mode, bandit camps, skill tree progression, resource gathering, and crafting - everything you'll find in other games. There's nothing new like others told me there would be.

Some friends that played the game on the PlayStation console told me there are a lot of new gameplay mechanics they haven't seen before, which is wrong on so many levels. I haven't discovered a single thing that has not been already overused in other games, which only tells me that the people I got this intel from are either very biased or haven't played many similar games. There are a ton of objectives to complete throughout the map, but most of the less important ones are oversimplified. I jumped into this game with high expectations, expecting something I'd never seen before, which was initially disappointing. Most side quests emphasize the slow approach to prolong the playtime. Fast travel packs are thankfully a thing and are easy to obtain, which saves a lot of worthless traversals.

[h1][b]Presentation[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

I was amazed by the incredible level of detail on display. The game's world divides into distinct sections: lush regions brimming with dense foliage and swaying grass, empty wastelands dominated by endless stretches of rock, and snowy expanses where visibility is severely limited. The rendering of foliage remains tolerable while traversing the world on foot; however, the moment you jump onto a back of a machine and pick up speed, the landscape transforms into rapidly growing foliage. The audio experience is expertly crafted, with sound effects that are notably immersive. The musical score is so distinctive that even a decade from now, you'll easily be able to identify the game it belongs to.

Now, let's delve into the realm of animations. I must express my disappointment with the animation work, particularly within dialogues. Finding an appropriate term, I would describe the animation quality as unsettling. I'll refrain from being overly critical, but some characters are horrifying. I've also encountered peculiar glitches, such as Aloy's eyes seemingly expanding to an almost anime-like size and some unconventional hand and facial movements exhibited by other characters during dialogues. It's worth noting that the updates fixed some of these issues, though sporadically, a few still manifest during gameplay. On a brighter note, the character controls prove to be impeccable.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

The game's narrative left me expecting more. It began strongly, setting high hopes for what would follow. However, as the initial sequence concluded, the pace slowed, and the excitement dwindled. While not devoid of interest, the story occasionally felt flat, lacking significant developments. Remaining attentive to collectibles and data elements is essential to maintain engagement. The issue seems rooted in the unremarkable characters encountered early on. Though later characters don't fare much better, the initial ones are notably dull. The story's initial portion lacked momentum, making pursuing predictable main quests unappealing. The Frozen Wilds DLC is an expansion pack and the best part of the game that introduces new content, including a new area to explore, additional quests, and more challenges.

Predicting outcomes 10 out of 10 times reduces the excitement of uncovering what's next. About 90% of characters lack any meaning of life, often reminiscent of lifeless zombies spouting dialogue. Main quests become much more interesting later, yet frequently involve traveling from point A to B, discovering something, and returning. The journey lacks entertainment beyond stationary machines awaiting attacks. Side quests are often repetitive and offer time for exploration and collectible hunting. I regret choosing the normal difficulty, as the game isn't as challenging as anticipated. Strategic planning triumphs over impulsive encounters. Biased hype around exclusive titles lacking superiority to third-party games is questionable.

[h1][b]Technicalities[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 17/20[/b]

The game's initial release was unstable and full of issues, spanning crashes, consistent frame drops, and recurring stutters. Thankfully, Nixxes intervened and diligently addressed these performance issues later on. The current version operates smoothly, delivering a commendable gameplay experience that marks a substantial technical enhancement. The game does exert a considerable demand on PC hardware. Nevertheless, a comprehensive array of PC-specific settings facilitates adaptable performance across varying hardware. Playing the game on an Intel Core i7-10700K, RTX 2080 Ti, 64GB DDR4 RAM, Samsung EVO 970 Plus NVMe 1TB SSD resulted in a stable framerate above 80 FPS most of the time at 1440p maxed out preset.

[h1][b]Final Verdict[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 82/100[/b]

Horizon Zero Dawn is not just a game; it's a journey into a breathtaking world filled with awe-inspiring landscapes, intricate storytelling, and adrenaline-pumping action. Clocking in at 118 hours, every moment spent in this post-apocalyptic masterpiece felt like a revelation.

From the very beginning, Aloy's character drew me in with her determination and wit. The narrative weaves a tale of mystery, uncovering the secrets of a world dominated by robotic beasts. The storytelling is so compelling that I found myself emotionally invested in every twist and turn.

The open-world design is nothing short of phenomenal. Roaming through lush forests, vast deserts, and snowy peaks is a visual feast. The attention to detail in the robotic creatures is remarkable; each encounter feels like a strategic dance, keeping me on the edge of my seat.

The combat system is both challenging and rewarding. Aloy's agility and a diverse array of weapons make every battle a unique experience. The ability to override and control the robotic creatures adds an extra layer of strategy, turning them into powerful allies.

Beyond the action, the game encourages exploration. Discovering hidden caves, ancient ruins, and solving environmental puzzles adds depth to the gameplay. The world feels alive with a rich history waiting to be uncovered.

In terms of technical aspects, the PC port on Steam is exceptionally well-done. The visuals are stunning, and the optimization ensures smooth gameplay even on high settings. The attention to detail in bringing this console gem to PC is evident, and it greatly enhances the overall experience.

Horizon Zero Dawn isn't just a game I played; it's an experience I lived. Guerrilla Games has crafted a masterpiece that sets the bar high for open-world adventures. If you haven't embarked on Aloy's journey yet, do yourself a favor and dive into this world of wonder, danger, and discovery.

1.	Story
Story is one of the strongest aspects of the game. Guerrilla Games has done a great job. It is gripping, well-written... it is just an amazing experience. This game has everything that a good single-player story game needs to have: strong emotional moments, unexpected plot twists, relatable characters, and so on. Personaly I really enjoyed story.
The story begins with a little girl named Aloy and a man called Rost. Rost is Aloy‘s father, and both of them live as outcasts in the wilderness of the Sacred Lands. That‘s because Rost's tribe, called Nora, outcasted them, and they are forced to live outside the tribe. However, Aloy wants to know why, so she is looking for the answers. She decides to go to the Nora to look for the them. However, she is an outcast, so no one will talk with her. But there is a way for her to get the answers, and it’s a trial called Proving. When she succeeds, she will become part of the tribe and get all of the answers she seeks. I am not going to continue because I don‘t want to spoil anything. Don't worry, this is just the very beginning of the game's story.
2.	Quests
Quests are really nice; I enjoyed doing most of them. Some of side quests even had their own story, just like in the Witcher games. Sometimes even 2 or 3 side quests were following the same story. This is something that I loved when I was playing Horizon.When I was doing side quests, I didn’t feel any kind of repetition or something like that. It seemed to me that every quest had something to offer. Main quests are mostly about exploring and getting to know the story, but they are not only about this, and they also possess quite a lot of combat. Speaking of combat...
3.	Combat
Combat in Horizon is excellent. There are plenty of possible ways to fight. You can be a sneaky bastard, killing everyone quietly like a shadow, or you can be the biggest badass and start shooting at everything that moves. To be honest, the stealth approach is much more successful than the badass one. Because it may be tricky to kill enemies face to face, especially if there are many of them and not just one enemy.
What I really like about Horizon’s combat is that it involves an element of strategy. You need to think before you start fighting. You have many options to choose from. There are many types of guns, traps and also you have a huge advantage, you can override machines. This will help you in combat. What is more every machine has its unique weak point that you can find and use it to your advantage. Every machine except the fucking Sawtooth. I wasn't able to exploit any weaknesses on this son of a bitch. Horizon is an RPG, so upgrading Aloy is a necessary part of this game that must not be forgotten. Aloy can be upgraded not only by buying new gear and leveling up, but you can also unlock new skills with skill points. You will earn one skill point after each level up and after completing certain quests. They are divided into three different sections in the regular game, and if you purchase the DLC 'The Frozen Wilds,' you will receive an additional section of skills. 
4.	Game World
Horizon is an open-world game. The world is huge and filled with various activities, from destroying bandit camps to finding collectibles and taking down machines. I recommend doing all activities because they will reward you with huge amount of xp and resources. I don't think I've ever played a game that rewards exploration and collectible finding as much as Horizon does. Here's what I mean: when you collect a required amount of specific collectibles, you can take them to a merchant interested in buying them, and he will trade them for some useful items. This trade might not provide you with extremely over-powered weapons or an enourmous ammount of resources, but it can be helpful. What's also great is that you don't need to search for these collectibles randomly. You can purchase a map from a merchant, and once you buy it, all the collectible locations will automatically appear on your map, making it easier to aim for a 100% completion run.
Like in every open-world game the map is hidden. To uncover it you can find tallnecks, machines that are harmless unless you are an idiot and go right under their legs. Ahem ahem ahem, don't ask me how I know this, thanks. When you climb a tallneck, you can override it, and the entire region will be revealed. But reaching the tallneck might be challenging because they are often surrounded by various types of enemies. However, with enough patience and a tactical approach, you can reach the tallneck without engaging in combat.
5.	Graphics, audio, optimization, bugs
To be completely honest with you, the graphical aspect of Horizon Zero Dawn looks amazing. Textures are sharp, and everything looks great. This level of quality can also be attributed to the audio and optimization. Game runs smoothly, and I rarely experienced any FPS drops or similar issues. The game is perfectly optimized, and the developers have clearly put a lot of effort into it. As for bugs, I haven't encountered many. The most common issue was that some creatures occasionally yeeted from the ground after being killed, but this only happened a few times. 
6.	My opinion about this game, my statistics
So, I believe I've expressed my opinion throughout this review, but to summarize, this game is fantastic. I believe this game is still up to date. Graphics look amazing, gameplay is rewarding and tactical, game world is not empty, exploring is well designed...I believe that Horizon Zero Dawn is one of the best AAA game of this genre. This review might make seem Horizon like a flawless game without mistakes, but it's not. There are some minor problems. One of the most significant problem is the facial expressions of the characters. Sometimes they didn't look very natural, and they didn't appear very real. Given that Horizon features a lot of dialogues and various characters, this aspect can ruin the overall experience a little bit. Another thing that bothered me was the main quest line, not the quests themselves but the travel involved. Let me to explain. Horizon's map is huge and at times, it felt like one quest sent me to one location while another sent me to the other side of the map. This left me surprised  and sometimes annoyed, but it isn’t a major issue. It’s only annoying.
Overall, I enjoyed this game, and I would recommend it to anyone seeking a single-player game with a good story and combat. I’ve spent 59.3 hours on the first run and achieved nearly a 100% completion so it tells something about the quality of Horizon. I would rate this game 10/10. Those mistakes are merely minor on this title, and they don't ruin the overall experience a lot. So this game is definitely still relevant and definitely shouldn’t be forgotten. It holds its own even among popular and new games like Elden Ring and even now it has something to show.

Teh world of Horizon Zero Dawn is nothing short of magnificent. Imagine standing on the edge of a dense, emerald forest, with sunlight filtering through the leaves, creating a mesmerizing play of shadows. Or picture yourself traversing the scorching deserts, where every grain of sand glistens under the blazing sun. These landscapes are not just backgrounds; they are living, breathing works of art that make exploration a joy.

Horizon Zero Dawn is more than just a game; it's an immersive adventure that takes you on a visually stunning and thrilling ride through a meticulously crafted world. From awe-inspiring locations and jaw-dropping graphics to heart-pounding encounters with colossal machines, ths game has left an incredible mark on my gaming experience.

The game's entertainment value is off the charts. The story is a rollercoaster of emotions, flled with unexpected twists and memorable characters. Aloy, the game's fearless protagonist, is a character you'll become deeply attached to. Engaging in combat is a thrill in itself. You'll employ stealth, master archery, and devise clever strategies as you face off against a diverse aray of mechanical giants. Whether you're stalking machines through tall gras or engaging in intense battles, every moment is a pulse-pounding experience.

Imagine the adrenaline rush as you confront colossal machines. The towering Thunderjaw, armed to the teeth, or the elusive Stalker (which I HATE), blending seamlessly into its surroundings. Each machine is a visual spectacle in its own right, and defeating them requires skill and strategy. The satisfaction of taking down one of these mechanical titans and salvaging their components for crafting is a visceral experience that's hard to match.

In my opinion, this game is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of gaming. Its breathtaking world, stunning graphics, captivating storry, and thrilling battles against giant machines combine to create an unforgettable experience. If you're looking for a game that not only immerses you in a stunning world & also provides hours of incredible entertainment, Horizon Zero Dawn is an absolute must-play. It's not just a game; it's an adventure you'll cherish for a long time to come. Like me.

After over 200 hours, 3 total playthours (One of them 100% completion) and all achievements, I thought this game has not just earned a recommendation but a review with it.

Positive:
-The graphics are still pretty good, especially for its age.
-The lore is incredibly good and continues the story of life on earth in a realistic and well imaginable way.
-The gameplay is good and keeps you entertained for many hours.
-The weapon and combat system is easy to use and understand. However it takes time to master.
-Long playtime, especially if you do all the things the game has to offer.
-Very good DLC.
-Great character design with well fitting personalities.
-Well thought out world design with high attention to details.
-In total 79 achievements, many of them are earned throughout the story.
-Lots of collectibles and additional narrative in both audio and text form.
-Very stable engine, can´t remember it crashing even once.

Neutral:
-The game has no auto save feature outside of quests, so you have to save the game manually at campfires.
-A few side quests feel a bit repetitive
-The photo mode´s orbital camera is hard to control and when doing so has a mind of its own and the area where the camera can be positioned is quite small.
-Facial animations feel a bit old (The DLC is pretty good however).
-No ray tracing support.

Conclusion:
Everyone looking for a new story based single player game, I recommend you try this one out.

The stereo mix is completely broken on this PC port.
- You can't hear dialog unless you're looking straight at the person talking; simply turning the camera away mutes the track.
- The character's steps can be heard only from the one speaker she's closer to, basically no sound on the other speaker.
- Often you hear loud sounds from locations that are behind large objects, like buildings or rock ridges, that overpower anything that happens right next to you.

There are no in-game controls for the speaker configuration, it's opaque which kid of audio setup the game assumes.


The game's auto-exposure also has trouble setting  a sensible brightness at night or in dark enclosed areas.
Especially in Cauldrons the picture often turns pitch black even without bright lights in view that might explain why the game lowered the overall brightness.
Outside a single bright rock somewhere in view can turn the rest of the picture black as well.

These two combined make this an unpleasant experience. I don't recall these issues from the PS4 version.

I was really excited to own this on PC, never played the PlayStation version but I've watched a lot of videos showcasing gameplay etc. so I know what the game is about. So far the game has lived up to my expectations, but sadly my enjoyment has been lowered due to the crashes. Yes, I haven't escaped from suffering game crashes, just like so many others, though I consider myself somewhat luckier than many others because my game only crashes every 60-90 minutes. Despite that I'm still enjoying the game and Guerrilla Games ARE working on patches to fix the crashes so hopefully it won't be too long until they finally get all the fixes in place and the game crashes become a thing of the past!

I'm sure there are some who will read this and wonder why I'm recommending this game. That's because I'm looking past the crashes and just focusing on the actual game itself. As such, it's a really nice, fun game, the game world looks very nice, gameplay is pretty good and fairly solid. You can see just why this game has been so popular amongst the PlayStation crowd ever since it was released a little over 3 years ago.

Yes, some may want to wait a little longer before buying, thereby giving Guerrilla more time to nail down more crash fixes etc. Right now it's certainly a gamble: you might be one of the really lucky ones who don't get a single crash; or you might be one of the really unlucky ones who crash every 5 minutes; or you could be one of those who can't even get the game to run; or you could be like me and just get a crash every so often! So that's the gamble. Then again, you could just wait a few weeks to see how things go. After all, many PC gamers have been waiting for 3 years to play this one, what's waiting a few more weeks gonna hurt? ;)

Make your choice, buy now or wait a few weeks. But either way, this one is a must buy at some point! :)

Edit on 27 Nov, 2020: So, it's been a few months since I first wrote this review and I figured I should add a little bit of an update on how things are going. Guerrilla Games have now released eight patches (plus a hotfix for patch 1.08) so far in their efforts to address issues. Obviously I can only comment on my own experience so others may have a different opinion. I'm happy to say that the patches have helped to reduce the number of crashes I was getting. I'm now at a point where I can play for hours at a time, sadly not completely crash free yet, but now a crash is much more of a rarity, I've gone from multiple crashes every time I tried to play to an occasional crash a coupe times a week!

I'm on 400+ hours played, completed New Game+ Ultra Hard and I've obtained all of the achievements. I'm loving the whole game: the story; the graphics; the music; the characters and of course the gameplay. Much fun and enjoyment can be had here, but, like so many things, it's not for everyone.

[h1]Great game, but the port does have it's flaws[/h1]
I'm one of the nerds that wasted a lot of time playing (and getting a platinum trophy) on the PS4 version of this game, and absolutely loving the game. By far one of the best RPG titles out there! There are definite cons and pros like any game, but the cons are more about the core of what makes RPG games the way they are, and why i play very few of them.

[h3]Pros:[/h3]
-Very captivating story which does a pretty solid job fleshing out and keeps interesting throughout the game.
-Combat is pretty well balanced though your addiction to dodging will be the key to surviving at least 75% of battles.
-Aesthetically, a masterpiece of a game, though it being the first huge title for a company like Guerrilla since the Killzone series (which I never was as invested in and never were as big as the Horizon series has been.) and the first in the series it definitely feels a bit lackluster/disjointed in the talking sections as the characters sometimes have unnatural movement (NPC classic moments) or the lip movement doesn't match the tone/volume of some of the lines they say. Not uncommon for the first in a series to have those issues. Those things aside the beauty of the game is incredible and it feels huge and exciting once you get going [spoiler](mostly after you leave the Embrace)[/spoiler].
-Big array of weapons, equipment, outfits, machines ect. It left me feeling like there was always something to do and much to explore. At times it was overwhelming, but as you get more familiar and understand the curve of the difficulty as you play on everything tends to work out as what you primarily will fight with and wear during certain encounters.
-Much to do and explore and it kept me coming back as most side quests were usually beneficial and relatively unique, but no game is immune from repetition [b]ESPECIALLY[/b] in an RPG title lol.

[h3]Cons:[/h3] (there maybe some spoilers but i'll try and keep it as ambiguous as i can and censor most spoilers)
-The endless running. it makes sense with such an open environment that you need to flesh out as much as possible and being a true RPG the game is going to be just massive, but if you're ok with sometimes just running 3 miles because you don't have any [spoiler]fast travel packs[/spoiler] and you somehow missed that pack of striders running amok. It sometimes feels like a drag, but it's part of the game play.
-This being a port it will have it's glitches from time to time, and i had a game breaking glitch initially where if i looted something too quickly it would either freeze momentarily or drop down to so slow for 20-30 seconds that it was less than a frame every 3 seconds. Then it would freeze to the point that it permanently ran at like 1/10th FPS which also slowed my PC to that speed until i restarted my whole laptop. I found a fix which resulted in me going to the properties tab in the game and turning off [i]full screen optimizations[/i] which has fixed the issue, buuuut it was an issue i was having. Also some textures take a crap in certain cut-scenes which is jarring, and sometimes funny at times.
-Slow progression at times. Just RPG stuff I'm not always a fan of, but I will say some of the upgrades are worth the work to acquire.

There's more i could elaborate on, but those are some of my pros and cons I have about this game. The cons are more about the issues of the port as those issues were never something i experienced with the PS4 version of the game.

[u]Should you buy this game at full price:[/u] I initially did for the PS4 and didn't regret it, but as for this version I'd say wait for a sale as I did. There's just enough issues that [b]SHOULDN'T[/b] be issues, and mostly with it being a port it takes away from the high price take of $50 still. This being said a friend of mine hasn't had a single game breaking issue so your experience may vary from mine.

Do with this info what you will. Have a nice day!

[h1] First impression (11hours in)  [/h1]

25 Euros on sale for this?! That's a bargain!, Well worth it's full price aswell. Very few games that have me hooked for hours at a time. 

If you like Sci-fi this, this is absolutely a no brainer to get. intriguing story, Well filled open world that doesn't feel like a lot of nothing between the action, and Side quests that kept me from progressing the main story for hours (that's a good thing). 

No bugs or issues so far, runs great.


[h1] Finished Main game + DLC around 84hours  [/h1]


So i did most of the things this game and dlc had to offer, the story had me hooked all the way through this game, and the story had me reading through every bit of text i came across, which in games, I don't normaly bother with.
The collectibles in this game add value to the game it's self, with gear and usable items + actual interesting lore attached to them, collectibles done right, if i'd say so myself. 

Game mechanics: Works more or less flawlessly all the way throughout. The one thing that i'll complain about is getting out of water in some instances can be a bit wonky, but there are so few times, i'd let that slide. 

Final words: I love how this game manage to be a medieval and a sci-fi game in one go!

If you want the quick version, this game is good. Real good. And if your considering buying it, buy it. Boom, you're done. However, if you're curious of the ways I found it to be a very good game, I've listed some important positives below.


COMBAT: an admirable part of the game. The combat system Isn't overly complicated to the point of confusing, but Isn't too simple to the point of being redundant and boring. The skill ceiling is a good height, and starting out, the combat isn't necessarily glaring. You just shoot machine with arrow until it stop moving. Luckily, the devs expanded on this and provided many different avenues and play-styles for dealing with bots. While I feel there could of been more done, the system works and fits well into the world they made.

IMMERSION: Most games have some sort of introduction that takes you through combat techniques and other small features. They'll have the instructor tell you "press E to pick up the sword" or "use your menu to craft new weapons"  and while helpful, it shatters any immersion you had built in the world. Why would these people be telling my to press E? Oh. Right. They're not people, they're NPCs, and this is a game. In Horizon, its clear that immersion is a top priority. While there is an introduction, it flows smoothly into the main game and does a seamless job at giving expedition and providing basic knowledge on combat. The great part is, I didn't even know there was a skill tree until a few hours into the game, because they didn't shove it down my throat. I cant imagine Rost going "Here's your skill tree, this is where you can learn important moves." While people may not appreciate this approach, it worked surprisingly well.

STORY: The most impressive part of this game I would say is its story-line. Compelling, in-depth, and creative are very good descriptors. While slightly predictable at times, this story truly does take the interesting concept it has and makes it shine. It keeps you wanting to discover more and kept me hooked all the way through. It gives you all you want from a story-line and more. The game never forces you to watch hours of boring mindless dialog, it instead presents questions that you can ask npcs if you would want to know more. Each cutscene is Important and interesting, I didn't skip a cutscene or a forced dialog a single time.


While there is much much more positive things I could say (replayability, map design, game-play loop) I feel these are the three most important positives that I picked up during my playthroughs of Horizon. I hope you try the game out yourself too.

I bought HZD while it was on sale. Played it for three, in reality roughly one and a half hours, before I wanted to have it refunded. Steam support declined my request, citing my three hours of playtime. So, I told myself, well, **** the poor performance and the very annoying start, maybe it gets better.

Yeah, it got better. Performance still sucked extremely, which I find rather surprising, considering that my specs are above the requirements. But the story slowly unfolded. Some side missions were rather poorly designed, but others actually were quite great. The main story also slowly got better and better, and the many small snippets of info you get by using the focus to scan your environment also helped to enrich the story.

Combat against the robots was also nice, nostalgic perhaps, as I really love the combat in Monster Hunter and this felt somewhat familiar.

However, the combat against human enemies is extremely awful. You can either turn your enemies into a porcupine or they die after one good hit, against the head. Yet, the movement of human enemies is sometimes extremely erratic, making it hard to hit them without slowing down time. Furthermore, sometimes there are simply too many enemies that just throw themselves at you. This is just annoying. And it feels like the good old moment in Skyrim when you stumble into a bandit encounter after having killed Alduin with just your fists or a wooden sword.

Pal, I killed half of the known robot population, managed to kill your friends, and you still continue to fight? If all humans had willpower like that, Operation Enduring Victory would have never ended... 

I really would have loved to have some sort of mechanic that introduced some sort of surrender-flee mechanic for human enemies. I hope that the sequel has such an mechanic. Otherwise they should just remove human combat, it sucks.

Lastly, the graphics are also decent, at least one my settings. No idea how it looks on low settings. Performance, however, as I already stated, sometimes sucks. I randomly have stutters, CPU-loud goes to 100% and the game just idk uses my PC to run a focus network or whatever.

All in all, HZD is a nice game, I rarely had bugs, and with exception of the performance, most aspects are good or far above average.
