**Embarking on the captivating journey that is Horizon Zero Dawn feels like stepping into an extraordinary action RPG with a third-person perspective.** Guided by the formidable huntress Aloy, players navigate a post-apocalyptic world teeming with robotic creatures, immersing themselves in a gaming experience that goes beyond the ordinary.

**The narrative of Horizon Zero Dawn unfolds within a meticulously crafted and expansive universe,** enveloping players in a spellbinding story that rivals the immersive quality of top-tier RPGs. Aloy's journey isn't merely a quest; it's an exploration of a world brimming with diverse characters, each contributing to the rich tapestry of this unique universe.

**The exploration aspect of Horizon Zero Dawn is nothing short of breathtaking,** echoing the prowess seen in other renowned titles. Every nook and cranny of this open world invites discovery, concealing hidden stories and untold mysteries that enrich the overall experience. The attention to detail is so exquisite that reality seems to dissolve, leaving players fully engrossed in the game's mesmerizing landscapes.

**In a narrative landscape painted with shades of gray, Horizon Zero Dawn navigates the complexities of morality much like real life.** Characters grapple with intricate motivations and moral choices, mirroring the nuanced decisions we face every day.

**Graphically, Horizon Zero Dawn stands as a testament to the capabilities of modern gaming graphics.** The world isn't merely visually stunning; it resonates emotionally. Facial animations convey a depth of expression, adding authenticity to character interactions. Dialogues become more than exchanges of words; they transform into a visual and emotional symphony.

**Elevating the overall gaming experience is the enchanting soundtrack by the talented composer Joris de Man.** The music seamlessly weaves into the narrative, enhancing the emotional resonance of Aloy's journey and the world she inhabits.

**The musical enchantment of Horizon Zero Dawn is truly magical and awe-inspiring.** Joris de Man's composition transcends the realm of mere background music, becoming a symphony that elevates the entire gaming experience to unparalleled heights.

**Each note in the soundtrack is a brushstroke on the canvas of an immersive narrative.** Whether it's the haunting melodies echoing through desolate landscapes, the tension-building beats during intense encounters, or the poignant tunes underscoring pivotal narrative points, every piece feels purposeful and evocative. The soundtrack becomes a character in itself, shaping the tone and ambiance of the game, enriching the storytelling experience.

**In the grand tapestry of gaming soundtracks, Horizon Zero Dawn's musical composition stands as a masterpiece.** It's not just background noise; it's a magical force that enhances the overall experience, making the game not only a visual spectacle but a symphony for the senses. **The soundtrack of Horizon Zero Dawn is nothing short of extraordinary, leaving an indelible mark and ensuring that the magic of the game resonates in the hearts of players.** <3 :)

This is gonna be a kinda long review but this game definitely deserves it.

First of all, the storytelling is one of my favorites in all the open-world games I played so far. The fact you just get thrown into this world with ruins of a lost civilization, not knowing what happened makes it so intriguing to find out more. I had so much fun with the whole storyline and most sidequests are great too. Furthermore, the graphic is still fantastic and can easily hold up with many recently released triple-A titles. 

But what stands out to me in this game are the gameplay elements. There are a lot of different machines to fight, and you can obtain various weapons to do so. In the beginning, big machines, like thunder jaws can be overwhelming because you do not have many weapons and don´t how to approach them. But the more you progress and the more you fight them the more you realize how easy they are with the right strategy. Every machine has different weak spots and finding the right way to target these is the key to winning the fight. Being able to shoot off parts from these machines which reveal these weak spots or shoot off enemies’ weapons to use against them, is something I have never really seen in another game before.

The progress system is pretty balanced as well. I always found enough resources on the way and inventory space is sufficient. Furthermore, the number of level-ups you get is fair as well and by the end of the game, you will probably be able to afford most of the abilities. And I got to say: Sliding under a machine to shoot its weak spot with 3 strong arrows while in slow motion and killing it in the process is probably the most badass thing I ever did in a video game.

There are two types of gamers: Power-gamers and role-play-gamers. 

Power-gamers look for the optimal build, don't actually give a shit about the story, are just looking for something to make them feel good about their miserable, pathetic lives. This is why pseudo-combat-simulators appeal to such people. They are losers in rl, so they use games to make them feel like they are bigger and better than they ever have any hope of being in rl.

Role-play-gamers are looking to play a character, like a character-actor. They are there for the story, graphics, and ambiance. They are not looking for a combat simulator. They want to stay true to their character. They are there to experience an adventure, not waste their time trying to figure-out how to get through one shitty battle after the other, because they are unwilling to optimize everything.

I LOVED the cyber aspects of this game, and the marriage between the more primitive setting and the technological aspects. However, this game hasn't decided what it wants to be. 

Are you trying to appeal to RPG gamers? If so, you failed.
Are you trying to attract power-gamers? If so, you succeeded.

It makes me sad, because I was totally into this game, until the combat went full-force. Then, I just asked for my money back. I couldn't remember which key did what or what, how, when, why with all the pseudo-combat crap. Decide what you intend to be, then go with that, but you cannot be both.

Pretty dang good.  I'm not normally much of a fan of AAA games but it takes a lot of the typical mechanics of such games and uses them to better effect than most AAA games do.  It feels like what Witcher 3 should have been, decking out your character with gear specialized for the creature you want to fight and coming up with a strategy to defeat it is actually fun and interesting and takes thought, instead of a linear walkthrough that the game handholds you through, which takes hours and ends in a 3 minute battle.

The battles are difficult enough that it overcomes the problem of wanting to hoard all of your single use items forever, while resources are just scarce enough that it gives you some interesting decision making about how much you really need to burn and what is going to be most effective in whatever situation you're in.  Leveling feels right, where things that were deathly scary get noticeably easier and easier, but that mostly just comes from learning the game better and getting new abilities and tools, and it never gets to a point where you can just tank things without concern.  It makes better use of the open world too, not as much "ignore everything but the quest marker" gameplay (though still some).

I think a good example of how it takes a tired mechanic and elevates it is the use of weakpoints.  They're less just about damage and more about status effects, and tend to be harder to get to, can take multiple shots to take effect, and can have potentially bad consequences if you don't plan right.  Maybe blowing out the fuel canisters to get a DOT is a good idea, but maybe you don't want to deal with a flaming dinosaur charging at you, maybe you want to take out it's ranged attack and deal with it somewhere it can't get to you, maybe you want to take advantage of the fact that it stuns easier, maybe it's a larger heard and you do want to get that chain of explosions going and try to hide and let them burn themselves out.  What's going to work and not is going to change a lot based on your abilities and tools and terrain and the number of enemies and whether it's one or multiple types of enemies.

**Embarking on the captivating journey that is Horizon Zero Dawn feels like stepping into an extraordinary action RPG with a third-person perspective.** Guided by the formidable huntress Aloy, players navigate a post-apocalyptic world teeming with robotic creatures, immersing themselves in a gaming experience that goes beyond the ordinary.

**The narrative of Horizon Zero Dawn unfolds within a meticulously crafted and expansive universe,** enveloping players in a spellbinding story that rivals the immersive quality of top-tier RPGs. Aloy's journey isn't merely a quest; it's an exploration of a world brimming with diverse characters, each contributing to the rich tapestry of this unique universe.

**The exploration aspect of Horizon Zero Dawn is nothing short of breathtaking,** echoing the prowess seen in other renowned titles. Every nook and cranny of this open world invites discovery, concealing hidden stories and untold mysteries that enrich the overall experience. The attention to detail is so exquisite that reality seems to dissolve, leaving players fully engrossed in the game's mesmerizing landscapes.

**In a narrative landscape painted with shades of gray, Horizon Zero Dawn navigates the complexities of morality much like real life.** Characters grapple with intricate motivations and moral choices, mirroring the nuanced decisions we face every day.

**Graphically, Horizon Zero Dawn stands as a testament to the capabilities of modern gaming graphics.** The world isn't merely visually stunning; it resonates emotionally. Facial animations convey a depth of expression, adding authenticity to character interactions. Dialogues become more than exchanges of words; they transform into a visual and emotional symphony.

**Elevating the overall gaming experience is the enchanting soundtrack by the talented composer Joris de Man.** The music seamlessly weaves into the narrative, enhancing the emotional resonance of Aloy's journey and the world she inhabits.

**The musical enchantment of Horizon Zero Dawn is truly magical and awe-inspiring.** Joris de Man's composition transcends the realm of mere background music, becoming a symphony that elevates the entire gaming experience to unparalleled heights.

**Each note in the soundtrack is a brushstroke on the canvas of an immersive narrative.** Whether it's the haunting melodies echoing through desolate landscapes, the tension-building beats during intense encounters, or the poignant tunes underscoring pivotal narrative points, every piece feels purposeful and evocative. The soundtrack becomes a character in itself, shaping the tone and ambiance of the game, enriching the storytelling experience.

**In the grand tapestry of gaming soundtracks, Horizon Zero Dawn's musical composition stands as a masterpiece.** It's not just background noise; it's a magical force that enhances the overall experience, making the game not only a visual spectacle but a symphony for the senses. **The soundtrack of Horizon Zero Dawn is nothing short of extraordinary, leaving an indelible mark and ensuring that the magic of the game resonates in the hearts of players.** <3 :)

At first, the world-building looks promising, you wonder what happened to the world. However even if some questions are answered some don't make any sense and only are there for the sake of the gameplay, even if it's immersion-breaking.

The graphics are... gorgeous, nothing negative here.

The bottom line is, buy it on sale, play 10 hours at most and uninstall. Which sadly, seems to be the new way of making action-adventure games nowadays.

The graphics and story were well done. There is some grind that can be annoying  (getting animal talismans rather than blue grade animal parts for one) needed to upgrade carry capacities and unlock some purchases from merchants, but most of what you need for ammo you get just looting machine kills. I felt lower difficulty (even story mode) seemed to work well for feeling rewarding on using the right attack on most machines as it still didn't hit hard if not attacking a vulnerability, but could sometimes kill in a charged longbow hit if done right.

It's a great game, if you like ubisoft-like open world stealth action games with crafting and collectables. The only things that stood out to me are lore of the world and pretty fun robot fights (but they do get boring). Story is fine, stealth is there, exploration is pretty fun, lore is interesting (and would be a lot more interesting if most of it wasn't in arbitrarily placed text logs), and a curious lack of puzzles.
Annoyingly, it still does the thing where it tries to portray realism, but then randomly f**ks up while also making gameplay worse. Example - bonfires for saving, it kinda makes sense, but is hella annoying when you can't save where you want. Another is ammo pouches/quivers - kinda makes sense, but is made almost redundant by the fact that you can quick craft arrows in the middle of combat, and make 20+ arrows in the time it takes you to draw the bow... Yeah, the only reason i see them existing is just that you would have to hunt random animals to upgrade them, wasting time. BS.

Few other points - crashes and controls.
For me at least, i could hardly launch the game at first without it getting stuck or crashing on me. An hour of looking up guides and changing random stuff, and now it was bearable, but still crashed randomly. 30h in i got to a place where it would always crash, 2 more hours or trying to fix it, reinstalling game, drivers, stuff, and finally no more crashes, no idea what exactly fixed it. The game has been out for 3 years on steam, wtf.

The controls are a mess too. Even until finishing the game and dlc i did not use dodgeroll because of how awkward and stupid it was, had to change sprint to manual from toggle, because it just toggled off if you did almost anything, and scroll wheel was completely useless because tab for weapon wheel was way better, heavy spear attack also took like 20h of getting used to, because the run and heavy attack have the same combo button, and half the time i would start sprinting into the enemy instead of hitting it.
Best part is, some keys are rebindable, while some aren't, some are combined and cant be uncombined, or cant change into specific keys... Wanted to use scroll wheel to scroll through consumables, nope, have to use a button to do it one at the time. Ugh.

So yeah, if you like ubisoft style sandbox games, you gonna like this too, but if not, dont expect too much more from it. I had my fun with it, because i rarely play this type of game and dont have the open world fatigue, but i would still only recommend it to be played on console, 3 hours of troubleshooting is way more than i would like, and the controls are probably better with a controller. Also, if you play on pc, for your own sanity put this game on an SSD if you have one, literally cut the loading times by 7x (1min 45s to 15s).

[h1] An Unbeatable World and Extraordinary Gameplay [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2]



Horizon Zero Dawn is undoubtedly one of the best open RPGs in recent years, and it has taken the leap onto the Steam platform with great success. As a long-time console gamer, I was ecstatic to finally experience Aloy's thrilling adventures on my PC, and I must say, it exceeded all my expectations.

The Complete Edition not only includes the original game but also comes packed with the Frozen Wilds expansion, adding even more depth to an already engrossing storyline. The first thing that struck me was the breathtaking graphics. The PC release takes full advantage of the enhanced capabilities, allowing for crisp details and stunning landscapes that immerse you in the post-apocalyptic world of the game.

From the very beginning, the narrative captivated me. The story unveils itself layer by layer, gradually revealing the truth behind the enigmatic past. Playing as Aloy, a strong and resilient protagonist, I found myself invested in her journey and committed to discovering the secrets of the ruins that scattered the world.

One aspect that sets Horizon Zero Dawn apart from other games is its combat system. The battles feel exhilarating and dynamic, thanks to the variety of weapons and tools at your disposal. The fluidity of Aloy's movements and the strategic element required to take down towering robotic beasts is simply unparalleled. Each encounter, whether against massive Thunderjaws or agile Stalkers, provides a thrilling and rewarding challenge.

Moreover, the inclusion of skill trees allows you to tailor Aloy's abilities to your playstyle. Whether you prefer stealth or brute force, the game offers ample flexibility to experiment and customize your character's approach to combat and exploration.

The Frozen Wilds expansion, while not altering the core gameplay significantly, does introduce a new, snowy region with its own set of challenges and quests. It seamlessly integrates with the main story and adds additional hours of content, making the Complete Edition well worth the investment.

The optimization of this PC port is fantastic, offering a wide range of graphical settings to suit various hardware specifications. On my mid-range system, I was able to enjoy smooth gameplay without any noticeable performance issues.

As for the technical aspects, I encountered no crashes or major bugs during my playthrough. The developers have done a commendable job in bringing this console-exclusive gem to PC, ensuring a seamless and enjoyable experience for players.

In conclusion, Horizon Zero Dawn Complete Edition on Steam is an absolute must-play for fans of action RPGs. Its immersive world, gripping storyline, and outstanding combat mechanics make it a standout title in the genre. From the remarkable graphics to the smooth gameplay performance, it's evident that this port was crafted with care and attention to detail. Dive into Aloy's post-apocalyptic adventure and prepare to be utterly captivated by this masterpiece.

The good:
[list]
[*]Scenery so beautifully picturesque it makes you want to experience it firsthand. 
[*]A fascinating post-apocalyptic story with plenty of background lore to slowly piece together through detective work and exploration, which I love. 
[*]Very cool and imaginative machine designs.  
[*]Fun combat that encourages creative use of weapons and methods of engagement. I was generally drawn towards the predictably reliable "stealth archer" approach, but there are situations when that isn't the most effective strategy. 
[*]Just about every skill on the tree is actually useful, which is kind of rare. 
[/list]
The meh:
[list]
[*]The side characters (other than Nil) aren't particularly memorable.
[*]The final battles aren't particularly challenging or interesting. 
[*]The enemy target focus tends be fixed on the player even when getting help from friendly machines or NPCs. 
[*]The hunter bow is redundant, especially later in the game. The tearblast arrow is clearly better than its hardpoint counterpart, and harvest arrows are pretty much pointless. A snapshot bow with fire arrows would have been the preferred option.
[*]Combat balancing in the DLC area isn't great. The tougher enemies - namely Scorchers - are so aggressive and resilient that brute forcing myself through fights using explosives ended up being the most viable strategy.
[/list]

Well, gotta say I'm surprised.

I approached this expecting a "Sony interactive movie" because of how much this game has been memed to be more in tune with GoW rather than being a gateway into Monster Hunter. 

If this was supposed to be interesting because of its story and characters, in my opinion it failed miserably.
 
The setting can basically be described as Rise of the Machines meets Jurassic Park on a post-apocalyptic reborn earth, where humans live in tribes and fight each other while hunting big dino-robots.

But the story is not bad because of the setting, which is pretty good actually, its bad because they just made it non interesting. Really, is just boring. 

And the fact that a good portion of the background events that led to the world being in the present state is told to you through f*cking AUDIO LOGS and DATA PADS is just icing on the cake to make it even less interesting. 

I reaaaally hate the use of audio logs to tell a story. I can cope with it if its an indie or a walking simulator, maybe its good for some horror games too, but only if its purpose is to get you acquainted to SOME of the story/background.

Not to tell half of what's going on and what happened before... That's just lazy, and also very badly implemented in this game. 

Why? Because if you're going to leave audio logs scattered around every single main story mission location, you might as well make Aloy shut up a little and don't let her interrupt the audio every single time...

I'm listening to something interesting for a change, only for Aloy to make a remark about something in the environment and then the audio cuts off... 

Forcing me to pause the game and go to the menu, search through tons of other logs to find the one I was listening, and then play it again from the beginning, hoping she doesn't interrupt it again this time.

That's dumb, I stopped listening to audios and reading data pads halfway through the game unless they were critical to the story. Otherwise it gets tiresome, I just scan them and move away, not like I'm missing on much anyway...

Also, the characters play a crucial role in making a story to be engaging, and there's not a single memorable character in this game. Not a single one. 

Sylens might be the less bland and boring of the main characters, and there was also a pretty funny guy from a side quest, I think his name is Gildun. Those are literally the only two characters I remember....

The rest of them are generic brown tribesmen (seriously they're all brown, was there something wrong with the color palette?) looking for an errand girl to send on a fetch quest.

Side quests are given by characters who are supposed to have a bit more depth than your average town NPC but are still bland and will also send you on the same generic quest over and over.

Go to X, investigate scene with your focus, follow tracks. Rinse and repeat. That's what almost 90% of quests are about, and it sucks.

What about Aloy? Completely forgettable, one of the most boring protagonists that I can remember, she only looks good, and that's about it.

I don't see who would play this because of the story and I've seen people praising it as if it was something marvelous. To each his own, I guess. 

Now what's really good about this game tho, that's the gameplay. 

Setting out for a hunt, scouting an area, scanning the robots to learn their weaknesses, laying traps and preparing your loadout, then finally facing them in thrilling, intense fights, is so satisfying and fun to do, especially when you go after big boys like Fireclaws and Thunderjaws. 

There's a lot of weapons, traps, and outfits at your disposal for every type of playstyle and situation and the game does a good job encouraging you to try everything, making the combat very dynamic. 

You won't be using the same weapons and outfits all the time, unless you want to at hard time with the toughest enemies. Although that was on very hard, which is the difficulty I played on, I'm sure on lower difficulties this will be way more forgiving.

Overriding a Thunderjaw and just watching this giant apex predator wreak havoc demolishing absolutely anything that crosses its path, is some of the most fun and satisfactory moments you can presence here.

I recommend to visit Cauldrons as early in the game as possible to get more machine override options and make them fight by your side. Is worth it just for how fun it is to watch them.

Now about the technical aspects. It looks wonderful, not exaggerating, this might be one of the best looking games I've ever played. I can't believe the PS4 was able to run this at a playable frame rate. 

But PC is what we care about and here it runs smooth as butter. Not a single frame rate drop in almost 100 hours played. Never crashed, no stuttering, short loading times, almost unnoticeable LOD pop in. Its technically impressive.

There's plenty of graphic options to choose from, customizable FOV, 144hz support, good amount of AA techniques... I don't think there's any major feature missing. Just about everything you expect a solid PC port should have is present here.

tl;dr Nice game despite the story being a bit underwhelming and a bad quest design structure. More gameplay heavy than I expected it, almost like a Monster Hunter "lite" of sorts. Looks very good, runs smooth, and has quite a satisfying combat system.

Horizon Zero Dawn is a worthwhile, often brilliant game that is also a wonderful demonstrator of some of the worst commonalities of game design and Sony's recent "style" of games.

pros:
-absolutely stunning, still one of the best looking games out there, easily, and also runs steady 60 fps at 4K with all settings maxed on a middling system (Ryzen 5 2600x, RX 6700XT, 32 GBs GDDR4).
-great gameplay. A bow and arrow is always a good gameplay weapon, but Aloy can acquire trap casters, elemental launchers, etc, as well as use her spear to take on enemies. Enemies are stacked with components to knock off for bigger damage and crafting uses, and a basic but effective skill points system adds to your skillset throughout the game.

mids:
-the story is very intriguing, but some flat characters and a lack of meaningful worldbuilding hampers it some.
-the world is good looking but nebulous. Having grown up in between Colorado Springs and Denver and near the Rocky Mountains, where most of the game takes place, i can say it A, looks very little like the actual Rockies and B, is simply too small to be a semi realistic depiction of Colorado and Utah, and yet too big to be fun to walk/ride everywhere. Utah and East of the Rockies is much more accurate looking though.
-Towers are boring but at least they move.

Cons:
-Aloy talks a bit too much. It's not as big an issue as the sequel, but it can get annoying, despite Ashly Burch doing fantastic work.
-detection percolates too far too fast. getting discovered in a bandit base means everyone knows where you are within seconds.
-combat against humans is inconsistent and often unfun due to a lack of damage indication, you'll often find yourself dying because arrows fly and theres only a little red vignette to indicate low health, beyond the heath bar.
-world is devoid of activity. Aloy literally cannot do anything but kill. open world games need what i would call distractions; back in the GTA San Andreas days, they had clothes to buy, gyms to get buff at or learn new melee moves at, fast food places to get fat at, haircuts and tattoos, dates to go on, races and gambling to do, etc. whether is for immersion or just to have something else to do, open world games of today have completely forgotten about that. when im tired of killing machines or humans, what is there to keep me in the game?

I wanted to play Horizon because I saw a trailer of a woman shooting arrows at robots and thought it looked insanely cool. It was. I loved this game.

I expected it to be very action-focused (like Darksiders for example), so I was suprised to see it had more RPG elements with like crafting and skills selection. Pleasantly surprised, mind you.

Still, let's start with the robot-shooting : it is as satisfying as you'd expect, there are lots of different ways you can go at it, and combat feels really cool and dynamic. I think stealth is maybe too good an option to choose something else, but you are free to experiment as you like, and with different weapons too.

As for the robots themselves, their designs are unique and cool and I loved seeing all the different kinds and how they worked. I was delighted every time I saw a new one. And, something that blew me away with their designs is : sometimes, you see a big one and your first thought truly is "wow, I want to fight that". It had never happened to me before and I think it adds to the cool factor.

The environments were varied, wide, and beautiful. You always want to explore, it feels good to find new places and admire the view. It also felt new and exciting to go from somewhere like a hut in the snowy woods and end up in a giant futuristic robot factory hidden in a mountain. Stumbling on these futuristic ruins without warning added something special to the world, you really felt like you were discovering a whole civilisation.

You also meet a lot of characters with different personalities, attitudes, and prejudices. They react differently to Aloy, making the interactions feel more real. I was also extremely impressed by how real the characters looked (I think they're modeled after real people ?), and how well the lips movements matched their speech. It's a tiny detail, but every time I thought "damn, that's neat".

The story started in a fairly standard way about a young woman wanting to prove herself, then it goes in a lot of unexpected directions. I loved uncovering information little by little, and through Aloy's story discover more about the world. The blending of worldbuilding and character development was really well done.

One negative point I have to talk about is the fact that a lot of lore is found through written logs. There are LOTS of them. And they're NOT short. And while I usually LOVE lorebooks and the like, Horizon is not the appropriate game to have to player just READ things. It's about adventure, exploration and environmental storytelling. So I basically ignored the logs, which is a shame.

But there is a lot more positive than negative, and I definitely recommend Horizon, it was a great experience full of wonder and epicness !

The beginning is a bit slow. But the meat of the game is extremely rewarding. Not only is the combat very well executed (and tweakable if you aren't feeling very hard-core, the story mode works pretty well! And there's harder modes that keep others entertained fairly well too) but the real reason this game just lives on in my head as a wonderful time is how the story unfolds. Maybe not so much in terms of characters, which is pretty surprising, as Aloy stays more or less the same person with a lot of sass and a bit of a chip on her shoulder -- but in terms of the story *telling*. You get to see the lore of the game unfold in such a neat way as you progress from spot to spot in a natural and well-paced way, and see the history of the world and how it came to be, well, [post-]apocalyptic. There are some really cool reveals, which make a bit impact, which is extra interesting because most of the reveals aren't really about you, they are about the past, but still make an emotional impact. And again, along the way, slow mo jumping and sliding arrow shots shooting off specific parts of robot dinos is just so satisfying. There are incredible visuals all over from the natural scenes to the human settlements to the underground tech dungeon-like places to the decaying ruins of humanity to the revitalized parts reclaimed by nature. You can tell a lot of love went into the game in all its aspects. So please, do yourself a favor and stick with it through the early hours because this game has a stellar reputation for a reason.

After 50h of Playtime and 100%ing the game my Review:

Graphics/performance:
The game looks and runs great, I had no bugs or glitches, and only one crash. You have to be lucky to see the beautiful stuff though because I feel, its either night or raining all the time ;P.
I could max out everything on a 3070 and had no frame drops at all, I haven't checked the fps, but it felt smooth.
When you skip cutscenes, Aloys hair jumps around a lot, but I only did this once after I accidentaly was mean to Rost and reloaded the save, normally I don't skip cutscenes ;). Also sometimes in cutscenes some textures were flickering, but thats it.

Gameplay:
What I loved is that it seemed like using certain dialog choices (Aloy despite the Nora) or doing certain sidequests changed the dialog in the main story. Alsos it seemed like main story also had custom dialog for situations, where you entered locations earlier than expected.Or if you already completed some sidequests before, I really liked that, the story feels more connected.

Combat is fun and very fleshed out, there are many different unique weapons and ways to use them. You can either use machines to fight for you, use brute force and just blast enemies with bolts or shockwaves, or be stealthy, use silent strikes or different arrow-types to use the weeakspot of enemies against them. All of that is explained neatly with optional tutorial quests and hunter trial, that you can easily skip if you want.

Side quests are mostly: Kill A, follow Tracks at B, Fetch me item C or talk to D, but I didn't get bored. There are also bunkers/cauldrons to explore and some puzzles, the puzzles are extremely trivial though.

Can feel a bit video gamy at some times, why do I only have a chance to get an animal skin, did that one arrow destroy the whole thing? Also NPCs feel a bit NPC like, just standing around in cutscenes (which is way better in the DLC). Also climbing is very videogame like, you climb, whereever there are yellow ledges, and nowhere else.

Story:
The story is very interesting to follow and really hooks you, its generally well made.

------------------ DLC -----------------------
Same level of quality as the main game, brings new unique Weapons and Enemies. Story was very interesting to follow and answers many questions from the main game as well as advances the story in general.
Also, NPCs and Aloy are Motion Captured in Cutscenes now, which greatly improves the quality.
New areas look great, but in some areas I had some very low frames this time, mostly in the cauldron with many lights, not sure if this was because Raytracing, if there is raytracing in a PlayStation Game.

Stunning Visuals: The game boasts breathtakingly beautiful open-world environments, filled with lush forests, snowy mountains, and intricate machinery.

Engaging Storyline: The game's narrative is compelling and thought-provoking, with a rich backstory that keeps players invested throughout.

Unique Setting: Horizon Zero Dawn presents a post-apocalyptic world where robotic creatures roam, offering a refreshing take on the genre.

Aloy, a Strong Protagonist: The main character, Aloy, is a well-developed and likable character with a strong personality and motivation.

Emotional Depth: The game successfully explores themes of identity, family, and technology's impact on society, providing emotional depth to the story.

Character Development: Aloy's character development throughout the game is both noticeable and satisfying.

Well-Written Dialogue: The dialogues and interactions between characters are well-crafted, adding depth to the world and its inhabitants.

Voice Acting: The voice acting is top-notch, contributing to the immersive experience of the game.

Open-World Exploration: The game offers a vast and diverse open world that encourages exploration with hidden secrets, collectibles, and varied landscapes.

Dynamic Day-Night Cycle and Weather: The dynamic environmental changes add realism and complexity to the gameplay.

Challenging Combat: The combat system is engaging and requires strategy, with various weapons, tools, and tactics at your disposal.

Robotic Creatures: The robotic creatures are a unique and fascinating part of the game, each with its own behaviors and weaknesses.

Crafting and Upgrades: You can gather resources and craft items, enhancing your weapons, armor, and abilities.

Stealth Mechanics: The game allows for stealthy approaches to combat, giving players different options for how to engage enemies.

Machine Overrides: Aloy can hack and ride robotic creatures, adding a layer of depth to the gameplay.

Skill Tree: The skill tree system offers customization and progression, allowing you to tailor Aloy's abilities to your preferred playstyle.

Photo Mode: The game's built-in photo mode allows you to capture and share the stunning world you explore.

Music and Soundtrack: The game's music and sound design add to the overall atmosphere and immersion.

Side Quests and World Building: Numerous side quests offer additional lore and depth to the game's world.

Expansion Packs: "The Frozen Wilds" DLC expands the game with a new region, storyline, and challenges.

Replay Value: The game has substantial replay value, with multiple difficulty settings and a New Game+ mode.

Technical Achievement: The game's technical prowess showcases the power of the PlayStation 4 and later the PlayStation 5.

Critical Acclaim: It received numerous awards and nominations, cementing its status as a must-play title.

Cultural and Gender Diversity: The game features diverse characters and representation, including strong female characters.

Fan Community: There is an active and passionate fan community for sharing experiences and tips.

Sequel Potential: With the success of the first game, a sequel, "Horizon Forbidden West," continues Aloy's story, expanding the universe and gameplay.

Overall, "Horizon Zero Dawn" is a must-play game for its immersive world, compelling narrative, and well-designed gameplay. It's an experience that offers countless hours of entertainment and is highly recommended to gamers of all kinds.

I've seen people scoff at the comparison, but Horizon Zero Dawn has a lot in common with later Assassin's Creed entries. If you're no fan of those, you [i]probably[/i] won't like this game either - at least from a pure gameplay perspective.

[b]However[/b]; I found the world building, stories and quests are a lot more fleshed out here. The main campaign is great, the map is efficient, and although there's grinding to be had, it's negligible. If you do run out of resources, it's never far away.

Also, having played both the PS4 version and now PC - bow hunting with KB/M and the precision it gives, is the far superior way to play the game. It almost made the game trivial, even on the hardest difficulty.

The only MINOR negative things I'd have to say about this game are that riding and melee combat feel a bit clunky at times, however since in 99,9% of cases a more calculated approach is way better AND more fun than trying to smack them with a stick, it barely makes a difference at all. 

The story is BEYOND AMAZING, beautiful graphics, authentic characters, the best combat I have ever experienced in a single player game, a rewarding progression system and an open world that's fun to explore and fight in!

The combat system offers a ton of skill expression and rewards experience and practice. There's huge variety when it comes to types of enemies you will fight and each of them have immense depth. 

The more you fight a certain type of enemy, the better you get at fighting them as you find out what weapons work against them and which don't, their attack patterns (helps you dodge) and their weak spots. And MAN does that feel rewarding, being able to outmaneuver and kill a type of opponent that seemed intimidating and close to invincible the first few times. 

This also motivates me (and many others from what I've read) to re-play the game at max difficulty at some point to put that experience to use and challenge myself. 

Crafting allows you to tinker around with all different kinds of modifications to tune your weapons (and outfits/armor!) exactly the way you need them for YOUR playstyle. 

If you're here for the (absolutely amazing) story and less interested in learning the deep combat mechanics of this game, there's a "story" setting that eases combat so you can fully focus on the narrative. 

Spoiler-free recommendation: Throughout the (open!) world of Horizon Zero Dawn, you will find „Data Logs“, little snippets of information in various forms.  Listen to them or read them! They are never directly required to complete a quest, but they add soooo much depth to the story that they will leave you googling theories after you‘re done playing for the day.

Oh, where to begin? I guess with a TLDR: This game is exceptional, it is worth playing and I think most gamers would agree with me. 

Now to the details! This game is a joy to behold, from the wonderful crafted ecosystems that feel real to the haunting and yet still beautiful soundtrack... Horizon: Zero Dawn does not disappoint. As you step into this world, an ice cold stream on one side and a field filled with swaying grass and deadly machines on the other, I hope you will be as captivated as I am. 

On the subject of those machines, they are equal parts awe inspiring and terrifying. Each has unique mechanics that make them all a very real threat, they force the player to adapt to the fight at hand or get squashed. They also all make sense, each filling a niche in the ecosystem and each playing a vital role in the new Earths future. 

Sure, there are some issues. The performance on PC isn't great if you don't have a very powerful PC and there are aspects of the game that are REALLY buggy. There's also a brutal difficulty curve if you want to 100% it as I have. But through these issues the core gameplay still shines for me. 

At the end of the day, is this game for everyone? Probably not. Is it worth everyone trying it at least once? YES. There's something here for most gamers. 10/10.

So I recently found out this game came to PC and decided to try it out because I heard a lot of positive news about this game.

But to be honest with regards to gameplay I'm on the fence. I am not a major fan of the combat as all your doing is dodging while trying to do damage (mostly with the bow). In my opinion this makes the game very tedious to play. Stealth is also pretty easy and I've played against smarter AI.

Music is okay but nothing noteworthy in my opinion especially compared to games with amazing OSTs like Mass Effect or Subnautica.

The best part of the game is the main storyline but I felt the prologue was done very poorly as it didn't draw me in a well as games like Mass Effect, Jedi Fallen Order, Spider-man or Assassins Creed game do. I think its a combination of poorly written introduction to the characters and the tedious gameplay.  To be honest I was even thinking of quitting early on and just refund the game. It was only because my mate told me to keep playing because it gets better that I didn't refund it.

Side story don't really contribute much to the world building and are just boring tasks of do this or do that. The few side quests with storylines that do exist seem to wrap up real quick. The collectables are a joke with most of them being random message talking about random stuff. And the rare collectables only seem to give you metal shards in return once you collected them. Which was useless because by the time I found all of em I already had like 10000 metal shards or something.

However I have to admit that is game is made really well with decent graphics, weather effects that have a effect on gameplay. And in my time in the game so far I have only found like 2-3 minors bugs but nothing game breaking so its pretty wel made. It also works with no issues on my PC unlike a few other games that recently came out (looking at you Spider-man remastered and Jedi Survivor).

Overall I would rate this game a 6/10 (maybe even a 7/10 taken into account how well it performance).

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Horizon Zero Dawn is a unique and awe-inspiring adventure that I've invested 15.2 hours in, and it's a game that transcends the boundaries of traditional open-world action RPGs. It's a stunning amalgamation of primal and futuristic, nature and technology, and above all, a masterful narrative that keeps you entranced.

In this post-apocalyptic world, nature has reclaimed the earth, and colossal mechanical beasts known as "Machines" roam freely. You step into the shoes of Aloy, a determined and resourceful hunter seeking answers to the mysteries of this world and her own origin. The game's narrative is rich and emotionally charged, slowly unveiling the secrets of the past as you journey through stunning landscapes.

What sets Horizon Zero Dawn apart is its remarkable world-building. The mix of lush forests, vast deserts, and ruined cities creates a breathtaking backdrop for exploration. The attention to detail in both the environmental design and the intricately crafted Machines makes this world feel like a living, breathing entity. The day-night cycle, weather patterns, and dynamic lighting add further depth to the experience.

Gameplay in Horizon Zero Dawn is a unique blend of hunting, combat, and strategy. Aloy's agility and precision in using her bow and various tools to dismantle or override the Machines is both thrilling and tactically engaging. The sheer variety of Machines, each with its own strengths and weaknesses, encourages strategic thinking, ensuring that encounters are consistently engaging.

One of the standout features of the game is the "Focus," a high-tech device that allows Aloy to analyze her surroundings, track enemy paths, and gather information. This device not only enhances the gameplay but also strengthens the connection between the player and the world, encouraging exploration and uncovering the game's rich lore.

The game's audio design deserves special mention, from the immersive sounds of the Machines to the enchanting musical score. The voice acting is superb, with Aloy's character brought to life with depth and authenticity.

Horizon Zero Dawn offers more than just a captivating main story. The game's side quests and additional content contribute to a sense of agency and exploration. The lore found in data logs and ancient relics paints a vivid picture of the world's past and adds layers of depth to the narrative.

With 15.2 hours invested, you're likely to have only scratched the surface of what Horizon Zero Dawn has to offer. The game's extensive world, narrative, and optional content can easily double or triple your playtime, making it an excellent value for the avid explorer.

In conclusion, Horizon Zero Dawn is a remarkable work of art in the realm of open-world gaming. It seamlessly blends a unique world, exceptional storytelling, and thrilling gameplay into an unforgettable experience. It's a game that transcends its genre, offering players a chance to lose themselves in a world where ancient mysteries and futuristic technology collide. If you value immersive storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and dynamic gameplay, Horizon Zero Dawn is a must-play, and it's a journey that you won't want to end.

It hits all the boxes for game enjoyment, and delivers a very unique experience.

Pros:
- Dynamic and Engaging story. Very creative, apocalyptic, and thrilling.
- Very satisfying combat system. With a variety of weapons and tools that gives you freedom to approach combat differently. With the right approach, you can control any fight you are thrown into.
- Amazing visuals. Very soothing and eye catching environments.
- Very interesting concepts. A post-apocalyptic, futuristic, cyber, tribal, primal, and medieval mix merged together very nicely.
- Well-structured missions. Map and mission design is on-point, providing a dynamic experience with enough freedom to keep everything interesting. 
- Excellently written main character. Alloy (the main protagonist) is by far one of the most proficiently built character I have seen in modern gaming. She is also brilliantly voice acted. 
- Sylens. He's a very interesting character. Lance Reddick did an amazing job with this one. 

Cons:
- Loading times. They can be a pain sometimes.
- Limited parkour. You can sometimes feel obstructed by the terrain, and limited to few areas to climb. 
- Too much knock back effects. Some are unnecessary and can feel annoying sometimes. 
- Uninteresting characters. Some (not all) characters are not well written and voice acted. Some are extremely annoying and you can end up skipping their entire conversations. 
- Although the game has a diverse array of weapon and armour, it could had still used a bit more, as you can remain stuck with a few weapons for a very long time. 

*** Overall, and exceptional game worthy of your time and money.

Look man. I just REALLY like stealth games and I love shooter games even more (especially bow and arrow based ones). This game is near perfect for me. The graphics, character and outfit design, world-building, quests, etc. are all VERY well done. 

I only have a few gripes with this game. First and foremost is that you need save frequently bc this game crashes pretty often. The other is that the controls are a bit clunky sometimes, and it can cause Aloy to miss jumps or run into things when you're trying to evade a machine. 

But my biggest issue, which is honestly infuriating, is the enemy AI. 
You'll hit a machine in one spot, and then run to another spot so you can get a vantage point when they run to your original location, but the AI just, goes to your new location automatically even though it absolutely did not see you move spots. It also has some other strange location issues. One such being if you alert an enemy into search mode from a specific point (even if the enemy can get to that spot no problem) the AI will just go to the middle of its spawn area and wait for you to move to another hiding place before literally bee-lining for you, even though it didn't see you again. 
In other words, the AI sometimes just interacts horribly when you're trying to stealth, which is strange since a massive part of this game is literally stealth hunting.

Horizon Zero Dawn is a visually stunning masterpiece. The gameplay is nothing short of beautiful, with good looking landscapes and funny machines. However, I do wish the quests had more depth and nuance. Additionally, the repetitive looting can make a sweaty gamer burned out. Nonetheless, it's an absolute blast to play, thanks to its compelling narrative and exhilarating combat, making it a must-play for any open-world gaming enthusiast.

This game was a mixed bag for me. Also probable spoilers ahead!

The machine combat mostly works well, the human combat is... unsatisfying. Human enemies are split into 2 types, first type takes 1-2 arrows to defeat and flinches easily. Second type never flinches and will ponderously walk towards you and hit fairly hard. The human boss fights were disappointing and not well fleshed out.

The world is pretty large and broken up by impassable mountain ranges as is standard for open world games. Machines roam a bit in the land and you'll run across other humans on occasion. The exploring side of the game didn't altogether appeal to me after spending many hours going around special spots marked on the map.

For a significant period of time I didn't have much care for the characters, Most of the prologue characters weren't a presence afterwards and for those that were (Teersa, Erend, Olin), I wasn't a fan of those people and couldn't get invested in their stories. However once the main story progresses some way through, my interest was restored and I'll talk about that later.

Now onto the main positives of the games.

Voice acting is excellent in the game, most characters feel appropriately voiced and you can feel it most strongly from the audio recordings later in the game. Some recordings earlier are there merely to showcase the old world that existed before and aren't overly interesting, but later on I couldn't wait to hear these recordings and how the stories of these characters was unfolding.

Finally the story, it starts well enough but goes very flat for many hours (depending on how much time you spend exploring or doing side quests) and I struggled to find motivation for a while to push on with the game. Eventually though when some of the mysteries began to unravel about the world, I became much more invested than before and got back to enjoying the game. The "lore" was told extremely well and I could care about what happened to those characters.

Overall I'd recommend the game, if the combat exploration becomes a drag, consider dropping it to story mode and just experience that part.

Where do I begin? The first thing that comes to mind is the setting. Although the market is saturated with post-apocalyptic video games, Horizon manages to turn such a cliché setting into something innovative. Let's see, the plot is not a literary masterpiece, but it keeps you intrigued. 

The interesting part here is the world, one devastated by wars, and in a desperate attempt to preserve what might remain, they ended up pronouncing the final verdict. Now the planet is inhabited by "primitive" tribes, and the wild fauna consists not only of animals but also of machines—those machines left behind in the attempt to safeguard life on the planet. I don't want to reveal much more to avoid spoilers, but in that regard, it's worth it.

The gameplay is typical of open-world settings, featuring a not-so-charismatic but adorable and innocent female protagonist. The controls are agile and swift, providing a dynamic experience. At certain points in the plot, we can even choose between various dialogue options, although they don't carry much weight in the long-term experience.

The combat, which I believe is the most important pillar, is a lot of fun, and if played on higher difficulties, it becomes a fairly intense challenge. In these situations, we'll need to devise strategies and closely study the enemy's movements in detail to overcome them. Not to mention when facing multiple enemies on your own – that's where the real difficulty kicks in.

As for the technical aspect, there are quite a few drawbacks here. While the game looks beautiful and boasts a top-notch artistic direction, especially in enemy designs, the PC optimization is absolutely terrible. In my personal experience, I had to scour the internet for hours to find a way to make the game run decently on a modest system that met the recommended requirements for a smooth 1080p experience. Issues included textures not loading, poor memory optimization, glitches and bugs, crashes, and minor visual anomalies.

But, beyond all the issues, once I managed to get the game running as it should, having tinkered not only with the settings of the software itself but also with the GPU and operating system, it's a more than recommendable experience, just for the setting, the combat, and the overall experience. My final score is a 7/10. I eagerly await the second part!

Based on a playthrough on the easiest difficulty (Story): do get this right now and enjoy the world and lore, at least for the main quest and the expansion "main side quest".

Aloy is awesome, the world is beautiful, and the story will entertain you. For those who are not as inclined to enjoying just lore and art, combat and exploration in this game is fun as well, though on the easiest difficulty it might get a bit boring at times as the enemies pose no huge threat.

The Frozen Wilds expansion is also fun and provides nice supporting lore for the main game as well, though the game should maybe make it a tad more obvious that you're probably supposed to visit the addon locations well before finishing the main quest to finish the game bit more smoothly story-wise. As a spoiler: [spoiler]after you finish the Grave-Hoard main quest segment, that spot is a very smooth transition into visiting the expansion world which is literally next to the Grave-Hoard entrance, as long as you've leveled up enough at that point.[/spoiler]

The game is big, but luckily not too big as to become a boring side-quest-grindfest, which is something many other open-world games suffer from.

Next up for me: NG+ on Ultra Hard. You know, to balance out the easy playthrough of Story difficulty and to get my ass handed to me. Aloy and I need to be put in our place this time, after being Matrix Neo -style badasses the first time.

Note: this PC Complete Edition version is the first time I'm playing this game. The PC port worked very well and I did not witness any game breaking bugs. The UIs and controls are maybe a little console-y in some ways, but that was not an issue for me at least, once I managed to find a keyboard layout that worked for me.

I just finished the game tonight and it's the most enjoyable game I've played in two decades.

Gorgeous graphics and artwork. The flowing hair and grass are beautiful. The color palette is bright and pleasant.

The gameplay is approachable but challenging. It's open world and kind of a blend between an action game and RPG. There were times I thought I'd never be able to kill these things, and then over time figured out how through strategy, leveling, and skill choices.

There are many stories in this game since it's open world and the side and main quests weave many threads as well as some independent journies. They have some hokey bits but kept surprising me with depth. You're mostly fighting rouge AI machines, with some occasional human battles. The approach they took allows most of your hunting to feel guilt free, since these machines are messing stuff up and shouldn't be here. Kill em! Nice and clean and no misgivings you might get about killing living things. But, as a post-apocalyptic world with lots of lost and untold history, there is no shortage of mystery and nuance in the stories themselves.

The writing and gorgeous setting are really the highlights of this game. I'm glad the developers included "Story" difficulty for folks who just want to explore those aspects, making the fights super easy if you prefer. I like the challenge and gameplay enough to keep it on Normal, but having the option is nice.

This game runs great on linux. Locked to 60fp at 4K on a Radeon 6650XT with Quality FSR. Has been a flawless experience for me. Not a single crash or issue.

Horizon Zero Dawn is absolutely spectacular and one of my all time favourite games. The moment you start playing your breath gets taken away by the scenery- the graphics are gorgeous and you can tell there was a lot of thought put into the environment details. Aloy is a very compelling MC and the story itself is well done. My favourite parts of the game are the open world exploration and combat; there's so much attention to detail in the story elements and lore and you can definitely tell when you explore, like when you find a rusted swing set in some ruins. Combat is very well done; it's a really nice change of pace to have a MC whose main weapon is meant to be long distance and not melee, and very satisfying when you target a Watcher from dozens of paces away and hit it square in the eye. However, it's pretty obvious this game was intended for Playstation and not PC from the layout of certain things, like the tools menu. I personally don't really like how the tools menu was done for PC use and it's a bit of a pain. The save mechanisms in game aren't my favourite either- I don't like just being able to save at campfires or major points- but those are really my major complaints at least so far. I had to review this game before I finished though because it's just... brilliant. Everything about it is thoughtfully designed and beautiful, and you'll never want to stop playing. Also, you get to ride machine horses, and there are machine dinosaurs. Even just for the machine dinosaurs it's worth it.

[h1] Far better than expected [/h1]
I didn't have high hopes - just another committee designed safe, balanced and unsurprising game, right? Let's buy it off a sale and regret later. Fortunately, Zero Dawn proved me wrong. Not without flaws, but with several very strong points. The biggest winning points come from a good balance of characters, a sufficiently complex and multi-tiered plot and game play mechanics with just the right balance of complexity and simplicity. The basics could be learned quickly, but mastering them would take time. 

Delving into the main and side plots bit by bit offered a very pleasing, though heavy and dark story line, offered in nice servings. Every time you had a question answered, two better questions came up. The boss fights were good old fashioned boss fights, where the mechanics were the same as before, just with more challenge at once. It felt like all the work you put into practicing paid off. Finishing tough situations felt rewarding, all the way to the end. Yet even after knowing all the tricks, you'd move carefully in the open and choose your fights. Even with a high level, you could get into trouble. This provided good realism.

As a player with somewhat limited hand mobility, I found Zero Dawn to be a bit on the difficult side. A steady hand will take you far, as you can't really hack and slash your way through very well. The variety of difficulty levels does scale nicely, though for some players with certain limitations, even the easier levels will offer unwanted challenges. It's by far not as bad as with several other games, but I would kindly suggest the developers to put some more effort into this. As for accessibility, I will applaud them for a good subtitle system and generally a helpful UI.

The downsides include several graphics glitches that tend to make especially close quarters fighting unnecessarily difficult. Graphics were generally okay, nothing to write home about but nothing to call bad either. Climbing mechanics let me down more than once, from both bugs and just bad design. Pushing left would make Aloy jump right, choosing to drop down carefully made her fall to hear death, and sometimes just finding where to jump to was infuriating. Too often planning had to be replaced with luck. Also, the audio side, dialogue, effects and music were rather lukewarm, not really trying too hard.

[b]In summary[/b] my expectations were very low and my surprise was quite happy. Expect a good amount of time spent, an intriguing plot and mostly well designed game play. 

The DLC wasn't quite as good. It was very heavy on puzzles, which were fun at first, but then they were taken to [b]WAY[/b] excessive amounts of just repeating and increasing the same old trick. It was playable, but clearly made with far less consideration than the main game. As with the main game, the plot and characters were the best parts, but this time game play wasn't as well tuned. The additional weapon options did bring some spice into the main game.

HZD has a few small problems like it won't save your item selection and defaults back to "Whistle" upon loading.
But overall I enjoyed HZD and the story enough to play a second Game+ play through.

It's hard to even name the game's weaknesses. It is excellent from all sides and looks perfect in 2023. Wonderful views. Best environmental storytelling I have ever seen! You try to find all the clues to understand what happened to the world and humanity.

IMO the story carries this game. It's pretty good. The voice acting can be inconsistent, wooden at times especially with minor characters, but wanting to know about the central mystery of the game and how it ends is what kept me playing.

The gameplay is alright. Sometimes the combat is really fun, but other times frustrating. I think the worst part about the core game design is its resource management. Gathering materials is very tedious, and having to constantly pause mid-combat to craft ammo totally breaks immersion and excitement. There's a lot of evidence that they want you to approach encounters carefully and with adequate preparation, but didn't completely commit to that. You're left with mid-combat pauses while you menu around and craft ammo because well darn, you ran out while dumping 30 arrows into a robot. You can definitely roleplay or artificially restrict yourself to not doing that, but it pains me to see that they spent all this time assembling the bones of a tight prep-based stealth action predator-style combat system and ultimately didn't stick with it.

I think the open world, though beautiful, doesn't really add much to the experience. I'm extremely tired of open world games and I spent the majority of this game figuring out how to get to the next main quest as quickly as possible. 

The movement in the game feels kind of wooden so I never found the act of just moving through this big-ass world satisfying. You can feel that underneath the pretty animations, you are just moving a 3D coordinate through space in the game engine in a stilted fashion. They just didn't blend it enough to make it feel seamless. I'm not expecting something on the level of MGS V, but when you are spending most of your time wandering around the game world it is hard not to notice. The worst thing that came to mind while playing is that I felt flashes of how it felt controlling a character in WoW. They say this game was instantly dated on release when BotW came out that same week - I think this rings most true when you go from playing a game with that much freedom of movement to this.

If I had to come up with one sentence that would describe Horizon Zero Dawn it propably sound like this:

"If you hadnt tell me the name of the Developer Studio behind, id mistaken it for a standard modern Ubisoft Title with actual good writting."

Prior to its release on PC HZD was one of Sony PS exclusive titles i didnt care about. Yeah at the time of its initial release it looked beautfull and intersting. But i tied myself to the PC and never had the money to buy a consle and didnt i consider to buy one. I like PC more than Console. But i was suprised to see this game on Steam one day. At the time of my purchase I was in the middle of my Red Dead Redemption 2 Playthrough and I made this kinda promise of not buying another fullpriced triple AAA title before i finished the last purchase. Sounds smart ? Well at this point I was close to 4k games and I tried everything to stop this escalated shopping spree. I beat Red Dead and I planned to start HZD. And i didnt. No real reason, I just did play other stuff. But for a very long i followed this "rule" of not buying anything full priced. Eventually i crossed the 4k line and eventually i started this game about a month or more ago after seeing enough videos to remind me what made this game intersting to me. 

So I had two bigger play session one before I left for a two week vacation and one after I got ill with covid a few weeks ago. In my first session I manged to complete the starting area and all its side quest and i got a 100% in the DLC. For the second session i finished what i started and beat it again in "speedrun" to get the missing achievements. 

Lets dive in a little deeper. For me its always important to look at the emotional side of my adventure within a game. And I wanna reflect on that. Overall id say that i enjoyed HZD. But there are some things that i dont like. You need to understand that when you look at the reception, most positives Reviews here on Steam, magazine, videos or any other form of media, this game is easily praised as a masterpiece robbed of the title Game of the Year. 

I cant see that. Not gonna lie this game has its moments. But is far from perfect.

Starting of we venture into the world as the outcast or shunned huntress Alloy. Alloy is someone I enjoy venturing on a journey. She has this tough situation that gave her the clarity and wisdom in world full of religion, spiritualism and symbolism. Knowing where she came from made her actions believable in a world where most NPC tagged hers as weird or crazy. In general this game has a good sense for world building and ecspecially its take on things like relegion, spiritualism and symbolsim. I would go so far that the game has prepared some background story that would work as its own game or even as a television series. The world I walked was world that made me wanna listen to what it has seen and its the main reason I continued and finished the game twice.

The best part of the game in general was the narrative. The game has a promising start, settings us up for so many questions and pursuing all those felt awesome. Each discovery had an impact and tieing all things together delievering the final answer was satisfying. This only counts for the main quest of the game.

The side quest where awfull. Awfull in all ways. The game chatagorizes Side Missions as Side Quest and Errands. The difference between both is that Side Quest have a little more step and Errands have about on or two. However the suffer so many problems I started to ignore what was going on with them. You find a character willing to give you a task. You then go and try to fullfill that task. Some start interesting with a stolen ware or a missing person. You find yourself following trails with your device in order to find someone stuck in the middle of knowhere or being ambushed by a bunch of machines. When found or saved they tell you that from now on they will get along alone. Quest over. No conclusion, no talk nor development for all the side characters. And yet thats not all. 
Random folks and espacially side quest givers have recyled faces. Same look, same animations they only changed stuff like hairstyle, beard or clothes. Have you any idea how dump I looked when I saw the death of a character and then had to take a side quest by someone with the same size and face. I felt betrayled. 

Another problems is kinda tied to a world building part. I dont have a problem with the world building choice. Rather with the lack of varation in how its portraied. So the world is centralised arround curtain believes. One is that men are surpirior and that curtain tribes are savages. Our luck Alloy is strong female characters that doesnt hide herself and she is from the so called savage tribe. As you might imagine a lot of conversations start with a disgusting look, some really unpleasant words and the command to go away do what ever women "should" do. 

I wanna clarify really quick. I am a white 26 year old boy from germany. I cant relate to the stress and disgrace women or person of colour have to go thru day by day. I wished it be different. So for me this was kinda of hands on experience how annoying it can be being talked down for being from a curtain tribe and curtain genders. Ofcourse this only a reflection of the real world and not be mistaken as full on experience. For this opportunity I am gratefull, however having boring characters all having the same or similiar dialog is more than just unpleasant. A lot of characters had the same personality, the same behavior and spoken line. At the end I could clearly identify those and predict their conversation. I feel that they wasted the potential here and it adds up to having boring side quests and forgetable characters. 

Another problem that kinda speaks against Alloys choice is that in the story she hesitates to help other, because she is so focused to fullfill her quest. But in the side quests she jokes that she does it for everybody. For what reason I had to be accused on listen the monolog of a friend about being selfish, if I accepted a side quest before that asked for a same or similiar thing. Side Quest felt if the where added late into the game and the had no budget to pay the writer.

I wanna briefly talk about gameplay. The game has a simple gameplay loop. It is interesting enough to keep playing but it has clear limations. While the story is well written, the special enemies and "bosses" are not. In general you find yourself running into machiens while traversing the map and they use the same machines with one exaptions as boss fights in the story. Sadly with the story we got introduced to three special enemies that are the greatest danger every discovered. However only two make an "living" appearance while the third can be seen as dead body. Its sad that we didnt got to fight atleast one. I mean they are scattered arround the world it wouldnt be that difficult storywise to bring back atleast one as the final big threat or boss. 

I still think HZD is a great experience. It feels like the average Ubisoft title with climbing towers to uncover map parts, having terribles side quest and map and world looking shiny with all the hightlighted things you could pick up. Underneath all that there is a great story with atleast a few good characters beside the incredible Alloy. The game has a fair share of moments and I cant wait to play the second part with it rumored to be released at the start of 2024 on PC. 

One last word on the DLC. It kinda can be played at anytime in the story. Canonwise for what i heard it happend before the end of the first game. I did pretty early on and I wanna say its the hardest and toughest part of the game. With me beating it early on I had a great advantage for the rest of the game which lead to fairly easy gameplay. I wont state this as an issues, i did this on purpose. I might recommend for you to do otherwise.

Horizon Zero Dawn™ Complete Edition представляет собой впечатляющее путешествие в удивительный мир, где древние племена соседствуют с могучими механическими тварями. Игра обладает невероятной красотой и детализацией, начиная от живописных природных пейзажей и заканчивая удивительно детализированными механическими существами.

Одним из главных достоинств игры является ее боевая система. Вы воплощаете роль Элой, смелой и исследовательской героини, вооруженной луком и стрелами, но главное - умением обращаться с механическими существами. Бои требуют не только ловкости, но и стратегии: вы должны обнаруживать слабые места врагов и использовать окружение в свою пользу.

Помимо боев, вас ждут захватывающие головоломки и квесты, которые требуют умения сочетать информацию, найденную в окружающем мире, и вашу смекалку для решения загадок.

Мир Horizon Zero Dawn™ оживает благодаря разнообразию его обитателей и красочным пейзажам. От жарких пустынь до снежных вершин гор, каждый уголок этого мира пропитан уникальной атмосферой. Механические твари разнообразны и захватывающе детализированы, создавая ощущение, что вы настоящий исследователь дикой природы.

Сюжет игры не оставит вас равнодушным. Он рассказывает историю о выживании, предательстве и поиске истинности в мире, полном загадок. Главная героиня, Элой, обладает сильным характером и глубокой личностью, делая вас сопереживать ей на протяжении всего путешествия.

Complete Edition включает в себя дополнение "The Frozen Wilds", расширяя мир Horizon Zero Dawn™ еще больше. Вас ждут новые задания, персонажи и увлекательные истории, добавляя еще больше глубины в уже богатый мир игры.

Horizon Zero Dawn™ Complete Edition - это не просто игра, это настоящее искусство в мире видеоигр. Ее захватывающий мир, увлекательный геймплей и глубокий сюжет делают ее обязательной для всех любителей приключений и увлекательных историй. Независимо от того, являетесь ли вы ветераном игр или новичком, Horizon Zero Dawn™ Complete Edition предоставит вам незабвенный опыт, полный эмоций и открытий.
