This marks the third time I gave HZD a chance and shelving it once more after a couple of hours. Just can't seem to get invested in anything this game offers. Maybe it does get better when you sink in a couple hours more but for me it is pretty clear that it will be more of the same for the next 10-20 hours.

Game still looks nice and I do like the overall design but the world itself seems incredibly inconsistent in every aspect. It's like the devs came up with a basic concept of how this world should look, how the map should be designed overall and how the player should progress but nothing is really fleshed out in any way. It is what it is I guess. It does make sense from the perspective of the protagonist herself and the tribes inhabiting the world because they are unable to make any sense of it, but the player is just thrown into it and most will start to wonder at one point or another. IT IS nice to run around that world but there is just not very much in it to find. Most places seem to be completely overdesigned for that matter, yes, very nice to look at, but you can run through it anyway because there is nothing of interest there.

Starting with the machines: They do look cool and all but they are EVERYWHERE and -surprise- attack any human on sight.  You will have to deal with them all the time and it gets tedious after about half an hour. The further you progress, the harder the machines will hit and soak up more damage. It is fun at first to look at your arsenal and formulate a strategy to take down a couple of them, but as you can imagine this fun does not last long because...that's right, the world is littered with enemies. I think it is part of the main story to find out why they are roaming...well the whole world but I never got that far to find out. Fortunately the game does have difficulty settings to mitigate this nuisance. I remember my last attempt at a playthrough shamefully flicking the switch on "Story mode" to just run through the world but just could not do it.

The story itself and RPG elements: Don't know. Never got that far to get really involved with the story. What I've seen was pretty uninvolving to begin with, because most players will have seen a variety of this starting scenario a dozen times already. At some points you get to choose how Aloy should react to someone which seems to be a watered down version (yeah, i know) of the Bioware Renegade/Paragon system. I don't know if there are any consequences whether you answer with violence or compassion, haven't played that long, but I doesn't seem so. It's just what Aloy says at that moment, the outcome seems to be always the same. The perks you can pick up are boring at best, most of them just leave you asking "Wait, why wouldn't I be able to do that before?" because it is mostly very basic stuff with very limited use. I guess you forget about most of them after seconds. I did. Kinda hard to imagine that your character trains 10+ years and not having thought of just ramming a big ol' spear down the guts of a machine to take it down.

Sidequests: All I have seen some kind of fetchquest or "rescue", sometimes just kill X. Can't remember any rewards to speak of, not even any meaningful conversation or getting any insights. Anything. It's just more stuff to do and often it seems like more fun to collect whatever collectibles are closest than fighting another dozen machines.

Controls: Clunky at best. Using an X-Box-controller they were intuitive enough but everything seems...off except for running straight forward. Especially the climbing parts seem implemented as an afterthought. The climbing itself is holding a button most times but be aware once you reach your destination. Can't tell how many times I fell off a ledge because everything is so darn imprecise. Only a fallen tree with yellow ropes indicating the only way to progress in front of you? AND THERE GOES ALOY FALLING TO A MISERABLE DEATH ONCE AGAIN. Haven't played an Assassin's Creed for ages, but wouldn't have had any problems doing that with Ezio or Edward. It has been done better so many times. Just infuriating.

The gameplay loop gets pretty boring for me in no time. I can't see how after leaving the tutorial-area this will change dramatically. This is all you do for the next hours, you have seen it all already. It is probably enough to keep some gamers entertained well enough, but it is just not for me. It reminds me of Dragon Age Inquisition where they literally threw a dozen versions of collectible stuff into the world with zero relevance to the plot just to pad out the game and that kind of seems to be the whole game in HZD. A collection of busy-work in an overdesigned yet unconvincing world where the player gets fed a bit of plot now and then. I'd get it on sale. It's not BAD bad, just not for me.

As Horizon: Forbidden West Complete Edition is just around the corner on PC, I figured I may as well review this game while it's still fresh in my mind.

Despite how generic the open world may feel, this game shines through its visual presentation and setting. The odd mixture of sci-fi and post-apocalyptic themes alongside Nordic tribes and beliefs shouldn't work on paper, and yet here we are. As humanity got pulled into their own demise by their own acts, it shines on through getting by using what brought them here in the first place.

While combat can be frustrating at times, nailing strong enemies and bosses down feel very rewarding. Although you may think those are just beasts that happen to look mechanical, they still bring their own spin to combats with their own weaknesses and strengths alongside specific attacks. Much like humanity in this game's lore, you will have to improvise, adapt, and overcome. While I pretty much have a pea brain when it comes to planning my gear ahead of combat, I know there is an incredible depth to it although it feels overwhelming at times. Combined to a very smooth movement system, this game handles like a charm nonetheless despite having a fairly clunky melee combat.

Where the game truly shines though is in its narrative. While it takes a while for the game to truly open up, it becomes utterly beautiful once it does. Every step that I took made me yearn for more about humanity's past and present. What are those mechanical beasts? Why are they? What is this "All mother" my tribe keeps talking about? What's behind that steel door? How did humanity bring itself to the brink of extinction and why? Who are all these people? This is something you are immediately introduced to during the game's introduction, and in hindsight it probably was the best way to do so. As you step into the unknown, the game sets you straight with the mysterious passing of an entire crew underground. From this moment on, you know something isn't right.
This whole feeling is conveyed perfectly well with the game's environmental design as mother nature took over what mankind left behind. As amusing as being referred to "The old ones" is, this adds so much character to the present events and furthers the mystery behind humanity's past. As the people fall clueless of what lied before them, we find familiar places in an otherwise inhospitable world.

It is with joy that I brought this game and its DLC to 100% completion. It isn't without its flaws, such as the rather generic open world setting. But the story behind it, the world design, intricate combat, incredible post-apocalyptic setting, and sense of mystery, made it an unforgettable experience. I can't wait to play Forbidden West and find out what happens in Aloy's next chapter.

Really disappointing. I'd love to moan and groan about all the different ways this game sucks ass, but when it comes down to it the game just falls short in a lot of ways that could've set it apart from literally any other open-world RPG. As it is, there are too many comparisons to make to games that have done this formula so much better.

To concentrate it down, there are a lot of uninteresting mechanics in this game, combat encounters are slow and grindy and resource intensive, meaning you'll have to grind more and more the higher your difficulty is to get the materials you need to grind out more difficult encounters to get the materials you need to grind out more difficult encounters to get... And on and on.

I turned it down to Easy just a little bit into the game, and then to Story, and I really think the beginning of the game is just horrible. Once you start getting the tools required to take down enemies, turning up the difficulty makes sense as you are actually equipped to take on a challenge, but the first couple hours of this game are easily 2/10 territory, the rest of this game is just kinda meh, even when you take the difficulty up to normal or hard. Really wish they had done more to make every enemy more than just an arrow sponge if you aren't hitting the specific weak points. There is absolutely no depth to encounters outside of "hit the glowy spots until it dies, and dodge" and that's a big ass letdown tbh. Every encounter is so 2-dimensional since you have to do the exact same thing for every enemy, as they all have the exact same weak points, and you somehow deal even less than negligible damage doing anything else.

I see professional speedrunners and long-time players getting shit on all the time because the combat is brutal no matter what, and I also see the average players on reddit and in forums resorting to exploits in quite a few areas because way too much of the game is just bullshit. Manufactured difficulty to pad out the playtime. If the game were truly fun and you weren't just banking on gamers™ continuing out of spite, you wouldn't have to stretch out the few encounters and quests the game actually has by ramping up the health slider on every enemy until the game is just barely fun enough to play... And why does every enemy respawn the instant you turn a corner?

PS I absolutely skipped the shit out of every single cutscene and dialogue in the game, I don't have time or patience for that boring BS. Really thankful you can skip them though, for sure. Some you can't for some reason, but by and large they are all ignorable. i'd also recommend turning off the music and dialogue audio sliders right when you boot the game up.

PPS This port is horrible, crashes, frame issues, model issues, everything clipping constantly, and the controls would work a lot better on controller but I can't give up aiming on a mouse to sit back and rely on auto-aim these days.

I'm only 10 hours in but I want to strive to get all the achievements in this game.  That's how much I've fallen in love with it.  Init ally I dismissed it because it was PS exclusive and I was interested in BOTW, Dragon Age inquisition, and Witcher 3;  Though those  games have their strong elements, Inquisition made some lore and story choices I feel iffy about, BOTW I felt was weak in story, and Witcher 3 I felt was over-hyped by it's community and the story too bleak (not saying those were bad games but they really were not my cup of tea).  Both games I felt could have been better in different ways.  But Horizon Zero Dawn?  As soon as I started, I realized It was perfect - the world, the game-play, the characters.... All of it

It's an awesome, beautiful, and empowering game.   I got it initially because I saw some concept art for it and I feel like this game lives up to it's concepts.  There is a huge diversity of characters and the combat, stealth, Role-play, dialogue are all perfect.  Even though I have open world fatigue, I don't feel that way wit Horizon Zero Dawn; Thus I say is an awesome game for everyone especially those who love beautiful environments, a rich and engaging combat system, A ton of cool lore, and an epic story which is a blend of Sci-fi and Fantasy!

I can't really say if I liked this game or not. 

I played the game on Ultra Hard from the start, so my gameplay was slow and painful but it didn't really bothered me. I liked the challenge.

But discovery part of the game was just meh for me. Random texts scattered around the map, most of them just random people talking about their daily lifes or commercials that centuries old. It's not interesting.

What Aloy wears not interesting or game changing. Weapons Aloy use are not interesting. There are a lot of different arrow types. But you will always use the most strongest ones. Because that means easy kill. And good upgrades open later in the game (mostly DLC) so there is nothing to looking out for when it comes to loot.

After completing any quest, game gives you weapon mods as a reward. Just random weapon mods that you can find from any other enemy. So you only complete the side quest for the immersion and most of the time there is nothing to do out there in the world, except for killing machines.

Story of Aloy is interesting at the begining for a short couple of minutes, but game doesn't make anything with it. She is an out cast for her whole life and after a short sequence of events she is the seeker of the whole tribe in a few days. That's just a weak writing there. 

What really interesting is what really happend to the world itself. And Aloy is the key. And the key opens the door that led to an unsatisfiying answer. At least for me. 

Maybe Forbidden West is a better game when it comes to the story. I don't know. If it comes to Steam, I would like to play it.

Horizon Zero Dawn jest dobrym przykładem gry przygodowej, która nie stara się na siłę, być czymś, czym nie jest, a czym i tak nie mogłaby być. Nie ma tu elementów dodanych na siłę, wybrakowanych - wszystko jest na swoim miejscu. Widać to w konstrukcji świat gry (otwartego, ale na tyle ograniczonego, że jego wielkość nie rozprasza uwagi), mechanice eksploracji i walki, a na interesującej i oryginalnej historii kończąc. Długość wątku głównego (podstawki i dodatku) oraz ilość zadań pobocznych starczają na długie godziny zabawy. Stopień trudności możliwy jest do dostosowania, więc to przyjazna produkcja także dla osób, nie będących na co dzień z grami akcji. Oprawa audio-wizualna (będąca na najwyższym poziomie, nawet po tych kilku już latach od premiery) swoim bogactwem dopełnia pozostałe elementy gry. Nawet bezcelowa wycieczka przez las potrafi dostarczyć pozytywnych wrażeń. Zwłaszcza nocą w okolicach Meridian. W kontekście grafiki, bardzo miłym dodatkiem jest możliwość ukrycia prawie wszystkich elementów interfejsu z poziomu aplikacji, bez konieczności korzystania z mod-ów. Nie dość, że zwiększa to poziom trudności (i satysfakcję płynącą z walki) to jeszcze pozwala na głębszą immersję.

-Horizon Zero Dawns is an open-world game that isn't bloated like the recent Assassins's Creed games and it truly was fun to go and explore every nook and cranny of the map together with getting every collectible. The map looks and feels stunning with it being the perfect size for a story game. I reckon you can go from one edge of the map to the other in max 10 to 15 minutes. 

-At first I didn't like Horizon Zero Dawn at A L L because some of the game features gave me a bad first impression. I dropped and picked right back up the game and ever since then it really grew on me. Went from annoyingly thinking I have to force myself to finish the game to exploring every location, completing every quest, attaining every achievement. I feel like this is what people meant when they called Days Gone bad for its start and I was atleast partly to blame for it in this case.

-At times the mount would get really janky, also the occasional stutters that will happen right before entering the biggest settlement (PC-port maybe bad? besides that the game ran a smooth 60fps even in the biggest of fights. Eats/R-word's your CPU tho, viewer beware!). I somehow didn't realize that there is a whole crafting mechanic in besides all the other menus that I was using. One thing that is a bit odd is that there are in-game lootboxes built into the core of the game so when you complete a quest for example. You go to your inventory go under a specific tab and there you have your openable lootboxes that give you materials or whatever. While looting you can find materials or yet again lootboxes, come to think of it, every big drop not from a dead enemy is in the form of a given lootbox, a bit strange in my opinion but doesn't ruin the game since there luckily aren't any microtransactions :D Stealth is a mixed bag, It's a good opener to a fight is what I'm going to say.

-Although even if your mount isn't like the Skyrim horse your character sure is. When there aren't any put in place parkour places to grab onto you cannot use parkour animations but you can stand & jump endlessly on every slight edge of a mountain or building for example. Even though you're not technically parkouring when you end up reaching your destination it can feel much more satisfying to do so. The mount on the other hand can go off course with automatically reaching the destination or require much patience if you're on any rocky path or steep incline, when so it will reduce the speed to a crawl basically and do the jumping animation, can be troublesome when other machines are aggroed and out for blood lol.
 
-I really liked the mysterious, simple premise of the story and the looming atmosphere. The "Frozen Wilds" story DLC was just stunningly gorgeous, reminding me the views of Skyrim. Got a couple nice pics in photo mode, all in or near the new DLC-area. It was very saddening to complete everything and having to put down the game because there wasn't any content left to play. Only wish the face paints and focus variants came before completing new game+ :D they just fit so perfectly when accessorizing. Cannot wait until Horizon Forbidden West comes to the master race. 8/10

This is the best story based campaign and open world adventure game I have played.

I'll keep it simple.

Played in 2022 on modern PC operating smoothly/constant high fps, at max settings.

Tweaks:
I think I used a reshade setup to make it more to my taste on a calibrated monitor and PC capable of enhancing the already beautiful game (better AA for example).

I *may* have altered the Field of View (FOV) to reduce motion sickness... can't recall sorry. If I did it was ingame or via ini file adjustment. I do it for most FP or 3rd person games that are too narrow a view.

My play style:
I may play for long sessions on a game of some hours if I'm really into it - but I'm not into "Day 1 rushed the main story to be done so I can tout about it and whinge about lack of end game content"

I like to explore and adventure doing all of the side quests along the way. A not hardcore completionist :).

HZD offered many hours of play. 118 hrs is me doing one play through with the DLC.

Immersion: 
This is the best story based campaign and open world adventure game I have played. 
I finished every nook and cranny and wanted more. 

The game has astounding, beautiful vistas and a genuinely captivating story that makes you think about our world today as it is. A few times I just hustled to climb to the highest point or best view because it really stimulates the imagination and brings you into the world. There is a sense of real scale here that works with the story. 

Reading/listening to the historic recordings you find builds the story - it's not all nonsense and fleshes out the quest lines. Not essential yet again, builds immersion and losing yourself in the story.

I never felt frustrated with the controls using KB and mouse. The port is well done and doesn't pull me out of the gameplay.

Progression:
I needed to develop skills in order to kill beasts and I could use different methods - required different methods yet it never felt like classic rock/paper scissors. The terrain and what you were up to matters. 

I had to grow, sneak and plan quite often instead of relying on weapon power. I sometimes went where I was not powerful enough to be safe and had to rely on stealth. This is the true value of a world that doesn't normalise itself to your level (eg like Diablo IV). That's bland. This has scale and earning more power feels more powerful. 

The world is genuinely enormous. It's genuinely full of animal life and I spent a lot of time hunting between point A and Point B so I could have the resources to enhance my gear. Bring up the map to see the available encounters and you think "Holy SH#$"... because it's so many!

Games I rate this with:
Fallout 4, The Witcher 3 are two games I put this on a pedestal with. Each had similar depth of story, crafting, some puzzles, combat and flavourful NPC connections. HZD has no base building though.

Star Wars The Old Republic (ok that's an MMO but still big story based focus), Jedi outcast/survivor, are also story based games I really liked that were not as open world but offered similar experience of adventure and "feel". 


I rate the game a full 10/10.

Imperfectly beautiful in most aspects- yes, most, because the jumping mechanics contributed to 60% of my headaches as I journeyed throughout Horizon Zero Dawn. Aloy, the character you are embodying, is notably above average in athleticism and skill yet hanging onto ledges seem to be an impossible task to undertake. The developer only determines certain ledges and ridges which was very infuriating especially with the vast terrain. 

Now onto the pros, combat was more strategic than head-on which was sooo satisfying - especially when Aloy was facing predator-like machines. A hunter at heart, a marksman at bay. With her arsenal, preparing for a strategic takedown with little physical contact made the game twice the fun. Checkpoints were easily accessible too due to the amount of campfires throughout the region so rest easy, Horizon Zero Dawn is not a Souls game.

One of the most beautifully executed games I've had the privilege to play this year! The premise and plot are like nothing I've come across before, and both the CGs and scenery had amazingly realistic graphics - I haven't seen visuals this good since Cyberpunk 2077. The voice acting was divine, the large cast of complex characters was clearly created with love, and Aloy is now one of my favorite female protagonists of all time. I also really appreciate the range of difficulty levels provided; since I'm not the best with strategy in games, I'm glad I had the choice to focus more on the story than anything else. All in all, there's nothing I didn't love about this game and I really hope the next 2 installments in the series will be coming to PC soon. This is definitely a series that deserves its own show (which is apparently in the works)!

The graphics, world and gameplay are amazing.
The normal mode is quite challenging and seems a lot harder than normal mode is for most games and if you try easy thinking it will be more like normal, it's not. Easy is too easy for me.
I did not have any crashing, though I did experience really bad lag  at some Cauldrons. But the rest of the game is fine.

The Keyboard mount controls are terrible, left shift to move forwards to sprint faster and left control to slow down and stop. I would prefer if the mounts had usual movement controls like how they are in Skyrim.
 I don't like riding them at all. Besides it's very limited as you can only ride 3 the Strider horse like, charger horse/ram like and broadhead bull like. It would of been more fun and interesting to ride sawtooths.

Facial expressions and movements can look really strange at times with weird looking eye movement and  rapid blinking. A NPC moved her face left and right jerkily kind of  robotically in conversation with her, it happens with others as well.
And an NPC was talking about something tragic but also smiling at the same time, seemed out of place and the wrong emotion to convey. Also lip syncing is not very good at times.

I find the combat, hunting and destroying machines the most fun part of the game.
Even so I felt there was too many machines around, I was fighting so many along the way that I ended up over levelled at lvl 40 and was only up to a lvl 15 main mission. As I got towards the end I just ended up feeling sick of fighting endless machines everywhere so just ended up choosing story difficulty so I could get rid of them quickly.
Hitboxes can be really off, arrows often don't hit where you were aiming for. I tried for both auto aim and with it off.
And often after using a critical hit on a downed machine I can't immediately use any other attack and she just stands there a bit and I can't attack again until the machine stands back up if the critical attack isn't enough to fully kill it. It's annoying.

I loved the story even though it was predictable. But the way the story is told I did not find it immersive. Any dialogue choices you make don't seem to affect anything. You're just following the story, there are no branching paths or any decisions to make, you don't help make or shape the story or outcome as there is only one ending. It feels like I am watching a movie, it does not feel like Iam a part of the game world as it's not immersive or deep.
Interacting with characters is not interesting they seem as robotic as the machines.
Only a few characters were memorable, the majority are very forgettable.
A few things did emotionally affect me though.

Underneath the pretty graphics and fun combat it's just a standard open world game that doesn't break the mould. Simular to the formula Ubisoft uses with a lot to do that is enjoyable and fun to play but lacking any depth.
I'd rate it 7/10 it's an enjoyable game to play through, I just feel it has some missed potential to be epic.

Horizon Zero Dawn is Playstation's take on the long-tedious-sidequestfatigue-RPG genre (at least compared with the other PS games on PC). I have played tons of these kind of games, and while I know many people hate them and have become tired of devs just pushing the same game over and over, I like them, I love the thrill of exploration and the necessity to find the last little collectible on a huge map, so this review is a bit biased.

However, HZD is not like Assassin's Creed, having played every single one of those, I though it was just Assasin's Creed Playstation Edition, but let me tell you, it isn't. Yes, it has several mechanics and ideas from that kind of game, and while it isn't as great as RDRII or Witcher III, it is almost there. Most Open World games have an immense map that looks overwhelming and ends up being a big empty space where you're just gonna travel through or admire the landscape, and yes, Horizon is a graphical marvel deserving of it's praise, but there's stuff to do too! The world feels alive and thriving and gives you the opportunity to get into some cool machine hunting with tons of different weapons, including RPG elements like elemental weak points, it's great!

The lore and story is intriguing too, and I was on the edge of my seat searching for clues and audio files to understand, what happened? The ending answered most, if not all of my questions, and while it leaves an open ending I don't really need another game, the story feels complete, unlike Days Gone for example. 

Now, the game looks incredible and breathtaking, is full of beautiful landscapes and diverse biomes, but it all comes for a cost, it needs a powerful machine, I played on medium-high settings and was a fluid 60 fps experience still looking good, but it is indeed a very demanding game, there are a few bugs here and there like with some achievements not unlocking unless you start a new playthrough, but the one bug that really bothered me was the audio issue, if I understand correctly is an issue with the compression and mix, the only way I managed to solve it was using external speakers or headphones, so beware.

To conclude, solid game, although an Open World game, it feels and plays much different than your usual Ubisoft, amazing graphics, cool story and lots of fun to be had.

Perfect Game #62, Horizon Zero Dawn.  There will be slight spoilers in this review, so TL;DR.  A fantastic game all around, the exploration is fun, the combat is amazing, and the story is top tier.  Horizon has solidified itself as one of my favorite series.

Now to go more in depth, Horizon Zero Dawn is one of my favorite games ever.  The story blew me away the first time I played through it.  I went in completely blind thinking that it was just a game about primitive people fighting robot creatures, but slowly learning what was actually going on is an experience that no other game has given me.  A big factor in the buildup of the story is the characters though.  Every character in Horizon feels important, even the small side ones and random NPCs living in settlements.  All the important characters are acted out and voiced incredibly and they really elevate the experience.

The combat is also very fun with a lot of variety.  The standard bow feels strong to shoot, ropecasters allow you to set up cool traps, slings are just fun to use, and there are even more to choose from.  The melee attacks are the only weak point here, but that option is still there although a little bare-bones.  The robots are also varied and interesting.  There are some that fly, there are robot bears, there's even a T-rex robot.  It's all so cool, and each one offers their own challenge and different ways to approach fighting.

The world is probably my favorite part of Horizon Zero Dawn though.  The map is filled with details like real-world places and beautiful scenery.  There are snowy mountains, arid deserts, and jungles full of terrifying machines.  The people living in the world are what complete it though.  People are fighting to survive in a post-apocalyptic world and each one is unique.  Everyone has their role and place and it really makes Horizon's world feel special.  I could not recommend Horizon more, it really is a great experience from start to end.

[h2]Good game.[/h2]
[b]Pros:[/b]
 1. Amazing environmental art
 2. Amazing character art
      - Really good facial animations. Not Call of Duty cutscene level, but close
      - Really fluid character movement while traversing the world 
 3. Great world building
      - Cognitive cohesion between characters aim and players actions
      - Motivating to explore the world
      - Likable characters that you feel invested in
      - Gripping storyline
      - Collecting story bits in audio or text format feels natural and entertaining
 4. Great, fitting soundtrack, but not really memorable like TLOU or Mirror's Edge
 5. Great fighting mechanics against robots. 
      - Involves using variety of tools and ammo types, it feels satisfying to see a robot and instinctively use ammo that hurts it the most. 
      - Game paces enemy strength quite well. Even maxed out player will find a challenge in the end game, however it depends on the skill and/or amount of cheese used.
 6. DLC is more of the same goodness, but harder. Builds upon existing narrative. Was definitely planned together with the main game. There is a character voiced by female V voice actor. ;D

[b]Cons:[/b]
 1. Torturing vacuuming simulator. Welcome to the "Connect the dots" game. Unless you are playing on easy difficulty, you [i]will[/i] be walking from red plant to red plant while traversing the world, as its the most cost effective way of getting healing items.
 2. Fighting against human enemies is underwhelming. Feels like they were the last thing developed compared to marvelous fighting you get with robots. It is great that it's not the focus of the game.
 3. Minor visual glitches. Mostly a black skybox during sunrise.

[b]Other Notes:[/b]
Well optimized game. Runs well, didn't crash, has solid autosave. I recommend maxing out the graphics as it's a marvel at every corner, and AI upscaling is worth using.
Worth its asking money, but is often on discount as well. A must play IMO.
Time needed to 100% the game: ~100 hours.
Time to complete only main quests on NG+: ~5 hours.

As a die-hard Witcher, Borderlands, and Assassin's Creed fan, my loyalty was firmly rooted in Geralt's world. But then, Horizon Zero Dawn strolled into my life, and let me tell you, it's like that feeling when you first bit into a perfect burger – mind-blowing.

Gameplay & World Building: 5/5

You know that parkour thing we love in Assassin's Creed? Well, Horizon Zero Dawn takes it and dials it up to eleven. Aloy's moves are smooth as butter, and I swear, I'd choose her over any Assassin for a rooftop race any day. The best part? Mission objectives are so darn clear. No more wandering aimlessly in an open world. This game holds your hand just enough, so you're never lost but free enough to explore.

But hold on to your gamepads because the real treasure here is the story. It's like Witcher 3, but on some next-level complexity. Aloy's journey, folks, is something else. It's not just a hero's tale; it's a quest to uncover the truth about the Faro plague that rocked her world. Every character, every choice, every twist, it all adds up to a narrative masterpiece. You'll question your every decision, and you'll love every moment of it.

Performance: 3/5

Now, here's the kicker. If your gaming rig is anything like mine – an i5 and a GTX 1050 Ti – get ready to play this beauty on the lowest settings to maintain that smooth 50 FPS. Yeah, it's a hardware hog, no two ways about it. But let me tell you, I gladly sacrificed some graphics for the storytelling feast this game serves.

Conclusion

In the end, Horizon Zero Dawn is not just a game; it's an emotional rollercoaster. It knocked Witcher 3 off its pedestal in my book, and that's saying something. This game's got parkour to die for, mission clarity that's a godsend, and a story that'll make you question your own existence.

It's all about finding the truth – about the Faro plague, about Aloy's true self, and about your own gaming heart. Even with its hardware demands, it's worth every pixel. Horizon Zero Dawn isn't just a game; it's an unforgettable journey into the depths of storytelling and self-discovery. So, grab your bow, jump into Aloy's world, and prepare to be amazed.

The world is very big but far from empty, resources are abundant without feeling cluttered, and the machines are always around to either fight or be carefully avoided. The weapon options, once fully unlocked/upgraded, give the player about a dozen ways to approach any fight or hunt, further augmented by unlocking the diverse skill perks. Lob AOE bombs from a distance, snipe weak points, trigger elemental explosions, distract, disarm, sneak up and stab them with your spear, turn wild machines into allies to fight beside you, or pepper them with two-foot-long stakes from an impossible thing called the rattler, all of these are viable play styles.

I'm 40+ hours in, and I've been grinding pretty hard because the hunting is so fun, so according to the game I'm at 50% completion. This with having uncovered the whole map, unlocked all top-tier weapons and gear, and encountered all enemies but specials/plot enemies. So believe me when I say I'm enjoying this game. But the character interactions are mediocre at best. Acknowledging that this game is 6 years old at the time of this review, HZD was clearly pushing up against the boundaries of the tech of its day. With everything else the game does so well, I can't be too hard on it for having a couple flawed facets. The writing is stilted, the voice acting is inconsistent, the body animations are random, and the facial animation is . . . so close to being good it makes me that much more frustrated with it. They clearly spent more time on the protagonist, so I end up hating her animations less, and that's good. The story is intriguing, and now that I'm thoroughly over leveled I'm going to rip through and see what it's about.

I got this game on sale, and if the story ends up disappointing I still would say I definitely got my money's worth. Open world action/exploration game, Monster Hunter meets Shadow of Mordor with a techno-viking crunch. 3/5

One of the best games I have ever played. I usually like RPG games with a good character arc, interesting mechanics and a beautiful interactive open world and the game has all of it. 

The protagonist goes from a nobody to a ruthless but yet compassionate warrior as she takes the world of chaos head on and survives against all odds. Among the games I have played, I was pretty invested in Lara Croft from the Tomb Raider series as a victim turned badass survivor and still like her but Alloy is easily one of the best female character in the universe of survivors bringing everyone together and saving the world.

The mechanics, mods and weapon system in the game is also interesting. You can modify the weapons to get a maximum damage or corrupt the machines and watch the chaos from afar and the damage you can conjure after the new game plus extra slots and collected mods is insane which practically makes you a god. 

And for the open world, it's one of the best I've ever seen both aesthetically and in size specially with the Frozen Wild DLC. I haven't seen an open world this beautiful following Day's gone. 

All in all, if anyone is looking to play this game, it's definitely worth your time. I got this game on sale but it's worth the full price. I hope the sequel Forbidden West comes along on PC soon. I plan on continuing the series.

Recommended: Yes

Playtime: 89.6 Hours

Achievement Completion: 100%

Game Length: 30-76 Hours

Reviewed on: PC

Pros:
1. Engaging Open World: The game offers a vast and beautifully crafted open world, filled with diverse environments, wildlife, and ruins, encouraging exploration.
2. Unique Combat System: The combat mechanics, featuring a mix of ranged and melee combat alongside strategic use of traps and tools, provide an exhilarating and tactical experience.
3. Stunning Visuals: Horizon Zero Dawn boasts breathtaking graphics, showcasing detailed character models, dynamic weather systems, and lush landscapes that contribute to a truly immersive experience.
4. Intriguing Lore and World-building: The game's narrative is woven into a rich tapestry of post-apocalyptic lore, unveiling the mysteries of the Old Ones and the robotic creatures that roam the land.
5. Compelling Storyline: Aloy's journey is emotionally gripping, with well-written characters and a plot filled with unexpected twists and turns that keep players invested in the narrative.
6. Varied Enemy Design: The diverse array of robotic creatures presents unique challenges, each with its own set of strengths and weaknesses, requiring players to adapt their strategies accordingly.
7. Well-Integrated Crafting System: Gathering resources and crafting upgrades for weapons, outfits, and ammunition feels seamless and rewarding, adding depth to character progression.
8. Engaging Side Activities: From hunting grounds and bandit camps to challenging cauldrons, the game offers a plethora of side activities that provide valuable rewards and contribute to the overall experience.

Cons:
1. Initial Learning Curve: The game's complex mechanics may take some time to grasp, especially for players new to the title, which could potentially lead to a steep learning curve.
2. Limited Character Customization: While Aloy is a well-defined character, some players might have appreciated more options for personalizing her appearance and playstyle.
3. Occasional Technical Hiccups: Despite the generally smooth performance, some players may encounter minor technical issues such as occasional frame rate drops or texture pop-ins.

Overview:
Horizon Zero Dawn Complete Edition offers a captivating blend of exploration, combat, and storytelling within a visually stunning post-apocalyptic world. Its unique premise, combined with a well-developed protagonist in Aloy, immerses players in a rich narrative filled with mysteries and engaging gameplay. While the initial learning curve and minor technical hiccups may pose slight challenges, the overall experience is nothing short of exceptional.

Gameplay:
The core gameplay of Horizon Zero Dawn revolves around a dynamic combat system where players utilize a combination of ranged weaponry, melee strikes, and tactical strategies to take down robotic foes. The introduction of Aloy's Focus, a device that provides critical information on enemy weaknesses, enhances the depth of combat, encouraging players to approach encounters with a mixture of cunning and precision. Additionally, the integration of stealth mechanics allows for diverse playstyles, further enhancing the tactical depth of the game. The vast open world encourages exploration, offering a plethora of activities and secrets to discover, ensuring that players are constantly engaged.

Graphics and Sound:
Horizon Zero Dawn sets a new standard in visual excellence. The game's meticulously detailed environments, from lush forests to barren deserts, showcase a level of craftsmanship that immerses players in a believable and awe-inspiring world. The robotic creatures are beautifully designed, with intricate animations that convey a sense of realism. Moreover, the dynamic weather system and day-night cycle add an extra layer of immersion. The sound design complements the visual experience seamlessly, with a score that heightens the emotional impact of key moments, and ambient sounds that further enhance the sense of place.

Story and Narrative:
The narrative in Horizon Zero Dawn is a standout feature, blending a compelling main storyline with a richly detailed world steeped in lore. Aloy's personal journey is intertwined with the broader mysteries of the Old Ones and the origins of the robotic creatures, creating a sense of urgency and curiosity that propels the player forward. The character development is superb, with well-rounded personalities and nuanced relationships. Memorable moments are plentiful, and the game masterfully balances moments of quiet introspection with high-stakes action.

Performance and Technical Issues:
Overall, the game runs smoothly on PC, with stable frame rates and minimal load times, even on moderately powerful systems. However, some players may encounter occasional minor technical hiccups, such as infrequent frame rate drops or texture pop-ins. These issues, while noticeable, do not significantly detract from the overall experience.

Multiplayer and Community: Horizon Zero Dawn is primarily a single-player experience, with no multiplayer features or online modes. However, the absence of multiplayer does not diminish the game's quality, as the focus on a rich, narrative-driven experience is a strength in itself.

Final Thoughts:
Horizon Zero Dawn Complete Edition is a tour de force in the action RPG genre, offering a captivating blend of exploration, combat, and storytelling. Its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and immersive world-building make it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast. While there are minor technical hiccups and a learning curve to navigate, these pale in comparison to the overall excellence of the experience. For those seeking an unforgettable journey in a post-apocalyptic world, Horizon Zero Dawn delivers in spades.

HZD sempre foi um jogo que me chamou atenção pela sua proposta e pelas imagens formidáveis de um mundo distopico, com essa mistura entre passado e futuro, e entrega realmente uma boa experiência.
Levantando as considerações positivas, o primeiro acerto para mim foi ter finalmente uma protagonista feminina, onde sua personalidade é bem construida entre uma pessoa amorosa, porem forte diante o que passou e precisa enfrentar pela frente.
A jogabilidade é boa, as lutas sao intensas, as maquinas sao bem feitas, tem ate interações entre eles, os diálogos sao coerentes, a historia principal te faz querer saber mais a cada momento, o mundo aberto é muito bem feito, as variações entre gelo e deserto, nos faz imergir de uma forma formidável.
Minhas criticas negativas, mas que nao me fizeram desestimular, foi a lança que ela usa pramlutar, do qual eu sinto que deveria ser mais livre o combate do que ela ter ataques pre feitos ao atacar (ela sempre vai atacar da mesma forma), tive problemas tambem com a mudança de tempo em algumas ocasiões que simplesmente um passo alterava de forma drástica o clima ou iluminação do ambiente, os NPC's poderiam ser um pouco mais distintos (muitos com a mesma cara), as roupas/armaduras sao bem feias e a fase final é energetica, mas eu particularmente queria algo mais intenso diretamente com Hades.
Do mais, otimas batalhas, otimos bosses, otima historia, side quest ajudam na exploração e aquisição de itens, Eloy é feita na medida certa, o cabelo é realmente um dos melhores ja feitos, boas opções de escolhas em missoes, o clima/tempo/ambientação é muito lindo, no geral vale a experiência e deixa um gosto de vontade para o segundo jogo da franquia

I'm not sure how I missed this game back when it was released but I'm so glad I picked it up in 2023 since its a gem.  I really liked the story and premise of the game, to me it was as good a story as Mass Effect or other AAA games.  Overall I felt it immersive and engaging and din't feel that I was 'grinding' for gear.  I really like the story mode that lets you turn down the difficulty a lot to get a by a frustrating boss fight, then flip it back to normal so I don't  get annoyed with tedious boss fights that make me quit the game out of frustration.  I would have liked to have seen more ability to customize armor or weapons.  Perhaps a way to forge multiple mods into a single 'legendary' mod to affix to armor or weapon instead of tossing out all your common mods as you filter to keep only the purple class mods.  I think that would help with the more difficult levels of game play and add another dimension to the game as you tend to get your kit setup and don't change it much after midway through the game but that is a small nit.  Maybe a way to store gear 'at home' and have a forge at home to do something with stored gear.  Also I felt there were too many weapons and armor sets you are changing out often (from silent armor to something more durable once you are discovered).  Too many weapons for a 4 weapon wheel - again changing out weapons assigned as 1 or 4 options on the wheel...  Hopefully some of this is refined in a subsequent release of the game (I have not looked at Forbidden West yet but will).  Overall worth the time to play through, even if on easy to hear the sci-fi story.

In short:

great combat, great enemies, amazing graphics, good map, runs well enough.

interesting story concept but bad delivery, unrewarding looting system, human combat is boring compared to robot, unsatisfying bosses and some questionable balancing choices for a few items.

Pros 
- great combat and enemy variety. There are tons of different robots to fight with the majority feeling extremely diverse (apart from the striders and their 4 or so counterparts). Each enemy fells great to fight as well down to how you can influence their AI by targeting weak points or using elemental arrows. Combat never got stale throughout my play through.

- One of the best looking games I've ever played. Animations for the robot enemies are also very well animated.

- The map is overall very good. Quite large considering there aren't any good methods of travel, but i didn't really mind because it meant I got to see more of the environments. Great variety of biomes which all look great. Decent coverage of content across the map. Tall necks are a fun way of uncovering sections of the map.

- I found the side content pretty fun, especially the cauldrons and dlc fireclaw encounters.

- The game ran smoothly for me, I also didn't experience any glitches outside of one or two floating objects (judging from other peoples experiences this isn't always the case, so don't take my experience for canon). For reference im running a 3080 + ryzen 7 5800x + 32gb of ram.

Cons 
- The biggest con for me is the story, which if you can be asked to pay attention, is at times interesting, but the delivery is terrible. So much of this game is talking to random npcs where you will be given different dialogue options, which is weird because they make no difference at all to the story. On top of that all the characters are very lifeless, meaning I didn't care about any of the dialogue options anyway so I would always skip the interactions and or choose the dialogue option which would end the conversation faster. The best parts of the story are when you visit the remnants of the old civilisation, where you discover more about what happened to earth and how/why Gaia was created etc. However 90% of this part of the lore is told through optional messages, audio logs and holograms rather than actual story telling.

- The looting kinda sucks, especially because Aloy has to stop dead for an animation to play of her picking something up every time you want to pick something up. This gets very tedious considering how many items you need to pick up for ammo crafting materials and health items. Also the only valuable things that enemies drop are the purple mods which means the reward for killing even the toughest enemies is pretty underwhelming, unless you like to have a lot of currency I guess.

- human enemies are boring to fight in comparison to robots.

- side content can be repetitive 

- The dlc weapons make everything else obsolete and so does the shield weaver armour. I started a new game + on the hardest difficulty and it was a breeze with those weapons and armour apart from the fireclaw encounters. Kinda trivialises combat because all you have to do is spam ice arrows and then either hardpoint or regular sharp shot arrows, which do so much damage with the dlc bows that I didn't find myself using any other arrows or tools most of the time.

- Boss fights could be better. There aren't really any boss fights in the game which feel like boss fights, because all the bosses are just regular enemies which can be found on the map.

- Mounts suck ass. It feels pretty unresponsive when you try to turn, not sure why robot horses have such terrible handling. Also when you do manage to turn your mount looses all of its speed for some reason which means you have to constantly hold shift. I just opted to walk or fast travel to objectives most of the time.

Title: "Horizon Zero Dawn: A Journey That Touched My Heart"

Introduction:

In the world of open-world games, where many tread similar paths, "Horizon Zero Dawn" is a shining gem that taught me the value of patience. If you're willing to invest time and emotion into its prologue, you're in for a profoundly rewarding experience.

A World of Wonder and Redemption:

Imagine the thrill of stalking gigantic mechanical beasts armed with nothing but a bow and arrow. "Horizon Zero Dawn" places you in the shoes of Aloy, a compassionate hero on a quest that involves not only helping villagers but also seeking the pieces of her shattered heart. It's a journey filled with themes of bullying, revenge, astonishing discoveries, and the unbridled joy of exploration.

A Heart-Wrenching Tale:

This game didn't just immerse me; it gripped my heart with its emotionally charged narrative. Learning about Aloy's painful past – how she was abandoned and mistreated – left me with a lump in my throat. As the story unfolds, you witness a transformation in how people treat her, and the fates of those who once looked after her (I'll spare you the spoilers). "Horizon Zero Dawn" tells a beautiful story that resonates deep within.

Masterful Skills and Combat:

Aloy's abilities are nothing short of extraordinary. The power to slow down time became more than a gameplay mechanic; it felt like an extension of my own skill. As I upgraded my bow, I grew more powerful, ready to face any challenge. The combat in this game is not just cool – it's an adrenaline-pumping, heart-pounding dance with destiny.

A Game for the Heart:

Now, it's important to acknowledge that "Horizon Zero Dawn" isn't for everyone. If you're a hardcore souls gamer seeking relentless challenges, you might not find them here. There are also lengthy conversations you can skip, but I implore you not to rush. Each dialogue adds a layer of depth to the characters and the world.

In Conclusion:

So, what's my personal verdict? I can't help but declare my love for "Horizon Zero Dawn." It's more than just a game; it's an emotional journey that left an indelible mark on my heart. It taught me the value of patience, the power of storytelling, and the exhilaration of mastering one's skills. If you're ready to embark on a deeply personal and emotionally resonant adventure, "Horizon Zero Dawn" is waiting to embrace you.

The game is a very good sneak with bow and arrow-game. But unfortunately some missions require a more head-on approach. Your character does not do well in close combat, and being attacked by more than one enemy is pure chaos. There are a lot of armor options in the game, but I felt they didn't help anything, so I just kept using the stealth armor and later the shield weaver.

The missions and pacing in total, felt ok. Even though I did a lot of side missions, the main missions were difficult enough. The story was very compelling and I think this universe really has potential for many more games. The puzzles and parkour paths could have been cut shorter. It wasn't too bad, but it started to feel like a chore after a while. The Hunting grounds was both maybe the worst and best experience in the game. I utterly loathe time limits, so finishing them was something I never thought I could do. But it was possible after using all kinds of tricks learned through the game, and also a little bit of cheese.

The sounds and music is really spot on. You really don't want to turn off the music. The voice acting is up to AAA standards, but the random comments and grunts misses from time to time. The dialog feels sometimes just routine acting from the voice actors. They doesn't live into their characters, but still does a passable job. The same goes for the graphics. Really stunning landscapes with a lot of biomes and variation. Well animated enemies and wildlife, but the people feels and looks like marionettes too often. 

The expansion The Frozen Wastes feels a little bit tacked on. It just dials the difficulty to 11, removes the possibility of controlling most of the machines, and give you armor and weapons that replaces everything in the base game.  So everything you earn and learn in the base game, is just thrown out of the window.

Note: For those of you that really want to experience the story, and fear the battles: In the last patch, they included a Story-difficulty. In this mode you can one-shot all the enemies more or less and experience the story without dying over and over.

to start, the ability tree isn't very good. it has the basic issue that a lot of other trees do where it allows for specialization, but each new ability is more expensive than the last so you're not really able to specialize. and yet at the same time, you're not able to specialize enough for certain play styles. in fact, all of the abilities seem to only really encourage being very aggressive with only a few improving stealth, and not in a way i find satisfying, i.e. you get to stealth kill enemies, where you go up to them from behind and kill them with your spear. once the *long* animation finishes, the enemy is dead. this leads to the issue i have with stealth:

it's not a good stealth game. 

there's no actual strategy or risk to it. you just have to crouch which makes you completely silent, then enter tall grass and you become completely invisible unless you attack. that's part of why the ability tree doesn't have enough specialization into stealth, there's nothing to actually improve. this type of stealth has no actual risk, so it's not at all satisfying to use. and on top of this, because whether or not you can be seen or heard is a binary, higher difficulties don't make the stealth more difficult. this combined with the stealth kill issue means that the difficulty increase with higher difficulties is honestly negligible, only really making combat take longer.

you know exactly where every nearby machine is due to your focus, which can see machines from around a hundred feet away through solid stone. not only that, but it can see the paths of machines that patrol, removing the fun and the challenge of figuring that out yourself. part of the fun in a stealth game, at least for me, is when i managed to miss an enemy during recon, meaning i now have to find a way to deal with them or i get seen, and have to switch to combat.

very near the start of the game sums this all up pretty well, when you have a mission to sneak past a few machines to save someone and there's zero challenge whatsoever, despite the fact that at the time you're 7 or 8. you see their paths, and once they walk past you then you sneak to the next bit of tall grass. this is essentially how it will be for the rest of the game.

combat just plain boring. there's nothing really to add to that. the process of combat is this brief loop:
1. identify the weak points of the machine.
2. shoot the weak point until it starts an attack.
3. dodge out of the way of the attack.
4. repeat from step 2 until the machine is dead.
this process doesn't change by the way if there are more enemies. it's just the same thing, with more dodging to not get hit.

the one part of the game i do actually enjoy is the story and the lore supporting it. it was interesting seeing how these people with nowhere near our technology today interpret things far beyond our technology. an example of this would be the mountain at the start of the game. you end up being brought into a sacred mountain, in which there's what turns out to be a door leading into something similar to the vaults in fallout, minus the experiments. it scans you, and says it can't let you enter due to there being corruption that you can fix. this gets reasonably interpreted as their god electing a chosen one to cleanse the corruption in the land. i just find this kind of stuff interesting.

despite this though, it doesn't make it worth it. stealth is unsatisfying, the combat is boring, and the numbers reward isn't worth the effort to level up, nor is it particularly satisfying to do so. i really do wish a could recommend this game, the idea is so cool to me but the execution just doesn't lead to a fun or satisfying experience.

There is nothing i could say here that others haven't already said. But for what its worth i think this is probably my favourite game of all time. 

Bought on my PS4 when it first came out and it was one of the only games i ever truly enjoyed to 100% complete. Feels like decades ago since its launch, but back in 2017, games felt truly 'finished' on release and none of these absolute sh*t shows over the past few years like CyperPunk 2077, Anthem, Fallout76, No Mans Sky etc which are marred with issues during their launch, and to be honest just completely ruins the experience of even getting started after all the hype. In that sense, Zero Dawn was never spoiled, which made its incredible gameplay, storyline and mechanics, even better.

I think my favourite part is the narrative. I've never felt more immersed and drawn to the story as i have with this game. The 'rebirth' of humanity, coupled with the events that led up to the near destruction of Earth, had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. Most games have a fairly obvious storyline and you aren't too surprised at its progression. (SPOILERS) But with every revelation of Gaia, Hades, the Alphas and even finally Aloy discovering the exosuit of Elisabet after her sacrifice at the end of the game, was just.. wow. I don't normally get emotionally invested in a game's story, but this was the first time i think ever where i shed a tear during the epilogue. Its similarity to the real world i think is what gave it that hook. All the games mentioned above are truly 'this would never happen in real life, or at least in our lifetime', but Zero Dawn (not to be a doomsayer or anything) is an increasingly possible situation for our planet, and i genuinely wonder what life will be like 1000 years from now. In that sense, you aren't only becoming a hero in this story, but you are saving the humanity that we all live in every day.

I bought this game on steam because my PS4 broke and i have no plans on getting the PS5, but i had this itch to relive that story again and god it was worth it. This will be my first and probably only review i ever write, but i wanted this to pay homage to the absolute perfection that is Zero Dawn, and as a tribute to everyone that was a part in its creation. I will keep this feeling long into the future and i hope if i ever have kids, that they get to experience what i did playing this game.

Horizon Zero Dawn is a groundbreaking video game that has captivated audiences worldwide since its release. Set in a post-apocalyptic world where humans coexist with robotic creatures, the game offers players a unique and immersive experience. From its stunning graphics to its compelling storyline, Horizon Zero Dawn has received widespread acclaim from both critics and gamers alike. With its open-world exploration, strategic combat mechanics, and intricate character development, the game stands out as a true masterpiece in the realm of gaming.
Yes!
This is one of the best games I have ever played. The setting is spectacular, the gameplay exciting, and the story compelling.

I came to this game straight after playing AC Odyssey which I think is one of the best games ever so Horizon had a lot to live up to.  I was absolutely blown away by the depth of the plot, the sheer visual beauty of the game and the distinct characters.  The game is set in various biospheres (desert, grassland, mountain etc) each of which is populated by specific tribes with their own unique look and philosophy (religion?) based on their fragmented understanding of the world around them.  The visual design of this game is stunning and there are a lot of unique character designs which keep the game's look fresh even if you find yourself in the same biosphere for  a long period.  The development of the story as Aloy learns about her past and the evolution of the world she lives in is really involving and there are plenty of collectable text points which you can collect and read later which add a lot of colour to the story.  In terms of gameplay there is the usual FarCry/AC skill tree and weapon upgrade opportunities with the focus very much on range weapons (melee fighting barely exists in this game), tripwires and traps.  Each robot has their own strengths and weaknesses to particular elements all lovingly detailed in Aloy's notebook (tip: if you refer to the notebook before engaging a machine your life is going to be immeasurably easier).  Some machines are harder than others (I've still not managed to kill a Rockbreaker) and their variety keeps the combat element engaging.  Downsides? Its quite common to get stuck on or inbetween scenery necessitating restarting from the last save point; also at the end of the game after completing the final battle and watching the post-credits cut scene the game returns you to the start of the final quest (you still get all of your XP from completing the game so not a major issue but not very clean).  Aside from that minor niggle a fantastic, immersive game and definitely recommended for fans of the long form RPG.  One last thing: curse you Ted Faro!

This is a fantastic game. Not a perfect game by any means, but it provides 70-85 hours of fun and what more do you want from a game.
The premise is quite unique, when it comes to the world, which immediately elevates it above any generic sequel of which we get way too many nowadays. 
You learn about the world and its alternate history through different datapoints throughout the world, which could have been done better. At the same time, it isn't terrible. 
Visually it is very well realized. It is one of the few games which gave me a sense of actual height, whether it is the height of buildings or the height of a mountain when you are standing on top of it. 
As is always the case with a good game the gameplay is the best thing about it, mainly the combat. You get a lot of different weapons to use on a multitude of different enemy types and the fighting is mostly smooth, even though it can be frustrating since a lot of enemies knock you down and it can snowball when there are a lot of enemies.
The in-game economy also works quite well, because there are a lot of incentives to go out and get different machine parts and get different wildlife in order to afford all sorts of weapons, outfits and upgrades. 
The story is surprisingly well written. It fits perfectly into the world and has a few twists and turns which makes it quite interesting. Unfortunately the characters themselves aren't really interesting, which does impact the story presentation negatively.
The only other negative would be the size of the world, which in my opinion is a little too big. There is a lot of open space that isn't critical and only increases travel time. 

As a sidenote: The game has been ported very well to PC. It looks fantastic and I had not a single dropped frame during 85 hours of gameplay.  

Pros:
+ concept
+ story
+ gameplay
+ pacing

Cons:
- characters
- open world

Feels like an Assassin's Creed made by From Soft, or a Dark Souls made by Ubi. Overall great core mechanics, interesting world, with a varied cast of characters and enemies, and lots of collectibles. 

The setting is honestly very intriguing and thought provoking, but a little on the nose. The interactions and "moral" decisions however have little to no impact on the characters and game progression, missed opportunity. There is only 1 ending, and there are two parallel main quest-lines so the game feels quite linear. The side-quests, DLC and overall environments do a great job at making the world feel alive and definitely enhance the storytelling. Subtlety is however completely out the window, with the main character constantly talking to herself in the typical videogamey fashion "oh I wonder what happens if I press that button over there". Visually it's fantastic, not much to say, typical mega big budget polish. Although character animations are a little uncanny.

By far the best thing is the core game-play surrounding the combat. The enemies a very varied in their behavior, attacks and sizes. With unique strengths and weaknesses that force you to play smart and counter them with a wide arsenal of weapons at your disposal. The crafting and elemental systems are IMO very fun, although there are clear weapon imbalances. Still having all this choice doesn't feel overwhelming and gives the player great flexibility on how to tackle combat.

The only true big negative is the main campaign length and lack of NG+ challenge. The actual main game is quite short, most of the content lies on the side quests and DLC, which are quite engaging. While I took me around 65 hours to max out all the game in NG, my NG+ run on ultra hard lasted only around 5 hours. By the end, it honestly feels like the game is way too easy. I do wish there were additional mechanics to increase the challenge further. This is more or less addressed in the DLC with new more dangerous enemies and equally more potent weapons to match.

TLDR: Game good, like an easier Dark Souls or a better ubi-game. Looks beautiful, short main story, great combat, kinda short campaign, lots of good side activities. DLC OK. Recommended, specially if you like collectathons

He often gets into trouble or causes trouble for others, and he needs Aloy to bail him out or fix his mistakes. He helped her stop HADES, the artificial intelligence that wanted to destroy the world, but he also saved HADES from destruction and kept it for himself.

These are just some of the examples of how the game portrays women and men in an unbalanced and unrealistic way. There are many more examples throughout the game, such as:

The Nora tribe: They are a matriarchal society that values hunting and nature. They are led by women, who are called matriarchs. They are mostly good, noble, and wise people, who respect Aloy and honor her as their savior. The men in this tribe are either warriors or hunters, who follow the orders of the women. They are mostly bad, cruel, and corrupt people, who oppress other tribes and sacrifice people to their sun god. The women in this tribe are either nobles or slaves, who have no power or voice in their society. They are mostly oppressed, abused, or ignored people, but they are also resilient, defiant, or rebellious people.

The Oseram tribe: They are a democratic society that values technology and innovation. They have no leader, but they have no leader, but they are governed by a council of elders, who are both men and women. They are mostly good, friendly, and helpful people, who support Aloy and share their knowledge and inventions with her. The men and women in this tribe are equally skilled and respected, and they work together as partners or rivals.

As you can see, the game portrays women and men in a very biased and unrealistic way. It shows women as being better than men in every way possible, and men as being worse than women in every way possible. It shows women as having no flaws or weaknesses, and men as having no strengths or virtues. It shows women as being able to do anything that men can do, and men as being unable to do anything that women can do. It shows women as being the only ones who can save the world, and men as being the ones who ruined it.

Feminism is supposed to be about recognizing and respecting the differences and similarities between women and men. It is supposed to be about empowering women to achieve their full potential without limiting or oppressing men. It is supposed to be about celebrating the achievements and contributions of both women and men in history and society.

But this game does none of that. It does not portray women and men in an equal and diverse way. It does not recognize or respect the differences and similarities between women and men. The game? Fantastic. The port? Awful. I've had a disappointing number of issues with this port. Despite having a somewhat beefy system (i7-11700K, RTX 3070, 3200MHz RAM and 980 Pro SSD), this game struggles to perform in many instances and exhibits issues not seen in any other games. 

List of issues:
-Game ALWAYS uses 100% of all 8 cores on my CPU at all times, no matter what is going on. No enemies present? Every core. Looking at vast, barren landscape? Apparently, every core is necessary for this. 
-Awful performance in 1440p, as its more CPU intensive. Can only play this in 4K. 
-Ridiculous pop-in even when running on a 980 Pro and 3200MHz RAM. 
-Every cut scene is impossible to take seriously due to the ridiculous pop in. The world rebuilds itself with every camera change, the characters pop-in and "settle" into the scene well after the camera changes position. 
-Terrible audio mixing. A character will be far away and sound like they're right in your ear, or randomly sound like they're in a tunnel with an echo. The bit-rate for the character's voices is screwed up somehow, it sounds like the dialogue is coming through a telephone. During intense scenes it is nearly impossible to distinguish the music, sound effects and dialogue as they all just jumble together. 
-Sometimes the textures just refuse to load, have to restart my entire PC for this to go away. Aloy's model will also just randomly refuse to load all the way for several minutes, walking around like OG Lara Croft. 

I play many graphically intense games and none of them are as taxing on my processor as this game is. In Cyberpunk and RDR2, even the most populated areas use less than 100% CPU and I maintain a stable 72 FPS in 1440P ultra settings. HZD goes sub 60FPS in 1440p just walking around, regardless of the settings, with my CPU temps as high as a Cinebench stress test. This is unacceptable for a game that released on the PS4. 

I hate to leave a bad review for this game, simply because the game itself is good, but there's just no excuse for a port that's been out for 2 years to have this many issues.  If the sequel has similar issues, I won't be buying it.

Horizon Zero Dawn is truly a masterpiece of gaming. The game combines an epic open world, an ingenious storyline, and stunning visual and sound design to create an immersive and captivating experience for the player.

First, I was impressed by the game's world and its beauty. Vast grasslands, forests, mountains, and wildernesses are depicted with breathtaking detail and reality. Even the robotic dinosaur-like creatures are amazingly elaborately designed, and the effects and movements during battle are breathtaking. The sunsets and sunrises are as beautiful as paintings.

The story is also deeply moving. The main character, Arloi, confronts his past and forges his destiny in a mysterious world. The complex relationships and surprising plot developments draw the player in. You will share in their adventures as you become emotionally involved in the characters' growth and conflicts.

The combat system is very comfortable and makes hunting and fighting fun. There is a wide variety of weapons and traps, requiring strategic play. The battles with the robots are a perfect combination of action game-like thrills and tactical elements that make it hard to stop playing once you get going.

In addition, the soundtrack and sound effects are excellent and further enhance the game's atmosphere. From the sound of the wind, to the sounds of animals, to the tense atmosphere during battle, the detailed sound design immerses the player in the experience.

Horizon Zero Dawn sets a new standard for open-world action RPGs, and I can assure you that its beauty and depth are second to none. It is one of those games that is well worth playing. Once you play it, you will be captivated by its charm.

I should probably premise this by saying I went into this game having no preexisting knowledge of the story, combat, or experience in any way. I picked it up in a steam sale for about 20 dollars and TLDR I would recommend it for some reasons and not recommend it for others. It very heavily feels like an Ubisoft game where Farcry and Assassins Creed had a robot dinosaur baby. All in all I feel like I got my monies worth, but I would never do a second playthrough.

The Good:
- The story is incredibly interesting and fascinating to uncover from a position of not knowing anything about the game beforehand.
- The visuals are stunning and the attention to detail in some areas is astounding and easy to get lost in their beauty.
- The combat is fun, challenging, and fast paced enough to keep it from getting repetitive (mostly.)
- The game ran pretty smoothly (there was some stuttering on load-up, but would flatten out after a few minutes) on a computer that is starting to show it's age on more modern games.
- All cutscenes are voiced, as are about 30% of the collectables.
- The enemies are wonderfully designed and you can tell how intricately crafted they were.

The Bad:
- There were some instances of environment merging problems where you could see pallet swapping squares on the floor rigidly cut and not blended.
- The main character is unlikeable, whiny, stubborn, and tries to make you feel things for her when it's not set up correctly emotionally.
- Voice log collectables and in game voices while exploring will play over eachother, making it impossible to hear what either thing is saying.
- Some characters faces have a very "uncanny valley" look to them. Sometimes a characters face will go from relaxed and calm to "Running aggression protocol" and stretch to angry mode. The main characters teeth don't always sit right in her head when she speaks too.
- There's a need for suspension of disbelief for parts of the game aside from the obvious. Like rappelling down a rope with her bare hands uninjured or enemies talking in gentle voices while using sonic attacks to disable people at the same time.
- Platforming is somewhat inconsistent sometimes. Sometimes you just have to nudge the character in the right direction and they'll jump automatically, and sometimes they'll walk off the edge to their death, and there's no way to know which way it is until you try it.
- Inventory is a nightmare in this game. Even with the extra slots from the DLC there is not enough slots and nothing tells you whether an item is still useful or not. You'll often run out of the items you need for crafting your favourite ammo types too, somehow. Also, you have to hunt for meat in order to make fast travel tokens. Super Annoying.
- Fast travel puts you into an often 20-30 second long loading screen if the area is far from where you are. In fact, most loading screens in this game are kind of wayyyyy too long, even for an older pc.
- What you're fighting scales wildly in difficulty. Some enemies are just attacking you constantly, and you spend 99% of the fight mashing your roll button for iframes. Other enemies are so slow you can run circles around them or kill them in 1-2 hits. There's not really any enemies in between. Also, flying enemies are more annoying than any game I've come across before, ever. 
- 80% of the side quests are uninteresting with characters you won't remember five minutes after you're done with them.

Again, I would never do a second playthrough of this game, nor did I stick around long enough to collect all the odds and ends. By the time I was about 80% of the way through the game I was tired of it, and then I did the 8 hour long DLC and just wanted the game to be over. However, I definitely recommend playing through it at least once for how interesting the story that doesn't involve the main character is, if you can find it on sale.
