Horizon Zero Dawn swept me away on an immersive action-adventure like no other. The beautifully crafted world and its intriguing origins more than compensated for the storyline's minor imperfections.

From the moment I set foot in the game's vast and diverse landscapes, I was captivated. The lush forests, desolate wastelands, and bustling settlements created a visually stunning and dynamic backdrop for my adventures. The coexistence of nature and technology in a post-apocalyptic setting felt refreshing and thought-provoking.

As I unraveled the secrets of this unique world, I found myself completely engrossed in the game. The mix of ancient tribal societies and futuristic robotic creatures was a stroke of genius that kept me engaged throughout.

While the main storyline had its ups and downs, I still found myself invested in Aloy's journey. Her quest to uncover the truth about her past and the world she inhabited was emotionally captivating.

However, what truly made Horizon Zero Dawn exceptional were the side quests and the vast amount of lore to explore. Each side mission introduced me to compelling characters, each with their own fascinating stories and struggles. The depth of the lore enriched my gaming experience, making the world feel alive and immersive.

The gameplay mechanics were smooth and intuitive, allowing me to master Aloy's combat skills and take on challenging foes. The strategic approach needed to defeat the robotic creatures added an extra layer of excitement to the game.

The stunning visuals and hauntingly beautiful soundtrack further heightened the overall experience. The attention to detail was commendable, making every moment in the game feel immersive and enchanting.

In conclusion, Horizon Zero Dawn's world-building and exploration were a true triumph. Despite a few hiccups in the main plot, the rich universe and the sense of discovery as I delved into the mysteries of this post-apocalyptic world made it an incredibly enjoyable and unforgettable gaming experience.

Easily one of the best open world games I've ever played. Somehow Horizon avoids the bloat that plagues most games in the genre, and is able to tell an incredibly genuine and focused story. It has some of my favorite world building and my absolute favorite setting (Colorado Springs + the cool parts of Utah). I didn't realize where the game was set until I discovered the ruins of the Air Force Academy, and when I did it made my jaw drop. The attention to detail in these familiar locales makes for a very believable post-apocalyptic narrative, giant death robots and all.

The gameplay stands out as well. The rush of adrenaline that comes from narrowly dodging the attacks of a massive robo-dinosaur thing only to pivot into a quick arrow shot into it's barely-exposed cooling vent is exactly the type of experience I wished for in games like Monster Hunter. Machine hunts can be short but are always intense, and there is absolutely no shortage of enemies on the map. The stealth mechanics are well done, and this is one of the few games in which traps and lures actually make sense. Fighting humans is not nearly as cool. The bandit camps in particular are one area of the game that I was a little disappointed by. Luckily, these encounters are rare compared to machine hunts. 

The graphics are insane. The incredible art direction and shockingly good textures, animations, and models make the world and the characters feel so vibrant it's almost uncanny. almost any frame at any point in the game is a set-piece moment, and it provides a beautiful backdrop for the story and gameplay. 

Some of the writing (ESPECIALLY Aloy's dialogue during side quests) suffers from Fallout 4 disease, where the protagonist is a sarcastic jerk to every NPC even if you truly want to help them. This isn't really a problem in the main questline, but it can get annoying.  

Overall, good game. I really wish Forbidden West was out on PC because this universe is my favorite post-apocalyptic setting of all time and I need more.

Horizon Zero Dawn thrums with the energy of a creative team finally allowed to explore something new. It builds on elements of open-world and loot-and-craft gameplay that we've seen before, but it does so within a context, a setting and a style that feel fresh. Horizon Zero Dawn discovers a stronger sense of its own personality in one game than Killzone ever managed across half a dozen. Guerrilla Games has long been developing some of the most buzzed-about games in the industry; with Horizon, it feels like it has finally found its own voice, one worthy of all that buzz.

The gameplay is what shines here. The combat is definitely based around thinking ahead, and laying out traps. It also helps to think ahead of what potions you'll need. The melee combat is fun, but best used in conjunction with ranged weapons. Stealth is a lot of fun, and is more consistent than a lot of stealth games today. I don't think I got tired of the combat at all.

Upgrading weapons is fun. You get some great mods to really customize a weapon to fit you. The only drawback to this system is you need DLC to upgrade your only melee weapon, and you only get one slot. That could've been better.

The story is alright. I thought they did a great job building the lore of the old society, it's fall, and the birth of a new one. The problem is the massive amount of lore out in the world. You have to go looking for most of it. Some of it is also hidden behind poor side content that I have no interest in (hunting and racing challenges are just lazy content to me.) Only a small part is where you end up naturally. It can be Ubisoft level of collecting these. Lance Reddick turns in his usual solid performance. Aloy is a mixed bag. She shows some growth, but is often a douche to people. I notice more towards men. It's odd. Rost seemed to be good to her, and the matriarchs cast her out. I also notice that the majority of men are either a bad guy, completely inept, apologizing for their behaviors, or putting themselves down. Aloy and Sobeck are also too perfect for me. Despite this, I still stayed with the story, and enjoyed it.

I ran this on an R7 3700x, with a 3070, and 32gb of RAM. This is clearly one of the best coded games I've played in a long while. I can only remember one framerate drop (very uncommon today,) no dropped button presses (also far too common,) and no crashes. This is a well made game.

While all worlds are beautiful today, this isn't very important to me. Kudos to this world. It's far more detailed than most, very beautiful, and not too big. Well done!

One thing broken with the game. Silent Strike from above never once gave me the option to use it. I was always unseen, and would often fall on them trying to make the prompt appear. Silent Strike from Below also never had opportunities to use. They were just wasted points spent. Also, Silent Strike on RB caused my stealth to be blown often, as it would change the prompt right as I hit it (like AC Valhalla.)

I got BOTW vibes, Final Fantasy 3 vibes (especially in the soundtrack,) and even some AC vibes from it. Overall, I recommend this game. I got it for $17, and it's often on sale. Don't pay full price!

It's a tired formula, these open-world, crafting/collectible checklist kinda deals. But I'll be damned if this isn't one of the best there is.

The post-apocalyptic/sci-fi/hunter-gatherer/ancient-world/but-with-robot-dinosaurs thing they got going on is absolutely enthralling to me, it's wonderful. It's a unique aesthetic that also lends itself very well to the gameplay: Said robot-dinosaurs are interesting (though, very rarely, frustrating) challenges that have different damage/elemental weaknesses and strengths that push you to use your whole arsenal in a way I don't experience in games often.

Aloy herself is awesome (which may or may not have something to do with my bias towards her voice actor, so, full disclosure: YMMV). The supporting cast has been mostly forgettable, but not grating or bad, per se. I will say that the facial animations of the generic character faces are a bit uncanny. They have naturalistic touches that show an attention to detail in their conversation animation system thingy, but things can feel a bit stiff and don't quite form a satisfying whole.

Overall, it's an incredible game and one of the few open-world games I stuck with. If you dig these, or liked them in the past but got burned out, Horizon Zero Dawn might be a good choice if you're looking to get stuck in again.

For my part, though, the amount of... padding in these games detracts from the experience. I've currently spent 50ish hours in it, but I was playing it like a completionist, even though I don't have the dedication or attention-span of one. It just left me falling off of the game part way through, playing less of the content that would've been worth my time than I should have, if you get my meaning. Hopefully if I do pick it up again I can adjust my approach and expectations so I can have an even better time with the game.

One thing : do not expect an RPG, though. There are choices in dialogs, but they merely extend the player's interaction. The story arc is fixed, with a single ending. Also, do not expect a deep reflection on themes like artificial intelligence (especially when applied to weapons), climate change and the like. As I said, this is about entertainment.

I truly hope the sequel will be ported to PC as well.

Horizon Zero Dawn is a fantastic fucking game. It's not often that I play a game for 14 hours straight, only to realise it's 6AM. Two days in a row. I felt bad about not playing AC Valhalla but this is the perfect game to fill in the void. Everything from the characters to the story itself were so well crafted I never found myself going along the main path just for the progress, but to also see where it takes me. I really love this game, for sure. So instead I'm dedicating this review to all the things I disliked about the game, but  it wasn't necessarily easy.

By far the most disorienting thing about the game are some of the settings, or rather, what it lacks in them. You see, there's a kind of "Dynamic camera" that follows Aloy, the main character around. So if you walk to the right, the camera pans to the left. If you go to the left, the opposite happens. It'd be fine if you could disable it, as it's not what I'm used to and I think it's a poor design choice. So instead I needed to download a mod from GitHub to fix it. Similarily, there's no option to disable hints. Even when you're at level 30, half-way to max, the game'll say to press G to highlight the track. Or if you run out of inventory space it'll still remind you that you can discard the excess. Why in a game with so much polish have these things been overlooked? Still, a minor issue.

The other thing I found to be somewhat poorly made was the skill tree, or rather, the unlockable skills themselves. In a game where you defeat monsters to harvest parts to make arrows, why isn't there an "auto-loot" skill for the most basic resources? Why isn't there a skill to pick herbs up faster, since that's what you're constantly doing? The worst offender by far, is a skill the game *does* have, the "Dodge Prowess" skill. Before acquiring the skill Aloy could do rolls back-to-back as a form of speeding up sneaking and being more efficient. But with the skill, the whole system is completely redone with Aloy being limited to a roll every few seconds? Why? As someone who snuck around the entire game this was especially infuriating, Before I could get around an area with some quick rolls, but with the skill which is required to unlock at some point, I was no longer able to do that. Rolling just seemed redundant at that point. There's also some skills I never wound up using, too. For instance, the "Strike from below" skill that lets you kill an enemy from a ledge above you is never used in the game, or at least I never encountered a chance to use it. I just feel like they should've put some more thought into the skills, is all. 

Now for the more nitpicky stuff. For one, I never used traps. Even in the one quest where the giver says "some traps would be nice" in a passive aggressive tone, I didn't use a single one. Why would you want to use a tool that alerts others, when using your stealth attack is more efficient and doesn't draw attention? The only time I did use a trap, was in the tutorial. Other than that they're really only good for selling to merchants, at least is what I thought of them.

The other thing that got annoying over the hours was the menu music. Every time you open your map, inventory, quest book or statistics, the same track gets played. It's this nice tribal(ish) song that starts off with a woman vocalizing. So when you want to see where to go, or what to do, that one specific note from that one woman gets nailed into your skull. It almost made me want to use the menu less because of it, and maybe subconsciously I did. Apparently a lot of people like the song, but I personally disliked it. 

The game also discouraged hoarding resources, especially in the late game. You can fit a lot of stuff in your inventory, but at a certain point it's no longer manageable. I was constantly barraged by red names implying my inventory was full. But as a natural hoarder in games like these, I couldn't help but manually make more room each time it happened. Maybe this issue could've been tackled better, but I don't know. It's fairly player-specific. 

One last thing is that the game can be fairly hand holding at times, but not enough to be irritating. Sometimes when you jump to catch a handhold on a cliff, Aloy will instead stop dead in her tracks mid-air to grab the lowest possible thing, because that's what the devs wanted. Even though she could very well have made the jump to the higher thing. Similarly there's situations where Aloy needs to jump a gap, but instead of landing it like by all means it looked like she could've, her trajectory changes dramatically to grab the ledge.

That's all to say, the game's near perfection. The voice acting is bar none, and the facial animations especially makes the game look very realistic. Even without playing the game on the Highest settings due to performance reasons, the game still looks fantastic. And aside from all the bad things I said about it I think it's one of the better Open-World games there are. There were times I would see a new enemy so big, I couldn't believe the size of it. And hours later I'd discover I could not only kill them, but also tame them? As a perfectionist I can also appreciate how some things could be ignored for the 100% steam completion. Not all the little collectibles needed to be found, and those that did have an achievement tied to it had in-game maps to determine their location. The game is just very good at what it does, and you should play it if you're at all interested.

Here's hoping Forbidden West comes to PC as well.

Never has an apocalypse, the events that lead up to it, and what happened afterward been stretched so far apart as in Horizon Zero Dawn. It is called a post-post-apocalypse scenario for a reason.[/quote]

While Zero Dawn might be “just another Open World Action Adventure”, it has its own charm in a very compelling world.

Horizon Zero Dawn: A Masterpiece of Gaming Brilliance!

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Horizon Zero Dawn is an absolute triumph of the gaming industry, a tour de force that captivates players from the first moment they step into its breathtaking world. Developed by Guerrilla Games, this action-adventure RPG delivers an unparalleled gaming experience that leaves players in awe of its narrative, visuals, gameplay mechanics, and the sheer brilliance of its open-world exploration.

The first aspect that truly sets Horizon Zero Dawn apart is its captivating storyline. Set in a lush, post-apocalyptic world, players embark on a journey as Aloy, a strong and resourceful young hunter seeking answers about her past and the secrets behind the enigmatic mechanized creatures that now roam the earth. The game's narrative is gripping and emotionally resonant, immersing players in a rich and nuanced lore that gradually unfolds as they progress. Aloy's character development is masterfully executed, making her a relatable and empowering protagonist whom players root for throughout her epic quest.

The world of Horizon Zero Dawn is a visual masterpiece. From the lush forests and verdant plains to the desolate ruins of the old world, every environment is meticulously crafted with stunning attention to detail. The vibrant colors and dynamic weather systems breathe life into the world, creating a sense of immersion that few games can match. Exploration feels like an adventure on its own, rewarding players with breathtaking vistas and hidden treasures at every turn.

Combat in Horizon Zero Dawn is an absolute delight. Aloy's use of her trusty bow and a variety of ingenious traps to take down the mechanized creatures is an adrenaline-pumping experience. Each encounter feels strategic, requiring players to study enemy patterns and weaknesses. The thrill of bringing down a colossal mechanical beast with well-placed shots is unparalleled, making every battle a truly memorable feat.

Beyond its captivating story and engrossing combat, Horizon Zero Dawn boasts an impressive array of side quests and activities that enhance the overall gameplay experience. Whether it's unraveling mysteries, aiding the locals, or discovering ancient relics, each side quest adds depth and context to the world, making it feel alive and dynamic.

The game's soundtrack is a soaring symphony that perfectly complements the game's emotional journey. It sets the tone for every moment, evoking feelings of wonder, fear, and triumph that stay with players long after the credits roll.

Horizon Zero Dawn is a technical marvel, with top-notch graphics and flawless performance. The attention to detail in character design, animation, and world-building is second to none. The seamless transition between cutscenes and gameplay further adds to the immersive experience.

In conclusion, Horizon Zero Dawn is an unforgettable gaming masterpiece that deserves all the accolades it has received. With its gripping narrative, jaw-dropping visuals, exhilarating combat, and impeccable sound design, this game raises the bar for open-world RPGs. Guerrilla Games has truly outdone themselves, and Horizon Zero Dawn will be remembered as one of the most exceptional gaming experiences of our time. If you're looking for a game that will transport you to another world and leave you in awe, look no further than Horizon Zero Dawn - it's an absolute must-play!

Horizon Zero Dawn is an action role-playing game developed by Guerrilla Games and published by Sony Interactive Entertainment. It was released for the PlayStation 4 in February 2017, and for Microsoft Windows in August 2020. 

The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world where machines have overrun the land. Players control Aloy, a young hunter who sets out to uncover the secrets of the past.

Horizon Zero Dawn received critical acclaim for its visuals, gameplay, and story. The game was also a commercial success, selling over 10 million copies worldwide.

The game itself is "good". It's big, it's fairly open, it's diverse in it's enemy types, the story is acceptable, the difficulty is, generally, the right fit.

My key issues are that Horizon feels like it would like to be open world Soulslike but then it uses a female protagonist and it feels odd because of it. Aloy is a wonderful character and I LOVE her red bobbing hair twirling in the wind as I scale massive robot creatures. That red hair tells you everything you need to know about her, she's fiery, she's hard headed, she's tough... but on the same token it just feels weird that a 150 pound female character should have a slow, undexterous fighting style. I feel like she should be witty, fast, quick, like a shadow in the weeds and combat just doesn't do that. That disconnect pulls me out of the immersion for the rest of the game.

I understand that won't bother some people (and I plan to finish this game anyway) so I've given the game a thumbs up but... they really missed an opportunity here creating a gameplay style that mirrored Souls but also gave it it's own flare and it just doesn't do that.

I came into this game blind wanting to experience the game without any prior knowledge. I had a blast with the story and I really loved some of the combat engagements. The visuals took me by surprise and was blown away. I can really say I got hooked later in the game and it was an amazing game to experience.  But this game felt incomplete and it falls flat from perfection due to lots of bugs, poor immersion, cramped environments, annoying movement in dialogue, issues in cut scenes and the list can go on. I chose to look past the issues to continue to experience the game. I upgraded my monitor and graphics card to play game on high refresh and ultra graphics. I recommend you play this at peak quality or the other issues will drag you through. I knew how great this game would end so I pressed on to see it through. This is a great game and I hope you take the time to experience at its max or else I would wait till HZD2.

Story:  I'll address my first issue and go on from there. Its confusing for the first bit of the game and I don’t know why but it did not grip me for the first few hours of the game.. IT GOT BETTER. That's what ill tell people when I talk about it. It sums up later, and it wraps up greatly! BUT. It isnt great at the beginning. 
Beyond the game's beginning, what gets you hooked (for me especially) "what happened before now" what was the then, what is the now. So many questions as the game gives you GREAT questions to ask and the slow roll of info and answers as you progress the game is so satisfying. 
The little text stories you can discover, and the little audio stories are Awesome! It was a little touch of feeling instead of a fact, or the game telling you what is going on. its just a feeling you'd get by awesome voice actors throughout the game that really added to the atmosphere. Bravo. 

Visuals: WOW! AMAZING! Characters look good! The scenery looks AMAZING! The shadows are killer! The creatures are so well designed it is a shame we cant just get some time to admire them, some high quality slow shots would be amazing for some of the creatures. But the game is truly beautiful. The areas are so well thought out and designed. 
Talking about it for me wouldn’t do it any justice so this is a game that I recommend you experience and that can be said for a lot of games.

Game play: great game play, I enjoy the rouge like hiding and killing this game has to offer. The skirmishes were enjoyably difficult and there are plenty of resources to play around with. This game very much caters to how you play the game your way. If you want to fight straight up, go for it. If you want to sneak around assassinating everyone, go for it. Do you want to setup traps and have the advantage? We got you. How about sneak past the enemy "cause fk that shit", we go you covered there too. 
There are lots of ways to play the game I applaud that. This is great to see for players to feel like what they want to do in the world is an option.

Open World: The game is vastly open world, it has a lot to offer but there was too much to deal with to really appreciate it. 
There are times where I felt that the game was pretty cramped. There was so much space but you could be having a tough battle and walk into another group across the ravine or hill. Then it isnt just a battle of 3 specific enemies its become a fight for survival as you're chased 1 v 10. also there would be animals posted up in spots just to fill a hole it felt like. 
There are a lot you can cheese, ill admit there were a few times I decided to cheese and go around cause it was way too tough to not go around (And not sneak by I mean I climbed the hill where I shouldn’t have been able to get to, to get around). There is allot of that available. Rocks you shouldn’t be able to climb up or down, but it is what it is, it doesn’t ruin the game entirely 

People in the world: the characters are great, the npc's are poor and clunky. Which isnt a deal breaker, youre the main character so who gives a shit about the random towns folk or whatever. I don’t care but as they're apart of the atmosphere and environment so they account for something. My problem is their uselessness as teammates or guards. They really just useful distractions against enemies but nothing else. 

Immersion: there was a disconnect for me at the start where you as a player to charater have to learn what they know and overcome the skills to do so. Climbing isnt a challenge at all which was unfortunate. People and merchants are posted up in random spots sometimes. 
There are wild aggressive animals right out the gate in your own land, it just didn’t seem to add up. What they were there for to warm you up about the creatures but they did not fit the atmosphere. You ask questions like "how is this even possible", "why is this here", "how would you have tribes and cities running around or merchants trading with enemies on your front lawn"… constantly.

issues 
- the sound in cut scenes at the end of the game were switching from my speaker and then my headphones while the audio was set to headphones. lucky i didn't miss the ending with no sound.
- refresh rate drops during cut scenes which was a bummer 
- people falling out of the map which is crazy 
- the head nodding and eye twitching in dialogue pulls the immersion right out of the game unfortunately.
- finishing the bandit camps would automatically reset you for no reason. (Let me light the fire and then reset the camp plz)
- right after fast traveling to campfire you could recive agro from nearby creatures. 
- The level gap between creatures is not evenly placed as you try to progress the story, you could run into some hard fights easily, now add other creatures nearby and you got a shitstorm to deal with.
- beyond the cut scenes there were lots of audio issues, hearing creatures not there, not hearing sound effects just empty noise. There was lots.
-no banking system to store mods or resources, I constantly had to break things down to make space as my bags would fill and there was no more bag upgrades.

Prepare your eyeballs for a visual feast! The graphics in this game are absolutely mind-blowing. Seriously, they should come with a warning label: "May cause temporary loss of speech due to excessive jaw-dropping." But wait, there's a catch! While the visuals will make your eyes go all heart-eyed emoji, the game itself plays it safe. Yup, it's like that guy who wears a suit to a costume party - no risks, no surprises.

Combat mechanics, oh boy, they're as solid as a rock. You'll need the reflexes of a cheetah and the strategic mind of a chess grandmaster to survive in this mechanized zoo. But don't get too attached to the action because guess what? The gameplay loop becomes as repetitive as your alarm clock every morning. Snooze fest!

Now, the story. Brace yourself for a mind-bending blend of ancient civilizations and futuristic tech. It's like Indiana Jones meets The Terminator, except with fewer whip-cracking cyborgs. The premise is intriguing, no doubt about that. But hold on tight, because some of those side quests are as shallow as a puddle after a light drizzle. Who needs depth, right?

Let's talk about the open-world, shall we? It's vast, expansive, and... as interactive as a museum exhibit. Don't expect to dig through every nook and cranny, because most of them are just for show. And don't even get me started on the user interface. It's about as user-friendly as a Rubik's Cube in the hands of a three-toed sloth. Good luck navigating that mess!

So, to sum it all up, Horizon Zero Dawn is like a reliable family sedan. It'll get you from point A to point B without much trouble, but it won't set your heart on fire or make you question the meaning of life. It's a safe bet for those who enjoy open-world adventures and want their retinas massaged by stunning visuals. But don't expect it to leave a lasting impact or make you reconsider your existence.

In the wise words of the great Dunkey, it's a market-tested, risk-averse product that most people will enjoy, but only a select few will truly love or absolutely despise. It's like lukewarm soup on a chilly day - it'll warm you up, but it won't make you go "Mmm, that's the stuff!"

Having fallen in love with the original release on the PS4, I eagerly delved into Horizon Zero Dawn on PC, hoping to relive the captivating story and immerse myself once again in its awe-inspiring open world. I'm thrilled to say that this PC version delivers on all fronts, providing a visually stunning and meticulously crafted experience. From the enthralling side missions to the perfectly balanced combat mechanics, Horizon Zero Dawn on PC is an absolute triumph that deepens the already remarkable narrative, leaving players in awe of the post-apocalyptic world and hungry for more.

Horizon Zero Dawn's open world is a breathtaking masterpiece, seamlessly blending nature's beauty with the haunting remnants of a fallen civilization. As you traverse the vast landscapes, you'll encounter diverse environments that feel alive and teeming with life. The attention to detail is astounding, creating an immersive and believable post-apocalyptic setting. Exploring every nook and cranny is a joy, and the world's mysteries unfold gradually, enticing players to uncover hidden secrets and engage with the rich lore.

Horizon Zero Dawn excels in offering a wealth of captivating side missions that go well beyond mere fetch quests. Each side mission feels purposeful and adds depth to the already intricate world. From aiding struggling tribes to unearthing long-lost artifacts, these quests provide a sense of immersion and reward that keeps players invested for hours on end. Whether you're seeking thrilling combat encounters or engaging with thought-provoking moral dilemmas, the side missions in Horizon Zero Dawn offer a truly enriching experience.

The combat in Horizon Zero Dawn strikes a perfect balance between tactical finesse and raw action. The encounters with formidable machines are intense and rewarding, offering a variety of approaches to suit different playstyles. The game's combat mechanics cater to both tactical players who enjoy planning their strategies and executing them flawlessly, as well as those who prefer a more direct and visceral approach. 

Horizon Zero Dawn's story is a triumph of narrative complexity and intrigue. While it may seem confusing at first, the more you delve into Aloy's journey, the more the pieces of the puzzle fall into place. Uncovering the truth behind Aloy's origins and the enigma of the post-apocalyptic world is a gratifying experience that keeps you hooked throughout the entire adventure. The game's excellent writing and superb voice acting breathe life into the characters, making their struggles and triumphs all the more captivating. Prepare to be amazed as the story unfolds, revealing the secrets that lie within the depths of Horizon Zero Dawn's enthralling universe.

In conclusion, Horizon Zero Dawn on PC is an exceptional experience that builds upon the brilliance of its original release. The captivating open world, filled with diverse landscapes and hidden wonders, invites players to embark on an unforgettable journey. With well-crafted side missions, balanced and tactical combat mechanics, and a layered narrative that rewards perseverance, this post-apocalyptic masterpiece never fails to captivate. Whether you're a fan of the original or a newcomer to Aloy's world, Horizon Zero Dawn on PC is a must-play title that will leave you in awe of its storytelling prowess and yearning for more adventures in this beautifully crafted universe.

[h1]스토리, 그래픽, 액션, 볼륨 무엇 하나 부족하지 않은 작품[/h1]
[h1]게임 초보들도 쉽게 입문할 수 있는 대작[/h1]

Horizon Zero Dawn은 지금으로부터 머나먼 미래를 배경으로, 노라 부족의 아이, Aloy를 중심으로 하여 펼쳐지는 오픈 월드 RPG 게임입니다. 게임 속에는 각종 기계 동물들이 등장하는데, 사람들은 이들을 사냥하며 살아갑니다. 주인공 Aloy가 이 아름답고 신비로운 세계를 탐험하고 파헤치는 것이 이 게임의 주요 스토리입니다.

액션이나 전반적인 게임의 틀은 몬스터 헌터 시리즈나 다크 소울 등의 게임보다는 파 크라이 내지는 유비소프트 식 오픈 월드 게임에 가까운 형태를 지니고 있습니다. 경험치를 쌓아 레벨업을 하면 받는 스킬 포인트로 여러 가지 능력들을 해금하는 식입니다. 기본적으로 활이 많이 쓰이나, 폭탄, 덫, 구속용 로프, 특수한 화살 등등 가지각색의 무기를 사용할 수 있어 다양한 상황에 유연하게 대처할 수 있습니다. 더하여 액션 게임 초보자, 입문자들을 위해 내러티브에 집중할 수 있도록 스토리 난이도 설정도 가능하게 되어 있습니다. 조작 자체는 어려운 편은 아니나, 키보드+마우스 유저인데 조작이 불편하다면 일부 설정을 자기에게 맞도록 바꾸는 것을 추천드립니다.


좋았던 점:
[list]
[*][b]먼 미래, 포스트 아포칼립스 배경[/b]
최첨단 슈트 대신 털실, 가죽을 짜맞춘 의복과 기계 조각 장식. 레이저가 나가는 총과 광선검 대신 활, 창, 새총 등으로 전투하는 사람들. 마천루와 네온 사인 대신 나무, 벽돌로 만든 가옥... 그야말로 부족을 이루며 살던 원시 시대로 퇴보한 인류의 모습을 보여주며, 그럼에도 기계 동물이 있다는 차이점이 이 게임의 배경을 특별하게, 궁금하게, 흥미롭게 만들어 줍니다. 

[*][b]액션 장르에 익숙하지 않은 사람들을 배려해주는 시스템[/b]
초심자들을 위한 난이도 설정은 물론이고, 맵 여기저기에 사냥을 연습할 수 있는 장소들이 마련되어 있습니다. 새로운 무기를 얻으면 튜토리얼 퀘스트를 통해 사용법을 익히는 것도 가능합니다. 전투 중 사망하더라도 패널티가 없으며, 스태미나 또한 아예 존재하지 않아 타 액션 게임에 비해 제약이 적습니다.

[*][b]내러티브가 전개되는 방식[/b]
스토리를 대놓고 읊어주거나, 지나치게 잘게 쪼개어 놓지도 않았습니다. 딱 그 중간이며, 큰 가닥은 잡아주면서 세부 정보를 편린의 형태로 제공합니다. 게임 내내 혼란스럽지 않았고, 주인공의 목적도 확실했으며, 정보의 파편들을 습득해 여러 가지 내용을 유추하는 재미가 있었습니다. 

[*][b]사냥의 다양한 선택지 및 직관적인 전투 시스템[/b] 
여러 가지의 무기를 사용할 수 있고, 전투 중에도 바꿔가며 수렵할 수 있습니다. 또한 특수 무기나 잠입 등의 능력을 활용해 상황에 맞게 다양한 플레이를 선택할 수 있습니다. 또한 슬라이딩, 점프 중일 때 원거리 무기를 조준하면 슬로우가 걸리면서 액션의 쾌감을 한층 높여줍니다. 적들의 약점과 급소를 쉽게 파악할 수 있고, 각종 속성과 도구를 적극적으로 활용하도록 유도합니다.

[*][b]숨 막히는 절경[/b]
개인적으로 가장 좋았던 부분 중 하나로, 그래픽이 단순히 좋은 것을 떠나 세계가 아름답게 만들어져 있습니다. 맵도 작은 편이 아니며, 다양한 생태계를 지니고 있어 눈이 즐거운 탐험을 경험할 수 있습니다. 사진을 예쁘게 찍을 수 있도록 Photo Mode에서 심도, 밝기, 기울기, 시간 설정 등 다양한 옵션 또한 제공합니다. 평소 스크린샷에 관심이 없는 사람이라도 F12에서 손을 떼지 못하실 겁니다.

[*][b] 탐험을 유도하는 수집 요소들[/b]
오픈 월드에 빠지면 섭섭한 요소들로, 특출난 보상은 주지 않지만 이곳저곳 탐험할 수 있도록 유도합니다. 이렇게 찾는 수집 요소들의 설명도 흥미로운 읽을거리와 상상해보는 재미를 제공합니다.

[*][b]입체적인 캐릭터들이 만드는 흡입력[/b]
스토리가 진행되면서 주인공은 물론이고 NPC 캐릭터들도 대사, 행동 등에서 변화하는 것을 볼 수 있으며, 많은 주요 인물들이 다양하고 입체적인 모습을 보여줍니다. 주인공 Aloy도 강인한 신체와 정신을 소유하고 있지만, 여러 고난과 역경을 겪고 비밀들을 헤쳐나가며 감정적으로 흔들리기도 하는 등, 만능이 아닌 주인공이라는 설정이 더 와닿았습니다. 더하여 특정 상황에서 Aloy가 어떻게 대답할지를 플레이어가 정할 수 있으며, 이를 통해 스토리에 빠져들 수 있는 몰입감을 제공합니다.[/list]


아쉬웠던 점:
[list]
[*][b]게임을 루즈하게 만드는 사이드 퀘스트[/b]
메인 스토리 자체는 아주 흥미진진하고 재미있었는데, 사이드 퀘스트가 상당히 많은 편입니다. 저는 메인을 밀기 전에 그 지역의 사이드 퀘스트를 다 끝내 놓는 식으로 진행했는데, 중후반부에 들어서면서 슬슬 지친다는 느낌을 받았습니다. 그나마 다행인 것은 지쳐갈 때 즈음 더 이상의 사이드 퀘스트가 없었다는 점입니다.

[*][b]어려운 초반부와 쉬운 중후반부[/b]
적들의 약점을 알기 쉽다는 장점은 후반부에 들어서면 새로운 자극이 없다는 것과도 일맥상통합니다. 후반에 특별한 적이나 변이한 개체 등등 새로운 형태가 추가되어 변화를 주었다면 조금 더 흥미진진한 전투를 해볼 수 있었을 것입니다. 

[*][b]어중간한 스펙으로는 어림없는 그래픽[/b]
그래픽이 수려하다는 말은 거꾸로 하드웨어의 성능을 상당히 요구한다는 말도 됩니다. 이 게임의 가장 큰 적은 제 컨트롤이 아니라 뚝뚝 끊기는 프레임이었습니다. 제일 낮은 그래픽 설정에서도 버벅이면서 힘들어하는 컴퓨터를 보며 언젠가 새롭게 PC를 장만하면 다시 처음부터 해봐야겠다고 다짐하고 있습니다.

[*][b]오픈 월드를 표방한 게임치고 부족한 상호작용[/b]
맵 상에서 할 수 있는 상호작용은 NPC에게 말 걸기, 적 때려잡기, 약초 등 파밍하기 정도 뿐입니다. 이는 GTA 등 자유도가 아주 높은 오픈월드보다는 엘든 링의 그것과 조금 더 흡사한 형태입니다. 주인공이 무엇을 하든 스토리는 선형적이며 (메인, 서브 모두 포함) 주인공의 선택에 따라 퀘스트의 흐름이 달라지거나 하지는 않습니다.[/list]

[h1]마치며[/h1]
Horizon Zero Dawn은 여태 해 본 오픈월드 게임 중 세 손가락 안에 꼽을 만한 수작입니다. 게임 내 시스템, 맵 구조, 스토리 전달 방식 등에서 개발진들의 고민과 배려를 엿볼 수 있었습니다. 액션의 재미, 스토리의 몰입감, 섬세한 감정선, 눈이 즐거운 황홀경. 그 모든 것을 사로잡은 훌륭한 게임으로서, 추천할 가치가 차고 넘칩니다. 오히려 세일할 때 구입한 것이 미안할 정도로요.
아름답고, 광활하고, 신비로운 미지의 지구를 탐험하는 우리의 눈에 비치는 우리의 유산을, 들여다 볼 준비가 되셨습니까?
I have really liked the storyline  and gameplay. Would recommend

Horizon Zero Dawn is probably one of the best open-world RPGs I have ever played.

Although the gameplay is very different from others (as there is a big focus on archery and stealth, while melee combat is not really useful), the storyline makes up for it. 

The protagonist (Aloy) lives in a post-apocalpytic world where killer-machines roam the planet, while tribal villages try and survive. During the game, Aloy will embark on a journey where she searches for her own origins, the origins of the machines and what happened that caused the apocalypse. 

The graphics are stunning and probably the best graphics of any game I've ever played. 

The only negative thing I have to say about this game, is that most of the side-characters are very one-dimensional, and aren't that interesting. Just a couple of characters (including Aloy) are interesting and have a variety of motivations and intentions, but a lot of 'main story'-side characters are just boring. I wish they'd delve a bit deeper into the side-characters and have a series of quests where Aloy is WITH the side characters, not just doing a job for the side character. More dialogue between them, more cutscenes, etc. would make it more interesting.

Rating: 9/10

The beginning is engaging, AAA, high quality stuff. After you leave the starting area though, it goes downhill. The game feels like it was created to be an PRG with an epic scope with some Bioware style stereotypes: you start in a small house as a nobody, but then become a part of an ancient/dead/rare order after your foster parent dies (not really a spoiler). You then go into the world, becoming well known for your deeds, you enter the largest city in the kingdom/realm, meet the king, work for him, eventually vanquishing the great evil and becoming a legend. Except you do not care for anyone or anything, since the RPG parts in this supposedly RPG game are completely throwaway and mean nothing. It tries to be a good Bioware RPG with none of the charm, none of the characters, none of the story.
Character progression is a bit better than Far Cry New Dawn. Yes, it's that basic.

Storywise:[list]
[*]Aloy herself comes off as rude at times, but generally just 'meh'. Sometimes she's an insufferable, stuck up b*tch. She's just a horrible person. Additionally, she comments on the most obvious situations, as if the player was blind and deaf.
[*]The story, like the rest of the game, starts off strong, but becomes very boring very quickly with glacial pacing and throwaway side quests.
[*]The lore? The writers tried really, really hard to flesh out the world with tons and tons and tons of collectibles with pages and pages and pages of text. None of it is engaging. The lore should be interwoven into side quests and main quests. The codex pages should have been only an addition, if you wanted to learn more. But in Horizon Zero Dawn collectibles are basically the only way of learning any details about the setting. You can ask a few NPCs this and that, but that isn't engaging as well.
[*]The dialogue wheel is just there to be there. Very few meaningful choices can be made and the NPCs do not acknowledge quests that have been finished before you encountered the quest-giver.[/list]

My biggest gripes concerning the story:[spoiler][list]
[*]The antagonist is present in 3 quests of the entire main questline: once at the beginning of the game and then at the very end. I literally forgot about him up until that point. 
[*]What the Zero Dawn project was, is probably the only good mission with actually interesting lore, but it's not something sci-fi hasn't done dozens of times.
[*]Elizabeth Sobeck is a literal Jesus figure, saved the world twice, and then sacrificed her life (with a sad violin and singing in the background no less). She had no negative personality traits. Perfect Mary Sue in every possible way.
[*]This makes Aloy a clone of Jesus. At least she's an a*shole, so she's not THAT perfect.
[*]Ted Faro is a one dimensional, irredeemable dumbass. How this man became a trillionaire by creating, and heading, such a powerful corporation, is beyond my understanding. While Elizabeth saved humanity twice, he doomed it twice. When he purged Apollo it was so farcical, so comically blind, it appeared as if it was created just to make Faro even more of a complete idiot.[/list]
I'm genuinely baffled how the writers thought both Sobeck and Faro are good characters. It's comedic. It's so bad, this alone made me want to give HZD a Not Recommended.

Come to think of it, Elizabeth is better than Jesus: he saved the world only once, she did it twice, thrice if you count the sacrifice. She is a superhero, not a human. One good thing about her: even though it's the same person, she's very well acted in comparison to Aloy. Don't ask me why that is.
[/spoiler]

Gameplay:
It's a stereotypical Ubisoft-like open world game. Tedious. The combat and stealth are unique in that regard, but those also become old fast. Combat is basically dodge-shoot weakpoint-dodge-shoot weakpoint against machines and headshot extravaganza against humans. Stealth is tuned for large areas and distances against beasts, whereas small and packed human camps cause you to become spotted nearly instantly... until you gain the best stealth armor equipped with the best stealth mods at which point you are nearly invisible as if it was Skyrim with Sneak at 100. Also, the fact it's all line of sight and hiding place (e.g. tall grass) based, means you will get easily noticed even in pitch black rooms.
However, despite all of these issues, combat against machines is the best part of Horizon Zero Dawn. It took me a long while to finish the story, because I was doing all the side quests and activities concerning combat.

Other thoughts:[list]
[*]The game looks absolutely gorgeous, downright beautiful.
[*]You will be spending much of your time gathering plants (especially for your medicine pouch) and meat. Yes, it becomes extremely tedious lightning fast.
[*]You can only climb at specific spots and it's even more braindead than Assassin's Creed. What's worse, the jumps are often predetermined, i.e. Aloy will inexplicably jump noticeably further or closer just to match the specific point she is scripted to grab.
[*]The silent takedowns against humans look very slow and clumsy.
[*]The mounts are behaving somewhat realistically, making them awkward and clumsy to ride on.
[*]The takedown from above sometimes only has a split second prompt making it really hard to use against fast targets.
[*]There is no method of quick switching outfits, even though there are separate outfits for stealth, melee resistance, ranged resistance, elemental resistance etc., and you can switch between them manually during combat, which means it is encouraged to do so depending on the type of enemy you face.[/list]

To sum up, it's a good time waster, to play an hour or two a day. But a game to be remembered? Not really, no. HZD has an interesting setting, but fails to use it properly, the backstory/lore is only ok, and the main plot is formulaic. Good for a single playthrough and never touch it again affair.

:edit:

Forgot to add. Music is good. Didn't bother with the Frozen Wastes DLC, since I barely found the patience to finish the main quest of the base game.

A very typical open world game with a very creative story. The characters and the mystery kept me hooked and in the world. I did not however appreciate the inventory management, the weapon upgrade system and the at times slow transit between locations of value. As a golden rule an open world needs to provide a plethora of options far enough to allow for the player to feel safe, but never to be bored. At many an occasion I was doing stuff I considered tedious such as hunting specific animals to upgrade my satchel to carry slightly more arrows or what not. I feel like having to hold down the button to craft/dismantle/perform any operation made it feel even more boring. For its time this game was visually stunning, but it looks about the same as ghost recon wild-lands to me looking back. I definitely had fun playing this game, but don't buy it unless its on sale, the game-play while fun, and a good story. Cannot save an open world that isn't always eventful. For full price I would have wanted more. For example, ghost recon wild-lands, while having a terrible story, allows me to use vehicles such as helicopters to cover ground very quickly. I am rarely spending more than 15-30 seconds between locations if I target every item of value. This game does not share the ability to fly, which makes sense but at the same time. I do not see myself getting the full value of the game, as I lack the energy to explore every last corner. Thus, definitely wait for a sale before buying this title.

I don't want to start a massive and epic thread here, but this is really one of my favourite games of all time.  The lead character - Aloy - is one of the best written leads in any game I've played, being clever, empathetic, determined and driven.  Aloy navigates a world where she was an outcast and is now the symbol of her tribe - the Nora - and a symbol of hope for many of the other tribes also.  The mechanics of the game - which were refined for the excellent sequel - are at times clunky, however they do not detract to heavily from the excellent gameplay.  Combat is a mix of learning enemies patterns and attacks, while making sure equipment is upgraded and players make use of a skill tree to maintain an edge on enemies.  The story is post apocalyptic, but the world is far from barren and players can explore diverse biomes with unique creatures and challenges.  Graphically the game holds up as the world still looks stunning, the characters look fine and animations are generally smooth.  If you can overlook a game's flaws, you will have a great time with this game.

I usually play sandbox games like Sims or JWE2. I have played some Fortnite too but with mixed feelings.
Before I bought this I wanted to have a look at some gameplay on YouTube; what I could expect, if it would be something for me. 

The game environment is what drew me in at first, when I scrolled through screenshots and trailers. But as I started watcing a taped playthrough the story got me instantly hooked. To be honest, I couldn't stop watching. I didn't. Which meant I now knew the whole story - beginning to end - before even having bought it or played myself. However, for someone like me who gets easily stressed in games where you hunt or are hunted, it sort of helped knowing everything going it. It didn't turn me off from buying it myself.

When I do play now I play for hours and hours. It's easily my favorite game. I spend time on main quests (despite knowing the story), take on side quests that I haven't seen anything of, foraging and just try to get better at taking out machines and various foes. I love that it has so many choices for difficulty, including a story focused mode. I absolutely love the world. It's breathtaking when it's at its best. And the story is fantastic.

If you're in the same seat I was, sitting there trying to figure out if this game is worth it, stop thinking about it. It's worth it.

Cons, they don't matter so it just seemed like a waste, was what I thought till I thought about it even more, which is where the pros come in. This is so far one of two games I've 100%-d and wish I could buy the next installments but they aren't made for PC.
This game was/is beautiful, the landscapes are diverse and graphically stunning. I had never heard of the game before and bought it on sale on a whim, and don't regret it.

The game definitely can challenge you especially if your trying to 100% it like I did on the hardest difficulty (as It is part of the 100% for the achievements), there's a few spots where I had to change my play style because of the harder difficulty as it's not like the lower ones -- stuff is much more expensive, you have no visual health bar, enemies have no visual health bar, they hit harder, and they respond super quickly to seeing you VS lower difficulties and you gotta get a creative a little bit to survive. the Ultra Hard difficulty wasn't too bad (I believe partially because I was already hugely stocked up on resources just because I'm like that which, Ironically helped me tremendously when I switched to Ultra as I didn't have to waste much any time gathering them) just took a little creativity compared to lower difficulties but wasn't impossible to do, and that's coming from someone who doesn't play games on the hardest settings, and I still found it enjoyable as hell (although more challenging in a great way)

Fighting the Grave Hoard Deathbringer in the facility on Ultra Hard Difficulty had me stuck at first because of the weapons it has do a lot of damage on that setting, and I found a minor tip to avoiding dying by watching a YouTube video, or else I wouldn't have been able to complete the game and would've been really frustrated. 
I used this to get past it (it does possibly take a few tries to get it, or else you fall to your death the deathbringer kills you and you have to retry like I did a few times) 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S46KKRlS-qE

Overall it was a beautiful and wonderful game, challenging the right amount, fits all play styles, open world, various ways to kill enemies and makes you think a little bit outside the box on harder difficulties. The was the only issue I really ran into through 3 runs was fighting the Deathbringer on Ultra Hard at the Grave Hoard facility, besides that it was the normal challenge for the difficulty and working past it in different ways. I hope if anyone sees this and tries this game, they enjoy it too!

Horizon Zero Dawn is a deeply, deeply flawed masterwork of an experience.

The game's world is one of the most beautifully realized I have ever explored in a game, in a style that I can only describe as "artistic photorealism". You could go anywhere, put the game into photo mode, and just gawk at how amazing everything looks.

The combat is also wonderfully satisfying, requiring you to literally break the pieces off of your enemies to defeat them.

But it suffers greatly from its worldbuilding, which is very overwhelming. There is so much lore to find, so many people to talk to, that you become lost and really don't even know where to start. And most of the side quests in the game can be distilled down to doing two things - talking to a person, or defeating enemies. There are no minigames, very few truly impactful dialogue choices... It's kind of disappointing.

I spent around 55 hours, in that time, I completed all main quests, side quests, errands, bandit camps, Tallnecks, and hunting grounds in the "vanilla" game, plus the main quest line and one additional side quest in The Frozen Wilds. The experience was generally satisfying and I am looking forward to Forbidden West's eventual release on PC.

The good: it's got a well-crafted world and world-story. The plot is interesting---not quite compelling---and the side quests are mostly rewarding. A couple of NPCs have interesting and compelling arcs that happen in tandem to the PC's. In the 60-ish hours it took me to finish the game, there was only a little grind, and I found it largely rewarding.

Mediocre: the world is huge. to the point that exploration becomes a goal unto itself, which can be overwhelming in an open-world game like this. Most of the weapons and upgrades, skill tree, and armor mechanics feel ancillary---they're unnecessary and don't really contribute to gameplay. The economics of crafting and shopping are yet a hair worse. And combat and knowledge can be subtle. You can effectively complete the game without paying too much attention, spending time to stealth, etc (although combat becomes much quicker if you pay attention to your Focus' output).

Bad: many of the NPCs are flat and uninteresting, despite fascinating side-quests they send you on. You also are very much railroaded, despite the RPG-feel of the game: your choices broadly don't matter, making these elements feel useless. Also, combat doesn't really scale as you level---This was a very nice feature of e.g. AC:Od, but here, if you skip something until you are well past the "recommended level", it can be completely trivial (sometimes. There are some player-skill tasks that are at best eased by leveling, taking skill tree components, having the "right" armor/weapon/modifications).

I'm gonna level with y'all, this is just a bad clone of The Witcher 3 with forgettable characters, bland follow-the-trail detective sections, and a disappointingly sparse story that is almost interesting. It also apes Assassin's Creed, Tomb Raider, and Red Dead Redemption, and does them all slightly worse. There're stealth mechanics, things to collect, bow combat, 'tombs' to explore, and animals you hunt to upgrade your inventory. Hell, its primordial techno-architectures even evoke Mass Effect. If you're looking for a well-crafted open world game, you'd be better off with those previously mentioned; and if you wanted thoughtful speculative fiction about a post-climate change world, you'd look into Citizen Sleeper and In Other Waters.

The only thing Horizon does that's unique and a delight to behold are its enemies. They're lovingly animated, dynamic to fight, and depending on where you aim, and with what, the battle changes, as does your loot. You can snipe off a fuel canister from as machine, then leave without killing it; alternatively, you can target it with a flame arrow and set the machine on fire. There's a wee crab fella that carries a container on its back, and you can shoot it off, and, after fighting for a bit, the wee fella will just scuttle over to it, pick it back up, then try to leave. It's beautiful. I truly wish the rest of Horizon's world received this amount of attention and love.

[h1]4/10[/h1] Gorgeous game, but very unpolished. This game feels like a UE5 project that was made by like 5 people. Just from a technical standpoint, the animations are janky while traversing the terrain. This is especially apparent in caves as you constantly get stuck on the stalactites and other geometry. Character clothing, hair and the various accessories they wear constantly clip through their character model. Why does quick saving fade the game to black? There are texture pop-in issues in the pre-rendered 30fps cutscenes.

The artstyle and setting is amazing. Essentially the "prehistoric" tribes are considered the "modern humans" and the sci-fi robot killers are what's left of the "ancient civilization". There is even some Greek mythology in there. But it's all wasted potential. The world is empty, and the side quests are painfully boring. "Go kill x amount of enemies" and go investigate footprints which lead you to some boring character which regurgitates shit you've heard from every other npc in the same monotone voice. For some reason they focus on the inconsequential characters and ones who actually have some character development in the story are killed off. Dialogue choices have no effect on anything. 

Combat is very flawed. The idea to have weakpoints on enemies would have been good if the game rewarded you for shooting them. On normal difficulty you have to shoot some weakspots at least 6 times to deal significant damage. Enemies are spongy and have huge amounts of health, would have been better to actually reward player skill which would lower the time to kill. Melee attacks are a joke and should have been cut. Stealth exists but I don't see why anyone would use it. Robots will become alerted as you can't silent kill big boys and humans are so easy to kill, why bother.

Why do I have to stop every 2 minutes during combat to craft arrows? Unless you loot absolutely nothing, you will never run out of crafting materials. After 10 minutes of gathering you could probably craft thousands of arrows. Having to craft them just ruins the flow of combat.

The map screen looks decent until you buy the collectibles maps and then it looks like a Ubisoftdick game. The UI is constantly cluttered with status effects and damage numbers. I don't like RPG elements where most upgrades are along the lines of "Wow this legendary bow which does 69 damage is much better than my common bow which does 60 damage". The skill tree, weapon and armor mods are pretty bog standard, but a nice addition.

The last "boss" is just some standard enemies you've fought before. As Tak Fuji would say "numbah two graphics"

This game is a beautifully crafted world conjured from a contradictory yet seamless blend of primitive and futuristic technologies. The characters capture the timeless human dichotomy of making sense of the insensible through seeing or believing - but in the end everything is somehow tied together on a deeper level. The attention to detail permeates everything from the visual environments and their biome-specific weather events, to the music that fits each landscape and civilization dispersed throughout the open world. The main story is uniquely captivating and the lore you find along the way might shed some light on the stories of life you unearth... 

Simply put; a masterpiece deserving of a play-through, and of which I almost feel bad that I got on sale because it was worth every penny.

Hoping to see the next installment Horizon: Forbidden West developed for PC.

Gameplay - 8/10
I love the hunting mechanic in Horizon Zero dawn and all the fights with the big machines are very fun and release at least 1 serotonin (yes, i did have to look up how to spell 'serotonin')

Graphics - 9/10
This game looks beautiful and rivals games such as Red Dead Redemption 2 in terms of detail.

Performance - 6/10
You will need a fairly decent PC to play this at a constant 60 fps at high/ultra settings.
This game however, runs perfectly on my mid-high range PC (RX 6600 XT, R5 5600X, 16gb 3600MHz RAM) with over 80 fps all the time on Ultra graphics settings.
However, I did have some major stutters in Meridian (The Big City). This could just be as it was loading as it only happened after fast travelling to Meridian and fixed itself after 10-20 seconds.
Edit: Fixed the stuttering almost completely by just enabling the AMD Radeon anti-lag feature in the AMD Radeon Software settings for HZD with only minor stuttering now that fixes itself in about 10 seconds (Nvidia users will have to find the Equivalent to the anti-lag Feature)

Story - 8/10 (No spoilers)
Great so far but i will not spoil. I will give my full opinion without spoilers once i complete the game.
Some of the mission, however, recommend that the player should be level 7 or over when they have a level 18 boss at the end. This does also happen in some of the side content such as the Sigma Cauldron that recommends level 7 but has a level 18 boss at the end but most of the time this doesn't happen as the side content doesn't have as many bosses at the end of each mission.
Edit: I have finished the story and it is great

Sound - 10/10
The noises that the machines make are something out of a Jurassic Park movie if the dinosaurs were robots.

World - 8/10
The world is pretty big and has a lot of things to do. I have completed many side quests which are very immersive and don't feel like the usual, 'Oh no, the world is going to end, but sure i can fetch some flowers for you'.

what i disliked

i would rate this an 8/10 since games are meant to be an interactive way to watch/see/hear/play a story

The combat in this game just did not gel with me at all and in the end it's a net negative experience. Fighting machines is a real chore and brings no joy, only alleviation of annoying activity, while fighting human enemies is lackluster and very plain. Mechanics of the game feel like they are designed for a very different character, a superhuman of some sort, and in the sequel they give Aloy proper tools with AOE attacks and many other tricks to compensate for her being only human. You always run out of ammo and have to break the flow of a fight to go into inventory and craft some more. You always get stuck in some tree or a rock while trying to dodge enemy attacks because the camera doesn't allow to keep an eye on both. Weapons are just weird and not well balanced, it's clear by the end that heavy guns are most satisfying to use, but they are few and far between. Story is nothing special, it serves it's purpose, but it doesn't keep you invested enough to care about everything that happens, characters here just do not shine and are not memorable.

It's a good base for further improvement, but I cannot recommend it as a fun time.

Across a vast and beautiful open world, Horizon Zero Dawn juggles many moving parts with polish and finesse. Its main activity - combat - is extremely satisfying thanks to the varied design and behaviors of machine-creatures that roam its lands, each of which needs to be taken down with careful consideration. Though side questing could have been more imaginative, its missions are compelling thanks to a central mystery that led me down a deep rabbit hole to a genuinely surprising - and moving - conclusion.

Every time I play the game I kinda lose the motivation to play the game the next day. Somehow the game always fail to capture my attention.

The entire game plays like a slog, from basic function such as having to pick up tons of herbs for healing because there's no reliable way (shops, traders etc) to refill your healing items, to combat which doesn't feel that exiting and satisfying to play (compared to Monster Hunter or any other Souls-like game). Imo, there's also way too much bullet-time combat than it needs to. You could argue that  

There's exactly no reason why the game needs to have an extra menu when salvaging enemies, and the animation that plays every time you collect world items (sticks, herbs, materials etc) makes everything a lot more tedious. Unlike RDR2 where animation plays a major role (such as skinning an animal) for it to be justified, this is not a game that focuses on it, so having to stop each time to collect anything really ruins the entire flow.

Yes, the story might be decent. Yes, the terrain and surrounding looks fantastic. Yes, the enemy designs are of top notch. However, the combat just doesn't click with how the play style revolves around shooting arrows and dark-soul-rolling 90% of the time, and the rest being melee combat that does not feel satisfying to play nor anything amazing to look at.

You could say I didn't spend enough time to reach the good part of the game. But if the game fails to capture my attention for the first 5 hours, I can't bother to finish the rest of it too. I might be biased on my gameplay preferences, so take this review with a grain of salt. I highly suggest people who plan to buy this game looking up the combat of HZD on youtube before making the purchase, because if you are not interested in it, the rest of the gameplay are going to be miserable.

15€ (2023) für 80h+ Spielspaß und einem der besten Geschichtenerzählungen in Spielen überhaupt. Man wird sogar dazu verleitet sich seitenweise kreative, lustige, teils traurige Inhalte durchzulesen. Das erdachte Zukunftsszenario wird dadurch faszinierender, da es an Teilaspekte unserer Gegenwart gekoppelt ist. Die Erzählweise ist komplett verzerrt, was bis zum Ende einen angenehmen Spannungsbogen aufrecht erhält. Man bekommt hier und da Fragmente und malt sich selbst mögliche Szenarien aus und wird dann völlig überrascht.

Vergleich mit Spielen mit ähnlich gutem story telling:
#1 Horizon
#2 Subnautica
#3 Elden Ring

Das Gameplay
Die Kämpfe fühlen sich immer gut an. Die Animationen sind klasse und es existiert eine taktische Bandbreite für alle möglichen Spielstile: getarnt aus dem Hinterhalt, immer feste druff, maximale Effizienz, Kreaturenbändiger oder geländeverminender Stratege, du hast die Wahl und kannst binnen Sekunden deine Strategie wechseln. Am meisten haben mir die Jagdgebiete Spaß gemacht, welche die unterschiedlichen Spielstile vorstellen.

Altersgrenze
Das Spiel ist offiziell ab 12 Jahren gelistet. Keine Ahnung, wie das möglich war, denn die detailierten Animationen, wie man auf unterschiedliche Art und Weise menschlichen NPCs seinen Speer zwischen die Rippen rammt.... uff! Eine Einstufung ab 16 Jahren macht definitiv mehr Sinn bei dieser Darstellung von Gewalt. Solche Auseinandersetzungen kommen geschichtenbasiert auch relativ häufig vor (bei mir ca. 30% aller Kampfszenarien).

Optik
Das Spiel ist auch unglaublich schön. Perfekt, um auch mal im Moment zu verweilen. Man wird regelrecht dazu eingeladen. Probiert ruhig einmal den Foto-Modus aus!

Alles in allem ein Meisterwerk. Ich habe tierischsten Respekt vor dieser komplexen Schaffensleistung, welche mich so in den Bann ziehen konnte. Es war ein schöner gedanklicher Ausflug mit viel angebrachter Kritik an [...].
